My wife thought I was just a computer guy. So when she tried to destroy me in our divorce, I revealed I'm actually a licensed attorney. Guess I should explain how someone ends up being a licensed attorney while their wife thinks they're just a freelance I t consultant. It wasn't some master plan, just a series of decisions that looking back probably saved me from complete financial ruin. Met Victoria when I was 26. She was everything, beautiful, ambitious, working at a high end marketing firm. I was finishing law school at night while doing I t work during the day to pay bills. When we started dating, she made it clear she couldn't be with someone in a boring profession. Like law said, lawyers were all stuffy old men who argued about paperwork. So I didn't mention the law degree, told her I was focusing on tech consulting full time. Yeah, I know, stupid. I was young and she was way out of my league, or so I thought. We got married two years later. By then I'd passed the bar, kept my license active, but never practiced. The I t consulting was actually going well, making decent money, flexible hours. Victoria loved telling people her husband was in tech. She'd literally introduced me at parties as my husband, the tech entrepreneur. Fast forward 10 years, the marriage wasn't what I'd hoped. Victoria had expensive tastes that grew exponentially each year. Designer everything, trips to exclusive resorts, a House we couldn't really afford, but she needed for her image. I worked 70 hour weeks to keep up. She worked maybe 20 hours at her job, spent the rest at the gym, salon or with her friends. The breaking point came six months ago. Found out she'd been having an affair with Derek, her Crossfit trainer. Classic, right? But here's the kicker, she'd been paying him $3,000 a month for private sessions for my business account. Those sessions were definitely private, just not the kind involving exercise. When I confronted her, she laughed, actually laughed, said I was too boring, too predictable. Derek was a real man who knew how to live. Then she said the words that sealed her fate. I want a divorce and I'm taking you for everything. You can barely dress yourself properly. You think you can handle a divorce without me destroying you? I said, okay, filed. The next day, the divorce papers were served and Victoria hired Reginald Ashworth from Ashworth and Associates, one of those lawyers who advertises on billboards, we fight dirty so you don't have to. She called me gloating. Reggie says you're an idiot for not getting a lawyer. He's gonna make sure you're living in your car by the time this is over. What Victoria didn't know was that maintaining a law license for 10 years means required continuing education, kept up with family law changes, divorce proceedings, everything. Boring weekend seminars that were about to pay off. First court date was yesterday, preliminary hearing for temporary orders. Ashworth immediately tried to intimidate me. You know, it's not too late to get representation. I know some budget lawyers who might take pity on you, Victoria chimed in loud enough for everyone to hear. He probably can't even afford the consultation fee. Been supporting this loser for years. He fixes computers for a living. When the judge asked if I was representing myself, Victoria actually snorted. Ashworth smirked. Then I pulled out my perfectly formatted legal documents with proper case citations and evidence references. The look on Ashworth's face was priceless. I presented exhibits showing Victoria had withdrawn $54,000 from my business account for her affair, plus her social media posts about planning to take him for everything. I referenced specific state codes about marital misconduct and economic fault. The judge was looking at me with interest. Seems surprisingly well versed in family law, Mr Thompson. I try to be prepared, your honour. Based on my evidence, the judge denied all Victoria's requests for temporary support and ordered her to return the stolen money within 30 days. Victoria exploded. This is, he can't know all this. He fixes computers. He probably googled it. Discovery phase was illuminating. Ashworth tried every dirty trick. But I responded to everything within 24 hours with proper formatting in case citations. During Victoria's deposition, I presented three years of text messages between her and Derek. Planning this divorce. I'm only staying until I.

With your daddy. Julie started crying. Coached tears. No, I'm scared of him. I want to live with Mommy and grandma forever. No further questions. The judge looked at my lawyer. Does the defense wish to cross examine? Your honor, my lawyer stood. Before we proceed, we need to submit critical evidence that will re contextualize this testimony. This is a delay tactic, Jessica's lawyer protested. Your honor, I have 18 days of video evidence that this child has been coached to give false testimony. The judge's eyebrows raised. That's a serious accusation, counselor. The build a bear she's holding contain the recording device I legally placed there. It has captured her grandmother coaching her on this exact testimony for three weeks. My mother's face went white. Jessica's confident expression cracked. I'll review this in chambers, the judge said. Five minutes later, he returned, his face dark with rage. Clear the courtroom except for essential parties. Now! Once the room emptied, my lawyer connected his laptop to the courtroom screen. The first video started playing. My mother's voice filled the room. Now, Julie, remember what we practiced? When the judge asks you, say, daddy touched you here. Julie's voice on the recording. But he didn't. Grandma. The CPS worker's pen stopped moving. The next video was worse. Julie, you need to cry when you say it. Real tears. Think about your hamster that died. Grandma, I don't want that. Ready to go to jail? He won't go to jail if You do this right, he just won't see you anymore. Then you get that trip to Disney world. Turn it off! Jessica screamed, standing up. This is entrapment! There's seventeen more days of this, my lawyer said calmly, including conversations where Mrs. Dickerson and Mrs. Grimes discussed the coaching strategy. The judge turned to Julie, his voice gentle but firm. Julie, is what you told us today true? Full story on channel linked below.

Hour in my car whenever she couldn't see my lips moving. The words got easier each time. Sometimes I'd tell her about my day, my fears, my dreams. All these one sided conversations she never knew about. One evening, her best friend Graceland visited. They signed rapidly in the kitchen while I pretended to read. I caught pieces of their conversation in my peripheral vision. Annalise was signing emotionally about something. Graceland kept encouraging her. Then I saw it clearly. Annalise signed, I want to propose. But what if he's not ready? We never discuss marriage. Graceland signed back, maybe he's waiting for you to bring it up. Annalise responded, I've been carrying a ring for two months. I'm scared he'll say no. That night, Annalise was washing her face in the bathroom. I stood in the doorway and said clearly, I know you want to propose. She patted her face dry. I saw you signing with Gracelyn earlier. She applied moisturizer. I've been practicing proposing to you for eight months. She brushed her hair. The ring is in my gym bag. I was planning to ask next Saturday at the farmers market where we had our fifth day. She turned off the light, walking past me. The next morning, she was making coffee, facing away from me. I pulled the ring from my gym bag and set it on the counter. Then I said out loud, I love you, Annalise. I've been telling you that for months. When you Weren't looking every day, sometimes twice. She reached for her mug. Turn around. When she did, she saw the ring box. Her eyes went wide. She signed frantically. What? How did I signed? Slowly, clearly. I've been practicing. Then I spoke, knowing she'd read my lips. Will you marry me? She started cry, signing yes before pulling her own ring from her purse.

Transfer the recordings to three separate cloud services and a physical drive in my office safe. Then I took my daughter in, bringing her milk and cookies before calling her a good girl. It wasn't her fault. She had down syndrome and didn't understand the gravity situation. I couldn't be mad at her. When young children do bad things, you point the finger at the adults in their life. The court date arrived three weeks later. The room was packed for what everyone thought was day three of our custody battle. Jessica, my ex wife, sat with her lawyer, looking confident. She been pushing for full custody with supervised visits only. My siblings sat behind my mother. Your honor, Jessica's lawyer announced, we'd like to call Julie Grimes to the stand. My eight year old daughter walked in, clutching her build a bear. She wouldn't look at me. The bailiff helped her onto the witness stand, adjusting the microphone to her height. Julie, Sweetheart, Jessica's lawyer said, I know this is scary, but can you tell the judge what you told your mommy and Grandma? Julie's little voice shook. Daddy. Daddy touches me in bad places. The courtroom gasped. Just. Jessica dabbed her eyes. My mother reached over to squeeze Jessica's hand in support. Where does he touch you? Julie pointed to her private areas. Everyone signed so fast, my eyes couldn't keep up. Her friend signed something that made everyone laugh. Annalise translated. She says, you signed with an accent. Like a baby accent. I tried signing back. At least I'm trying. More laughter. Annalise fixed my hands. You just said, you're crying. Close enough. Two years in, we moved in together. I was fluent by then. Our apartment peaceful, except for her cat, who meowed at shadows. We signed everything, rarely using our voices. Annalise preferred it that way. Said signing felt more natural than trying to read lips all day. But sometimes, when she was focused on something else, reading or cooking or painting her nails, I started talking out loud to her. Just little things at first. You look beautiful in that light. She never reacted. Had no idea. Then it became bigger confessions. I want to marry you someday. She kept stirring pasta sauce. On my way home from work, my home security camera activated. I saw my mother in the living room coaching my 8 year old daughter. In court, I'm gonna say he touched me here. My daughter was pointing at her private parts while my mother hugged her and told her she was a good girl. I almost swerved off the road watching my daughter smile about how she was going to ruin my life in 3 weeks time. The surprise build A bear I bought her was laughing at me from the back seat. The photos of Julie my mother had sent earlier now seemed contaminated. But instead of getting angry and acting on impulse like college me would have, I decided to take matters into my own hands. I sewed a recording device into the build A bear before driving home. Grandma's here! Julie squealed when I walked through the door twenty minutes later, running to me with the same innocent face that had just been rehearsing my destruction. I know, sweetheart, I said, handing her the build A bear. Mr. Snuggles has a new friend for you. My mother smiled that grandmother smile I'd trusted for 42 years. You spoil her, Daniel. How was work? The usual. I kissed Julie's forehead, my stomach churning. Thanks for watching her, mom. Over the next two and a half weeks, became the world's greatest actor. I installed cameras in Julie's dollhouse, her jewelry box, even inside the old tablet. She used for games. Every device was legally purchased and placed in my own home. And items I bought. My lawyer would later call it Genius Tuesday. My mother brought Disney brochures to my daughter for after the bad man goes away, she whispered Julie, who was ecstatic about the holiday and seemed to have no idea of the consequences she was doing. On Thursday, they practiced Julie's testimony again. Remember, baby, tears help. The judge needs to see you're scared of daddy. On Saturday, she gave Julie a new American Girl doll. This is for being such a brave girl. About our secret each night. I

What happened when you met a deaf girl at your cousin's wedding? Three years ago, at my cousin's wedding, I knocked over this girl's drink, reaching across the buffet table. I apologized for 30 seconds straight before realizing she was pointing at her ears and signing something I didn't understand. My cousin texted me later that night. That was Annalise. She lost her hearing from meningitis when she was six. He sent her Instagram. She asked about the guy who kept talking to himself at the buffet. I scrolled through videos of her signing stories, her face animated and express. In one video, she taught basic signs. I watched it over and over, trying to copy her hand movements. She looks so confident, so comfortable in her silence. I messaged her two days later. I'm the idiot who wouldn't stop apologizing at the wedding. Can I buy you a replacement drink? She replied with laughing emojis. You mean the guy who gave a whole speech to a deaf person, then added, yes, but only if you bring a notepad this time? At the coffee shop, we typed messages back and forth on our phones. Annalise told me her parents never Learned ASL after she went deaf. They still think hearing aids solve everything, like glasses for your ears. When she laughed, her whole face lit up. I forgot to read her next message until she waved her hand at me. Stop staring, weirdo! I typed back. Sorry, you're distracting. She Rolled her eyes but smiled. We stayed until they kicked us out of closing. After that date, I downloaded every ASL app I could find. I practiced finger spelling during my commute. Signed to myself in mirrors. My roommate caught me signing in my sleep. Dude, are you cursing someone out? I was apparently signing banana repeatedly. Annalise sent me daily sign tutorials. Today's phrase I'm hopeless at this. I sent videos of my attack.

When did a school safety rule almost cost students their lives? Our middle school had always been pretty relaxed about phones until three eighth graders live streamed themselves destroying the second floor bathroom for a prank. The very next day, the principal announced the harshest policy any school in our district had ever seen. Absolutely zero phones or electronics on school property. No exceptions. Not even if we kept them turned off. They literally hired extra security guards just to search every single backpack at the entrance, confiscating our phones like we were entering a maximum security prison. The searching process would make everyone late, create massive lines in the rain, and turn teachers into prison guards who spent more time hunting for hidden phones than I watched as kids who needed phones for medical alerts, anxiety apps, or insulin monitors got told, too bad, so sad. Our principal was convinced that if even one phone got through, it would corrupt the entire school and turn all of us into future prank Youtubers. Whatever. I never really cared. But then our school announced a field trip for our class, and my parents absolutely refused to let me leave town without a way to contact them. Then my mom got her brilliant idea. She decided to secretly sneak a phone by taping it to my left ankle and told me to keep it. Don't hesitate to use it in an emergency. My mom said I'd never broken a real rule before. So this was nerve wracking for me. My heart was pounding so hard during the security check that I thought everyone could hear it. But the guard just waved me through after checking my empty backpack as we loaded onto bus 1:05, the oldest one in the fleet.

He started coming to my appointments when I mentioned being nervous about going alone, held my hand during the 36 week ultrasound, built the crib I'd ordered online because I couldn't figure out the instructions, all while I took care of Caitlin. It was the life I had always dreamt of having with my ex, Dylan, well before the cheating. But just like all evil villains, Dylan showed up at my apartment just a few weeks before my baby's due date. He knocked on the door aggressively, yelling, come on, sweetheart, let me in! You can't keep my kid from me! I opened the door and glared at him. How's Paige and your other baby? His face twisted in annoyance. It wasn't mine. He forced a smile and grabbed my hand gently. Look, I was wrong for hurting you the way I did, but you need a father for that baby. Some want to take care of you both. I'm doing just fine without you, I said, trying to close the door. He blocked it with his foot, pushing me backwards while he let himself in. Come on, sweet cheeks, we can make this work. Carter stepped out from the guest room to check on the commotion. Dylan broke into a horrifying smile. Are you freaking kidding me? You already found some loser to play daddy? What, you couldn't handle being alone for five minutes? Or is he the bio father, too? Get out or I'll make you! Carter said. Stepping forward completely, towering over Dylan. Dylan but a scared step back and nodded. I'll get custody, get you both arrested. He stormed off, shouting about his lawyers, which I guess was just a bluff since we never really heard from him again. Dylan was right about one thing, though. My baby did need a father. Good thing we found the perfect one. Carter and I settled down in a house together and tied the knot when Caitlin was old enough to walk down the aisle as a flower girl and our son was old enough to waddle down with the rings.

Portland was perfect for starting over, gray and rainy and nobody knew me. I got a job that didn't care about my pregnancy and found a doctor who didn't judge when I said there was no father involved. Everything was good. But it was at the prenatal classes where things just rapidly escalated. From an exhausted guy named Carter walked in late to the class carrying a Newborn. Sorry, he said to the instructor. Caitlin had a rough night. You can pair up with her, the instructor said, pointing at me, the only other single parent in the room. During the diaper demonstration, his practice doll's head fell off and he just stared at it. Three months in and I still can't keep a fake baby together, he muttered, frustrated at himself. I laughed and helped him reattach the head. She looks pretty healthy for someone whose dad can't work a practice doll, I said. He smiled in appreciation. I'm just glad babies are a lot sturdier than this thing. We joked around with each other a bit more before Carter sighed and said with a sad expression, her mother would have been amazing at this if she were still here. I reached out and put my hand over his. You're amazing enough now. Don't lose confidence. You're my partner here. He sat up straight and gave the practice another go. We started getting coffee after class. He needed help figuring out his daughter Caitlin's sleep schedule and I needed Someone who didn't look at me with pity. We just talked about normal stuff, baby products and keep nutritionists and whether organic formula was worth the price. But after a couple of weeks, things shifted. We started hanging out as friends, even calling each other husband and wife when strangers asked. He started coming to my appointments when I mentioned being nervous about going alone, held my hand during the 36 week ultrasound, built the crib I'd ordered online because I couldn't figure out the instructions, all while I took care.

When my boyfriend said he wasn't ready for kids, I didn't realize he was already a father. Three pregnancy tests lined up on my bathroom counter, all positive. I couldn't believe the timing. My boyfriend's birthday was in two days and this was the best present I could ever give him. I threw on my coat and rushed to target before they closed and immediately started crying when I found a tiny Dodgers onesie in the baby section. Remembering how my boyfriend Dylan talked about teaching his own kid on the field someday, I stuffed the onesie and pregnancy tests in a happy birthday bag and headed to his apartment. I wasn't prepared to be the one that got surprised. When I got to his door, I could hear voices inside and I figured it could have been anyone until I heard that laugh, that specific laugh that once tormented me in college. It was Paige, his ex. She answered the door wearing his old baseball Jersey, the one he'd never let me touch. Her hand immediately went to her stomach as she smirked at me. I felt all the color drain from my face. Oh, god, she was pregnant, like several months pregnant. Dylan appeared behind her and instantly went just as pale. Before he could say anything, Paige stepped in. We've been back together since Christmas, she said, rubbing her belly. He didn't tell you. We've been living together this week, preparing for the baby. F me Christmas. We'd spent New Year's Eve together, Valentine's Day, even my birthday, all those chances to end things and tell me the truth, only to knock me up to this evil jerk. I took a deep breath and set the gift bag down on his doorstep. Happy early birthday. On my way home, he called me over and over, but I refused to answer. I blocked him everywhere, even blocked his family and blocked anyone who tried to help him reach out to me. I moved in with my cousin, hoping for a duo.

When did your grandparents sexist rules almost kill them? My grandparents were absolutely convinced that strong women were an abomination. After my parents died and they got custody, they enforced the most insane rule. I couldn't lift anything over five pounds. Not groceries, not textbooks, not even my own backpack. They genuinely believed that if a girl developed any muscle, she'd become manish and unmarriageable. At 15, I watched my female classmates play volleyball and carry their younger siblings, while I had to ask boys to carry my lunch tray. The humiliation was constant. During PE, I had to sit on the bleech there's with a fake doctor's note my grandmother had somehow obtained, claiming I had delicate feminine constitution. When teachers asked why I couldn't participate in the fitness tests, my grandfather would arrive at school to lecture them about preserving young ladies fragility. Women who lift heavy things damage their wombs. He'd tell my horrified gym teacher, we're protecting her future children. My grandmother would nod along, adding how her own mother never lifted anything heavier than a teacup and lived to 90. The other kids started calling me Princess. Helpless behind my back, I'd stand there watching everyone load equipment after class, while I wasn't allowed to even stack chairs. When a male classmate jokingly flex near me, my grandmother report and him to the principal for encouraging masculine behavior in young ladies. Then our neighbor, Mister Reid, a retired physical therapist, noticed me struggling to open Our front door. One day he'd watched me fail to carry grocery bags from the car while my elderly grandparents struggled with them. Instead, during one of their church mornings, he knocked on my window. This is dangerous, he said quietly. In emergencies, you need basic strength. He started showing me exercises I could do silently in my room. Push UPS against my bed frame. Squats while they slept. Lifting paint cans in the garage during their three hour Sunday services. I do planks while they nap, building core strength. They couldn't see under my loose dresses. Mister Reid left resistance bands hidden in our shed, teaching me routines through the fence. For months I trained in secret, terrified they discover the slight firmness developing in my arms. Then one November night changed everything. I woke to the smoke alarm shrieking at 2:00am. Black smoke was already seeping under my bedroom door. I ran to my grandparents room, finding them coughing and disoriented. The hallway was an orange nightmare of flames eating through our old wooden walls. My grandfather tried to get up, but the ceiling beam above their bed suddenly crashed down, pinning him across his chest. He's screamed in pain, trapped completely. My grandmother pulled uselessly at the massive beam, her fragile arms shaking. Get help! She cried. But the flames had already blocked the stairs. The smoke was getting thicker, making us all choke. My grandfather's face was turning purple, the beam crushing his ribs. My grandmother Kept pulling, sobbing, accomplishing nothing

At my 21st birthday dinner, my aunt asked, what did you decide to do with the three million dollars? What three million? I asked. We were all sitting around our dining room table eating Mom's lasagna. The settlement money, Aunt Christie continued, looking confused. From the hospital accident when you were a baby. You were supposed to get all of it when you turned 21. My mind went completely blank. I had no idea what she was talking about. Mom and dad started glaring at Aunt Christie like they were telling her to remain quiet. Aunt Christie, I think you're confused, said, trying to laugh it off as maybe a joke. I don't have any money, let alone 3 million. I work at target. You never told him about the settlement? Aunt Christie asked, my parents starting to look pissed. Mom stood up fast and started clearing plates, even though we weren't done eating. Christie, stop right now! She hissed. This is none of your business! Dad stood up too. Christie, you need to leave now! But Aunt Christie wasn't backing down. When you were one year old, she said, turning to me, the hospital gave you the wrong medication. Your heart stopped, your kidneys failed. You were in a coma for a week. Sarah, shut up! Mom screamed. Dad tried to grab Aunt Christie's arm, but she pulled away. He deserves to know! She shouted. At the back. I saw Dad's water glass shaking in his hand before it spilled. All over his pants. After you recovered, Aunt Christie continued quickly, your parents sued the hospital. They won $3 million. The money was put in a trust fund for you. Your parents were supposed to manage it until you turned 21. Until today. I started thinking about my life. I have been working since I was 16, sharing a crappy apartment with three roommates so I could one day afford college tuition. My parents never helped with bills. They always claimed that they were struggling. Wait, I said, my brain finally catching up to what was happening. If there were $3 million with my name on it, where are they? Why have I been living like this? Why did you tell me we couldn't afford college? Dad wouldn't look at me. Mom kept washing the same plate over and over, scrubbing it so hard, I thought it might break. Mom! Dad! My voice was getting louder. Now where is my money? We were going to tell you, mom finally said. She was crying. Now tell me what? I stood up, but my legs felt weak. That you had $3 million for me this whole time, while I was working double shifts at target. It wasn't just your money! Dad suddenly shouted. We raised you. We paid for your food, your clothes, your childhood. We deserved something! Deserved? I couldn't believe what I was hearing. We invested it, mom said quickly. For your future. We technically didn't spend it. Invested. Aunt Christie laughed, but It wasn't a happy sound. Tell him the truth, dear. Tell him about Vegas. Tell him about the cruises. Tell him about the gambling. Those were business opportunities, dad yelled. We were building wealth for the family. Everything clicked in my head at once. All those weekend trips my parents took. They called them business trips. But dad worked at a hardware store and mom was a receptionist. I trusted them. But what business trips could they possibly have? Did you spend my money gambling? I suddenly felt sick at the implication. The money from when I almost died as a baby. You spent it on casinos? We were trying to make it grow, dad said. We thought we could turn it into 10 million, 20 million for all of us. How much is left? I asked. Nobody answered. How much is left? It doesn't matter, mom said. We're your parents. We know what's best for you. Tell me how.

Why was my teenage daughter suddenly obsessed with learning Spanish? My sixteen year old Valentina had never shown interest in languages. She barely passed English class and once told me learning foreign languages was pointless torture designed by sadistic teachers. But exactly three weeks ago, everything changed. Overnight she started going crazy about learning Spanish with books and Duolingo. Since when do you care about Spanish? I asked over dinner Tuesday night, watching her scribble verb conjugations on napkins between bites of pasta. College applications look way better with a second language, Dad. Yale and Harvard basically require it now, she said, completely avoiding eye contact and fidgeting with her fork nervously. Fair enough reasoning, but then incredibly weird things started happening that made zero sense. I heard her having full conversations on the phone in absolutely perfect Spanish. Not broken beginner Spanish with grammar mistakes. Fluent, rapid fire, native level Spanish with complex slang and regional accents. The kind you definitely don't learn from Duolingo. In three weeks, I secretly checked her browser history expecting tons of language learning websites and online Spanish courses. Absolutely nothing. Just regular teenage stuff. TikTok, Instagram, YouTube, makeup tutorials, and Amazon shopping. No Duolingo progress. No Spanish websites, no online classes anywhere. One morning around 7 a. M. I heard Valentina on Facetime speaking to someone in incredibly rapid Spanish, laughing hysterically and using slang expressions I didn't recognize. When she suddenly noticed me standing in the doorway with my coffee, she immediately Switched to awkward English. Okay, um, talk to you later about the, uh, homework assignment we discussed. The person on the other end very clearly said, Diamo mochissimo, mi amor before she frantically hung up. Who exactly was that? I asked as casually as possible. Just my Spanish study group, she mumbled, her face turning bright red. We practice conversations together for authenticity. Study groups def. Definitely don't end with I love you so much, my love. I started paying much closer attention to everything. Valentina would mysteriously disappear for three to four hours, claiming Spanish Club meetings at Jefferson High. But when I called the main office, pretending to ask about pickup times, they said Spanish Club had been permanently canceled all semester due to complete lack of student interest. Last Tuesday afternoon, fancy package arrived specifically addressed to Valentina Rodriguez, not her real last name. Inside was a gorgeous silver necklace with Mi Corazon Aterno engraved on an expensive heart shaped pendant. Real silver, professional craftsmanship. Probably $300 minimum. Secret admirer sending jewelry now? I teased, carefully examining the intricate Spanish engraving. She defensively

My girlfriend said no girl would date a gamer, so the gaming community made her single. Annabelle stood in my doorway while I was practicing my build orders for Starcraft and pulled the plug from my computer. This. She waved at my setup. All of this. You need to quit gaming. I laughed, thinking she was joking. She wasn't. Adult men don't play video games. And you have a girlfriend now. You should be taking me out to dinners and spending money on traveling instead. I disagreed, but I couldn't argue either. I was crazy about her. She was beautiful, funny, and up until this moment, I thought she was perfect. I pulled her into my lap and smiled. I have a tournament coming up that I've been training for. After that, I'm all yours. I leaned in to give a kiss, but she dodged it, rolling her eyes. I don't care if it's a million dollars. It's pathetic, she said in a cold voice. If you loved me, you'd stop playing. I stared at her, dumbfounded. You're not serious, I said. Delete everything or I'm done. You have 24 hours, and trust me, you don't want to choose. Wrong! She threatened and walked out. I'll compromise, I told her over dinner at the expensive sushi place she loved. 10 to midnight, only two hours after the tournament. In three weeks, we can talk about me quitting completely. She stabbed at her salmon roll. Two hours every night is 14 Hours a week? You're ignoring me. Babe, I. I said gently. You're literally just scrolling on your phone during that time. Look, I'll take you anywhere you want. More dinners like this, weekend trips, whatever you want. Just give me two hours to practice. Her eyes lit up at my offer. Fine. But I'm keeping track. And if you play one minute past midnight, we're done. For about a week, she seemed satisfied. I took her to fancy restaurants twice a week, brunches every weekend. That trip to Nepal she'd been hinting about? Booked it. A friend's birthday party where I knew nobody. I was there making small talk about zodiac signs and things I didn't really care about. I responded to every text within minutes, watched her reality shows without complaint, posted couple photos twice a day. But I felt something shifting. He started making snide comments about my gaming again. She'd spam my phone during practices, saying, sorry, I'm not as important as your little game. It was exhausting, but all I could think about was my tournament in two weeks. But my girlfriend wasn't planning on making it easy. When Annabelle realized I wouldn't stop my two hour gaming sessions, she started involving our family, telling my parents she felt like she was competing with a computer. My own mother pulled me aside to ask if I needed help for my gaming addiction. Then she went public. She posted a thirst trap on Instagram. I'm showing her In black lingerie on our bed with me gaming in the background with a pole in front. Asking what would you choose, me or gaming? All her friends trashed me in the comments and as if it wasn't enough she became violent, spilling wine on my keyboard, unplugging my router during ranked matches to charge her phone, cutting cables, even deleting save files from my console games. When I was working from the office at a local gaming meet up I vented to a stream about my tanking rank and missing equipment. Dude, think about it. If you had a friend in the situation, what would you tell them? Run! I said with a tired sigh. So. And that struck me hard. Smash! I woke up to the sound of my keyboard shattering again.

I told my sister that my wife isn't spoiled, her husband just doesn't like her. My sister Amy has been making snide comments about my marriage for years now. Every single time she sees me doing something nice for my wife Sadie, she gets this bitter look on her face like I personally ruined her entire day and stomped on her dreams. Last month at Mom's house during our weekly Sunday dinner, I got up to refill Sadie's coffee cup because she was tired from pulling double shifts at the hospital. Amy practically snorted and made this disgust did face. Really? She can't walk to the kitchen herself? Her legs work just fine. Two weeks ago I casually mentioned buying Sadie flowers for absolutely no reason other than I saw them and thought she'd like them. Amy rolled her eyes so hard I genuinely thought they'd get permanently stuck back there. Must be nice to have a husband who wastes money on dead plants that'll be gone in three days. But yesterday was the absolute final straw that broke my patience completely. We were at Sunday dinner again and Sadie mentioned her back was really bothering her from all those 12 hour nursing shift she's been pulling. Without even thinking about it, I started gently massaging her shoulders right there at the table. Amy slammed her fork down so hard it made everyone jump. Oh my god. Seriously? Why do you always do all that? She has hands, doesn't she? She's a perfectly capable grown woman who can take care of herself. The whole table went completely silent. Sadie looked absolutely embarrassed and uncomfortable. Mom cleared her throat awkwardly. Dad just stared at his play. But Amy wasn't even close to being done with her little tantrum. She leaned forward across the table with this nasty, vindictive smile plastered on her face. You know what's really funny to me? You never did stuff like that for me when we were kids growing up together. And I'm your actual blood sister. She's just your wife. That's when something deep inside me finally snapped. Lately, see, Amy's husband, Tom, is genuinely one of the absolute nicest guys I've ever known in my entire life. He's incredibly kind, patient beyond belief. Works two demanding jobs to support their family financially, never complains about anything, never raises his voice even when frustrated. But I've been watching Amy systematically tear him down for 15 long years now. At their wedding reception, Tom surprised her with an expensive honeymoon upgrade he'd saved for months to afford. She complained the room was too small and the view sucked. Every single family gathering, Tom tries to hold her hand or put his arm around her lovingly. She shrugs him off like he's some annoying stranger bothering her. When he tells jokes, trying to make everyone laugh, she gives him this look like he's completely embarrassing her in front of everyone. Three months ago, at my birthday party, Tom Pulled me aside, looking absolutely exhausted and defeated. His shoulders were slumped and he looked like he hadn't slept properly in weeks. I honestly don't know what I'm doing wrong anymore, he said quietly, staring at the ground. I try to be romantic and thoughtful. She says I'm being too clingy. I give her the space she seems to want.

What unhinged rule did your landlord make that literally cost them thousands? My landlord shows up at my town home last week with a new rental addendum. No automotive work in the driveway, she says, looking at my toolbox with disgust. This is a respectable complex, not a mechanic shop. It's unseemly for our female residents to be crawling around under cars looking so dirty. She glances at my grease stained tank top and shorts. Maybe try some more appropriate hobbies. Yoga perhaps? I noticed her teenage son peering around her shoulder, staring at my legs like he always does. Last month I literally had to spray him with a hose when he wouldn't stop hovering while I worked. Fine, I tell her, wiping my hands on a rag. No more unladylike activities with tools. I'll leave all the mechanical stuff to the professionals. She smiles, satisfied, and walks away. But here's what my landlord doesn't realize. For three years I've been handling basic maintenance around the complex in exchange for a discount on rent. Nothing official, just a handshake deal I made with her husband when I first moved in. But he cheated. She divorced. Now she's my landlord. The first week after the new rule, her garbage disposal jams. She texts me to fix it like always. I tell her can't use tools. Remember? You said it was unseemly. She I have to call a plumber. $200 for what would have been a 5 minute reset. Then the Security gate starts sticking. I used to spray the track with WD40 every month. Now it groans and shutters every time it opens and closes. She and her son spend an entire afternoon trying to fix it with YouTube videos. The repair guy charges her $300 and

My mom gave me an ultimatum. Pay the rent for my golden child brother and his girlfriend or face the consequences. So I refused. A week later, they showed up on my doorstep with their things, saying, we're moving in with you. I'm Ruby, and I've been the responsible one my entire life. While my brother Jake bounced between jobs, I worked through college, built my career, and saved toward buying my own place. Jake is 28 and has never held a job longer than six months. I helped pay for his college tuition, which he wasted by dropping out. Two years ago, he moved into my apartment after getting evicted, turning it into a disaster zone with random parties. Final straw was walking in on him having sex with some girl on my couch, the couch I'd saved months to buy. I gave him a week to leave, but my parents immediately sided with him. Family helps family. My mother said. Jake is going through a phase. A phase? He was 26 years old. Last week, my mother called, inviting me to dinner to meet Jake's new fiance, Megan. When I arrived, I found out they'd gotten engaged after three weeks. Megan was unemployed, but claimed she was looking for something worthy of her talents. After dinner, my parents revealed the real reason for the invitation. They wanted me to pay hey Jake and Megan's monthly rent while they covered the deposit. No, I said flatly, absolutely not. The Silence was deafening. So you won't help your own brother? My father demanded. Neither Jake nor Megan said a word. They let my parents fight their battle. Jake can get a job like everyone else, I said, grabbing my purse. My mother stood up. If you walk out that door without agreeing to help, there will be consequences, Ruby. I walked out anyway. What I didn't tell them was that I just received a massive year end bonus. Combined with my savings, I finally had enough for a down payment on my own condo. For days, my phone exploded with guilt trip messages. I ignored them all and finalized my condo purchase and came that Saturday. When my doorbell rang, my parents stood there with Jake and Megan behind them. My mother pushed past me, then turned to Megan like a tour guide. This is the living room. Ruby's bedroom is the master. That will be yours and Jake's. Ruby can take the pullout couch. Megan inspected my space. It's smaller than I expected, but I guess it'll do. What exactly is happening? I asked. My mother smiled coldly. Remember what I said about consequences? Jake and Megan are moving in. I'll take your bedroom, you'll sleep in the living room, and they won't pay rent. Instead of exploding, I forced a smile. Fine, but I need two weeks to arrange things with my landlord. The shock on their faces was priceless. The moment they left, I called my realtor. I need to close on that condo immediately. By Friday, I was signing documents. That weekend, I quietly moved everything to my new place, leaving only basics to make it look like I still lived in the rental. I left Jake the spare key as promised when he called asking where I was.

How did you convince 80 teenagers to break into your principal's house at midnight? My grandfather wasn't just Westfield High's principal. He was its beating heart. He'd show up to spirit week in full costume, lose his voice at Pep rallies, and turn senior pranks into legendary battles he somehow always won. The man literally orchestrated a midnight operation to relocate every senior desk onto the football field after they flipped his office upside down. But when we lost grandma last spring, we lost him, too. He'd become the complete opposite. No more costumes, no more jokes, and definitely no more pranks. When my classmates started buzzing about senior prank ideas in March, he shut it down immediately over the morning announcements. There will be no senior prank this year. Any student caught attempting one will not walk at graduation. This is non negotiable. Everyone kept coming up to me in the hallways. Josh, you have to talk to him. Come on, you're his grandson. He'll listen to you. But I already tried. Every Sunday dinner at his empty house, I'd watch him push food around his plate in that too quiet kitchen where grandma used to hum while cooking. He'd just grunt when I mentioned school traditions. Rules are rules, Josh, even for you. My friends were relentless, though. During lunch, everyone kept begging me to come up with some. That's when I remembered this hilarious TikTok I'd seen where an entire senior class snuck into their principal's house. For a sleepover? Just camping out in sleeping bags until he woke up. It was wholesome, harmless, and honestly, kind of sweet. I looked around the table. Guys, what if we all broke into his house for a sleepover? The planning was intricate, but everyone was committed to pulling this off perfectly. I still had a spare key from when I used to stay over as a kid, and I knew my grandfather's routine by heart. He always took his hearing aid out at night and slept like a rock until his 6 a m. Alarm. We wouldn't damage anything or steal anything. We just be 80 seniors with sleeping bags, having the world's quietest slumber party in his living room and kitchen. I knew every creak in that house, every security light, even which windows he never locked. At midnight on April 30th, I LED the entire senior class through his backyard. We moved like ninjas, carrying sleeping bags and pillows, suppressing giggles as we filed through the back door. Everyone was so careful and respectful. We laid out our sleeping bags in perfect rows, took selfies, giving thumbs up, and settled in to wait for his shocked face in the morning. People were already imagining his reaction, wondering if he'd laugh, yell, or secretly be impressed. I knew him well enough to know that after the initial shock, he'd probably make us all breakfast and tell the story for years. At 2:00am, we had finally all settled down and Most of us were already drifting off to sleep. That's when we heard it. A massive thud from upstairs, followed by something that sounded like gasping. I don't remember running upstairs, just suddenly being there. Grandpa was on the floor, barely breathing, his face the color of ash. He was clutching his chest like he was trying to hold his heart inside his body. And when our eyes met, I saw something I'd never seen before. My grandfather was terrified. Call 9 1 1! I screamed, my voice breaking as I dropped to my knees beside him. Grandpa, it's me. It's Josh. You're going to be okay. The next few minutes were pure chaos. Sophie was already sobbing into the phone with emergency services. Tom, who'd been a lifeguard, had his fingers on my grandfather's pulse, calling out.

My boyfriend claimed his ex was a psycho stalker, harassing him daily. When I discovered why she kept calling, I made one decision that burned his life to the ground. I didn't notice it at first. You'd think a woman would immediately recognise when her boyfriend of two years is lying about his psycho stalker ex. But Hayden was smart about it. He'd show me threatening texts from his crazy ex, delete her number in front of me, then restore everything when I left for work. It wasn't until she contacted my work email directly that I saw the first crack in his story. This woman is insane, Hayden said, reading her message over my shoulder. How did she even find where you work? The message didn't sound crazy. Please, just five minutes. He's lying to you. I have proof. Delete it, he said, not meeting my eyes. Has she been stalking you this whole time? I asked. Since we broke up two years ago, Sylvia. He pulled me close. I sat there stunned. We've been together for two years. Why is she still contacting you? Some people can't handle rejection, he said dismissively. I've tried everything. Police won't help without physical threats. I just protect you from most of it. I believed him until I met his ex. Three weeks later, I was at my usual coffee shop when a woman approached my table. Professional blazer, designer bag, and visibly pregnant. You're Sylvia, she said quietly. I studied her Face, pretty, put together. Nothing like the unstable person Hayden described. You're the ex. I'm not his ex. She placed her hand on her belly. I'm his girlfriend of four years. This is his baby. The coffee shop seemed to tilt. Hayden stayed at my place five nights a week. We had dinner with my parents every Sunday. We were planning a vacation to Spain. What did she mean, girlfriend of four years? She pulled out her phone, hand steady. I know this is shocking. She showed me recent photos from last week. Hayden kissing her belly. Their shared apartment lease from three months ago. An ultrasound dated two weeks prior with Hayden signature on the sign in sheet. Text messages where Hayden called me. This crazy girl from work who keeps hitting on me and the stalker who won't leave me alone. Your work trips? I managed to ask. Those are his nights home with me. She scrolled through her calendar. He tells me he's at sales conferences. I took photos of every piece of evidence. We sat there for 90 minutes, comparing schedules, matching lies. Her name was Raya. They've been together since college. The pregnancy was planned. They were house shopping. She hadn't even known about me until recently. That night, when Hayden arrived at my apartment, I played my role perfectly. I kissed him hello, made dinner, asked about his day. He sprawled on my couch discussing our weekend plans while simultaneously texting. Right. That he Was stuck at a client dinner that was running late for three days. I investigated everything. Found his parents on Facebook, devoted Catholics who posted daily Bible verses. Discovered they paid his rent believing he was in graduate school for his MBA. Found out his father had gotten him the job at their friend's investment firm. Learned they had no idea about Raya, the pregnancy, or me. Raya and I were now allies. Share. Bring information. On day 4, I made my move. Hayden was at an emergency client meeting. He was actually at Raya's prenatal appointment. She was sending me real time updates from the waiting room. I composed a detailed Facebook message to his parents. Attached every screenshot, the ultrasound photos, pictures with time stamps showing him with both of us on the same day.

My girlfriend said no girl would date a gamer, so the gaming community made her single. Annabelle stood in my doorway while I was practicing my build orders for Starcraft and pulled the plug from my computer. This. She waved at my setup. All of this. You need to quit gaming. I laughed, thinking she was joking. She wasn't. Adult men don't play video games, Jake. And you have a girlfriend now. You should be taking me out to dinners and spending money on traveling instead. I disagreed, but I couldn't argue either. I was crazy about her. She was beautiful, funny, and up until this moment, I thought she was perfect. I pulled her into my lap and smiled. I have a tournament coming up that I've been training for. After that, I'm all yours. I leaned in to give a kiss, but he dodged it, rolling her eyes. I don't care if it's a million dollars. It's pathetic, she said in a cold voice. If you loved me, you'd stop playing. I stared at her, dumbfounded. You're not serious, I said. Delete everything or I'm done. You have 24 hours, and trust me, you don't wanna choose. Wrong. She threatened and walked out. I'll compromise, I told her over dinner at the expensive sushi place she loved. 10 to midnight, only two hours after the tournament. In three weeks, we can talk about me quitting completely. She stabbed at her salmon roll. Two hours every night is 14 Hours a week? You're ignoring me? Babe, I said gently. You're literally just scrolling on your phone during that time. Look, I'll take you anywhere you want. More dinners like this, weekend trips, whatever you want. Just give me two hours to practice. Her eyes lit up at my offer. Fine. But I'm keeping track. And if you play one minute past midnight, we're done for about a week. She seemed satisfied.

Groom paid me $300 to ruin his wedding. Turns out he didn't need me. I'm scrolling through Craigslist at 3:00am because my car insurance is due in six hours and I've got exactly $139 to my name. Then this ad pops up. Easy $300. Need actor for wedding performance. Must be comfortable with public speaking. One time gig this Saturday. Listen, for 300 bucks I'd explain to Gordon Ramsay why ketchup belongs on steak. So I click reply faster than I've ever clicked anything. This guy messages back in literally 30 seconds asking if I can object at his wedding. I'm staring at my phone like it just grew legs. He explains he needs someone to stand up during the speak now or forever hold your peace part and just say they object. Make something up about loving the bride or whatever. Just stop the wedding before I can even process how insane this is. $150 hits my Venmo. You get the other half after you do it. My car insurance Bill is staring at me from my laptop screen. $285. I text him back asking why he wants to ruin his own wedding. He says I Learned something that's made it impossible for me to marry my girl. I can hear the tea being poured, but instead I'm texting the stranger I'll be there like I'm agreeing to pick up milk from the store. I show up to this country club that's so fancy. The security guard looks at My TRP car like it might contaminate the parking lot. I have to lie that I'm with the band just to get through the gate. She's built like she could throw me through a wall for fun. You're not on the guest list, she says. I'm trying to play dumb, but she leans in close enough that I can smell her perfume. I heard my brother on the phone last night. He hired someone to ruin this wedding. That wouldn't be you, would it? If it is, you should know I will absolutely destroy you. She shows me her fitness app like it's a weapon, and there's a photo of her choking someone out at what looks like a dojo. I'm nodding like a bobblehead on a dashboard while she explains this is her brother and best friend getting married, and if I try anything, she'll end me. The announcement comes for everyone to take their seats, and she points at me with two fingers, then at her eyes, then back at me before walking away to join the wedding party. I grab another champagne and down it straight up, then follow the crowd into this church that probably cost more to build than my entire neighborhood. The ceremony starts, and the bride looks like she Stepped out of heaven. While the groom is sweating so much. His tux looks like he went for a dip in the pool. The maid of honor, that purple dress Terminator from earlier. Keeps turning around from the altar to stare directly at me. Then it happens. The priest says those magic words. If anyone objects to this union, speak now or forever hold your peace. My body moves before my brain can stop it, and I stand up. I object. The words

Oh, not break up. Just a break. You'd wait, and we'd get back together when I'm ready. Lexi, what you're describing is breaking up. You wanna date other guys while keeping me as your safety net? I'm 29, not some college kid waiting around hoping you pick me eventually. She completely lost it, crying about how I didn't fight for us and how four years should mean something. Four years did mean something to me. Enough that I wasn't going to cheapen it by turning it into a backup plan. She spent another hour negotiating. Maybe three months. Maybe we could still see each other sometimes. Every compromise proved she saw our relationship as optional, something she could control based on her whims. Next morning, I returned the engagement ring I've been planning to propose with on New Year's Eve. Use that refund to upgrade my PC setup and get back into gaming. Lexi's exploration wasn't going well. She Dated a self absorbed personal trainer, a DJ who used her for rides and

That's when mom decided she was done with the whole parenting thing. Not done having kids, just done raising them. That became my job. I became the family's live in nanny. Meanwhile, I was making breakfast, packing lunches, checking homework, giving baths, reading bedtime stories, the works. She even started a blog about raising successful children. I read one post where she talked about teaching kids independence. Yeah, by making your oldest daughter do all the work while you get day drunk with the neighborhood moms. When I finally got out for college on a scholarship I earned despite everything, mom acted shocked I didn't come home every weekend. Then after graduation, when I got my own apartment, she couldn't understand why I wasn't moving back home. The kids, they needed their big sister. Translation, she needed her free babysitter back. So last month, mom organized this big family dinner for my 25th birthday. Fancy restaurant. The whole family dressed up for about an hour. It was actually nice. Kids were telling me about school, asking about my promotion. Mom was weirdly quiet, but I figured she was trying to be better. Then she stood up to make a speech. This whole thing about family and raising wonderful children and how blessed she was. My brother was premed. The twins were on a roll. The baby was apparently some kind of art genius. All because of her amazing parenting. She kept going. I remember when each of them Was born the sleepless nights, the endless laundry, the constant worry. But look at them now. I'm so proud of what I've accomplished as a mother. She actually dabbed at her eyes with her napkin, like she was getting emotional about her own lies. That's when she looked at me and said it. Eight year old asked, why did Mommy tell daddy you're the reason they're getting divorced? I nearly dropped the juice box I was handing to her little brother. What do you mean, sweetie? My voice came out higher than normal as my stomach dropped like a stone. Emma's big brown eyes stared at me with that brutal honesty only kids possess. Mommy was crying on the phone last night. She said, you ruined everything and now daddy has to move out. The living room suddenly felt too small, too quiet, except for the cartoon still playing on the TV. I knelt down to Emma's level, my hands trembling slightly. sometimes adults say things when they're upset that don't make sense. But even as I said it, my mind raced through every interaction I'd had with the Morrison family. David thanking me for watching the kids still seeming distant lately, barely making eye contact during pickup. The way she'd started paying me through Venmo instead of cash. Her messages cold and formal. Something was very wrong here, and I had no idea what I'd supposedly done. Emma tilted her head like she was trying to solve a puzzle. But mommy showed daddy pictures on her phone. She said you were doing bad things. My blood turned to ice as I grabbed my phone. With shaking fingers, I started scrolling through my photo gallery, my social media, anything that Rachel might have seen and miss transcribed. Then I found it. Buried. In my Instagram from two weeks ago, a photo I posted of myself making breakfast at 7:00am, still in my pajamas, with the caption Sunday morning vibes. In the background, barely visible through my kitchen window, was David's car parked in my driveway. But David hadn't been at my house that morning. I've been alone, making pancakes for myself, like I did every weekend. I stared at the photo, zooming in on the silver sedan that looked exactly like his Honda Civic. The license plate was partially obscured, but the first three letters were clearly visible. K J H. David's plate started with K J H. Called my neighbour, Missus Chen, who had security cameras facing the road. Within 20 minutes, she'd sent me footage from that Sunday morning at 6:00am, showing David's car pulling into my driveway while I was clearly visible through my kitchen window, alone and cooking. The footage revealed something that made my stomach lurch. David had sat in my driveway for over an hour, just watching my house while I moved around inside, completely unaware. Missus Chen's cameras captured him taking photos through his car window, angling his phone to make it look like he was inside with me. The time stamps showed he'd been there from 6:47 to 8:00am, documenting my morning routine like surveillance. I realized with growing horror that David had been creating fake evidence of an affair that didn't exist. I immediately called Rachel, my voice shaking as I tried to Explain, Rachel. I need to show you something about the photos David gave you. But she cut me off, screaming that I was a homewrecker who destroyed her family. She hung up before I could tell her about the security footage. Twenty minutes later, I heard shouting from next door. Through my window, I watched David storm out with a suitcase while Rachel stood in the doorway yelling. Emma and her brother were pressed against their upstairs window, watching their world fall apart because of lies their father had created. Detective Morrison arrived that evening after Rachel filed a police report claiming David and I were having an affair. I showed her the security footage, a timeline of David's staged photographs, and my phone records proving I'd never communicated with him outside of babysitting arrangements. She studied everything carefully, then asked if I'd noticed.

Girl cornered me at the grocery store and asked, why don't you remember me? Mom? I'm sorry. What? I asked, thinking she'd mistaken me for someone else. Her voice cracked with anger. Mom, it's me, Emily. Your daughter. A strange tingling crept up my spine. I think you're confused. I don't have any children. She pulled out a birth certificate from her backpack and showed it to me. I know you're my mother. You gave birth to me on March 15th, 2007. I looked at the paper and my name was there. I would have been 17 then. I'm 35 now. The math worked, but nothing else did. This has to be fake, I said, though my hands had started trembling. I've never been pregnant. I think I would have remembered if I gave birth. Emily's voice broke completely. I've been looking for you for months. Finally found you, and now you're acting like I'm nothing. I backed away from this strange woman. Look, I don't know you. I've never seen you before. Her eyes filled with tears of rage. Just look at me! Everyone says I look exactly like you. How can you stand there and pretend you don't know me? The resemblance was unsettling, but that didn't mean anything. I need to leave, I said. Please don't follow me. I could hear her crying behind me as I abandoned my cart and headed for the door. But I knew there was no way I had a child. Because like I Said I'd never been pregnant. The next morning, I went to work, trying to ignore what happened yesterday. But Emily was waiting outside my office building. My coworker Brian was with me, and he stopped mid sentence when he saw her. Alicia, that girl looks exactly like you, he said quietly. Emily stepped forward. Because she's my mother. She gave me up for adoption 18 years ago. Brian's eyes widened. Looking between us, Alicia, you never mentioned having a kid. Because I don't. The words came out too sharp, too desperate. I've never had a baby. This is insane. Brian frowned, doing the math in his head. Wait. He looked at me strangely. Alicia, you disappeared during junior year, remember? You were gone for, like, nine months. Your mom said you were sick. I opened my mouth to explain, but nothing came. I tried to remember junior year and hit a wall of nothing. Just blank space where memories should be. I was sick, I said automatically, but I didn't know what kind of sick. Sick how? Emily demanded. Weren't you pregnant? I don't know, I admitted, and the words terrified me. I tried even harder to remember, but all I got in return was a severe headache. I need time to think, I said. Emily grabbed my arm. I'm not disappearing. I found your address online. I'll be there tonight whether you answer the door or not. True to her work, Emily knocked on my apartment door at 7 That evening, I sat on my couch, frozen, listening to her persistent knocking that went on for 10 minutes. Straight through the people. I could see her determined face so much like mine, it made my stomach turn. But no matter how hard I tried, I just couldn't remember being pregnant. I even pulled out my high school yearbook to try and find out, but I had no pictures from junior year. It was like I didn't even exist during the time when this girl said she was born eventually.

When did your grandparents sexist rules almost kill them? My grandparents were absolutely convinced that strong women were an abomination. After my parents died and they got custody, they enforced the most insane rule. I couldn't lift anything over five pounds. Not groceries, not textbooks, not even my own backpack. They genuinely believed that if a girl developed any muscle, she'd become manish and unmarriageable. At 15, I watched my female classmates a volleyball and carry their younger siblings, while I had to ask boys to carry my lunch tray. The humiliation was constant. During PE, I had to sit on the bleachers with a fake doctor's note my grandmother had somehow obtained, claiming I had delicate feminine constitution. When teachers asked why I couldn't participate in the fitness tests, my grandfather would arrive at school to lecture them about preserving young ladies fragility. Women who lift heavy things damn edge their wounds, he'd tell my horrified gym teacher. We're protecting her future children. My grandmother would nod along, adding how her own mother never lifted anything heavier than a teacup and lived to 90. The other kids started calling me Princess. Helpless behind my back, I'd stand there watching everyone load equipment after class, while I wasn't allowed to even stack chairs. When a male classmate jokingly flexed near me, my grandmother reported him to the principal for encouraging masculine behavior in young ladies. Then our neighbor, Mister Reid, a retired physical therapist, noticed me struggling to open our Front door. One day he'd watched me fail to carry grocery bags from the car while my elderly grandparents struggled with them. Instead, during one of their church mornings, he knocked on my window. This is dangerous, he said quietly. In emergencies you need basic strength. He started showing me exercises I could do silently in my room. Push UPS against my bed frame. Squats while they slept, lifting paint cans in the garage during their three hour Sunday services. I do planks while they nap, building core strength. They couldn't see under my loose dresses. Mister Reed left resistance bands hidden in our shed, teaching me routines through the fence. For months I trained in secret, terrified they discover the slight firmness developing in my arms. Then one November night changed everything. I woke to the smoke alarm shrieking at 2:00am. Black smoke was already seeping under my bedroom door. I ran to my grandparents room, finding them coughing and disoriented. The hallway was an orange nightmare of flames eating through our old wooden walls. My grandfather tried to get up, but the ceiling beam above their bed suddenly crashed down, pinning him across his chest. Screamed in pain, trapped completely, my grandmother pulled uselessly at the massive beam, her fragile arms shaking. Get help! She cried. But the flames had already blocked the stairs. The smoke was getting thicker, making us all choke. My grandfather's face was turning purple, the beam crushing his ribs. My grandmother kept pulling Sobbing, accomplishing nothing with her deliberately weakened body. Everything they taught me, every lecture about feminine weakness, every rule about 5 pound limits, disappeared. I grabbed the beam, planting my feet exactly how Mister Reid had taught me for deadlifts. My grandmother screamed at me to stop, that I'd hurt myself, that ladies don't do this. But I pulled with every bit of hidden strength I'd built in those secret morning workouts. The beam lifted just enough.

Must be nice having all that free time. Another cousin chimed in about how their lives really started after having kids. Then someone asked, have you considered adoption? It's harder when you're older. It was a coordinated ambush, delivered with fake sweetness. Even my parents joined in, with mom mentioning I was wasting my best years and dad wanting more grandkids. My accomplishments never mattered here. The only currency they valued was diapers and Christmas photos. Then the topic shifted to my sister Amelia, the former golden child who got pregnant at 21, dropped out, and disappeared into addiction. Years ago, my aunt mentioned casually, Amelia's son Jamie is in foster care now. She said it like discussing the weather. Detached, zero emotion. I froze. Jamie? I'd never met him, but knew he was about 10. What do you mean, foster care? I asked. She shrugged. You know how Amelia is, kid. But what can you do? I looked around, waiting for someone to say something, but they all went back to their conversations like Jamie didn't exist. My parents waved me off dismissively. You wouldn't understand. It's not that simple. That night, I couldn't stop thinking about Jamie. A ten year old abandoned by his mother and dismissed by the very people lecturing me about family values. I started digging online. Jamie had been bouncing between foster homes for years. How could they pretend he didn't exist while judging me? The next morning

My parents forced me to donate my liver to my abusive sister. Then a DNA test shattered everything. I was never really part of the family that raised me. My mom tore up my medical records in the hospital lobby, screaming that I was letting my sister die. My father stood beside her and called me a selfish mistake. They tried to force me to donate half my liver to the same sister who used to laugh when I cried, who told our school I was adopted before I even knew it was true. But what still wakes me at night are the doctor's words. You are not biologically related at all. Seven words that made my mother collapse when she finally couldn't lie anymore. I stayed in that hospital chair, frozen and humiliated, as shreds of my medical file fluttered around my feet like discarded receipts. You think you get to sit there and act like a victim, mom snapped, her voice echoing through the lobby. Your sister is dying, and you're doing nothing. Strangers watched. A nurse organizing files, a woman holding her toddler tighter, a security guard nearby. No one defended me. I gathered the torn papers with shaking hands, not from guilt. I needed proof. Something they couldn't twist into another lie. I didn't raise you to be this ungrateful, mom whispered, stepping closer. We gave you everything. I looked up into her eyes. You gave me what you thought I owed you for. She blinked. Hard for a moment. Real quiet. Then came the scream. You're letting your sister die. It echoed through the lobby like a headline. From behind the glass wall, Vera caught my eyes and smiled. Not gratitude. Ownership. That satisfied look that said I was still orbiting around her needs. My father appeared, his shadow falling across the tiles. You're just a selfish mistake, he said. Like a fact he believed for years and finally stopped hiding. I walked to the water fountain, memories flooding back. Vera getting the plain window seat while I got the middle. Her brand new car for her 16th birthday. My clearance sweater. The college acceptance letter she accidentally spilled coffee on before I could read it. Be grateful, they always said, after every slight. We didn't have to take you in. I pulled out my phone and found the email from six months ago. National donor match results. I tested myself when I first heard Vera was sick, hoping if I wasn't a match it would end there. I never told them the results. Days later, Doctor Holstrom called me back. Your mother marked that you hadn't been tested, but our records show you were tested six months ago. The results were emailed to her showing you were not a match. She knew she had the answer and still dragged me here. I want printed copies, I said, my voice steadier than expected. He handed me a vanilla.

This kid was carrying literally every textbook he owned. I'm talking a tower of books up to his chin. Backpack so full it wouldn't zip. Even had notebooks tucked under his armpits. My first thought was, what a nerd. Probably doing extra credit for every class over the weekend. I was pumped to go to a huge party that night. But as I watched him closer, I saw a group of guys walking past him. Then all three of these guys from the football team decided they were gonna mess with him. Came up behind James like it was planned. First guy stuck his foot out, second guy shoved him in the back hard, and James hit the concrete badly. Books exploded everywhere. All of his papers blew away, and he was covered in MUD. But as his glasses flew off, the third guy stepped on them. Not even by accident, just crush them while laughing. Looks like someone's got to study how to walk, they said, kicking his chemistry book into the street. James was on his hands and knees, trying to gather everything, not saying anything, not even looking up. His face was completely blank, like he'd gone somewhere else in his head. The guys were filming it, already posting to their stories. Caption probably Something stupid about nerd down. Other kids walking by just kept going, some laughing, most just glad it wasn't them. That's when I noticed something weird. Mixed in with all the textbooks were other things. A framed photo of what looked like his family, some medals from middle school, even what looked like birthday cards. Why would anyone bring birthday cards to school? But I didn't think about it too hard. Just felt my stomach twist watching him try to pick up wet notebook paper with his hands shaking. I don't know why I walked over. Maybe because the guys who tripped him were dicks. Who in 10th grade? Maybe because James looks so pathetic crawling around. Or maybe because my mom would have killed me if she saw me walk past. I started helping James pick up his stuff. I felt horrible because as I tried to hand him his glasses, he flinched, thinking I was gonna hurt him. He was so confused when he saw I was actually trying to help. Thanks, he mumbled, trying to carry everything at once, books sliding out of his grip again. Don't worry about them. Why are you bringing all your books home anyways? I asked, having half the pile. He just shrugged and said he liked to study. We walked together, and it turned out he lived like three streets from me, which was insane because I'd never seen him around. The whole time he kept trying to take the books. Back like he was embarrassed I was helping. When we got to his house, I don't know what possessed me, but I said, there's a party tonight. You should come. The look on his face was like I'd asked him to fly to the moon. I don't really do parties, he said, yeah, well, maybe you should start. I replied, writing the address on his hand before he could say no. I figured James wouldn't show, but around 10 that night, there he was at Jake's door, wearing the same clothes from earlier, holding a two liter of Coke like it was a ticket to get in. People looked confused. Someone asked if he was lost, but I brought him inside and acted like it was normal. Turned out James was actually funny when he wasn't terrified. That Monday, I saw him come back to school with all his books, and we started hanging out. And by senior year, James had completely transformed. Got contacts, started dressing better, actually talked to people. He got into MIT, early admission, and eventually he was so popular he had to give a speech.
NA

My girlfriend said no girl would date a gamer, so the gaming community made her single. Annabelle stood in my doorway while I was practicing my build orders for Starcraft and pulled the plug from my computer. This. She waved at my setup. All of this. You need to quit gaming. I laughed, thinking she was joking. She wasn't. Adult men don't play video games, Jay. And you have a girlfriend now. You should be taking me out to dinners and spending money on traveling instead. I disagreed, but I couldn't argue either. I was crazy about her. She was beautiful, funny, and up until this moment, I thought she was perfect. I pulled her into my lap and smiled. I have a tournament coming up that I've been training for. After that, I'm all yours. I leaned in to give a kiss, but she. She dodged it, rolling her eyes. I don't care if it's a million dollars. It's pathetic, she said in a cold voice. If you loved me, you'd stop playing. I stared at her, dumbfounded. You're not serious, I said. Delete everything or I'm done. You have 24 hours, and trust me, you don't wanna choose. Wrong. She threatened and walked out. I'll compromise, I told her over dinner at the expensive sushi place she loved. 10 to midnight, only two hours after the tournament. In three weeks, we can talk about me quitting completely. Like she stabbed at her salmon roll. Two hours every night. Is 14 hours a week. You're ignoring me. Babe, I said gently. You're literally just scrolling on your phone during that time. Look, I'll take you anywhere you want. More dinners like this, weekend trips, whatever you want. Just give me two hours to practice. Her eyes lit up at my offer. Fine. But I'm keeping track. And if you play one minute past midnight, we're done for about a week.
