As I walked toward the door with my copy of the will, dad grabbed my arm. This isn't over. I'll sue you for everything. I smiled and pulled out another document. Actually, it is over. This is Grandpa's final letter to you. Want me to read it out loud? His grip loosened. I shook free and headed for the exit. You're dead to me! He screamed. I turned back one last time. Funny, that's exactly what Grandpa said about you. The last thing I heard was Linda sobbing about their reputation as the door closed behind me.

On Christmas, my sister gave me a paternity test. So you remember, you're not part of this family. While dad laughed hysterically. I'm 29. Always been the odd one out in the Peterson family. Different hair, different build, different everything. They joke about the mailman constantly. So when Sarah handed me that DNA kit with a smirk, saying, time to prove what we all know, I wasn't even surprised. Dad was cracking up, mom nodding like she'd been waiting years for this moment. Fine, I said, but let's make it interesting. How about we all take DNA tests? You know, for science. The room went quiet. Sarah laughed nervously. Why would we need to? Because I already took one six months ago, I said, pulling out my phone. And according to 23 and me, I have a half sister named Jessica. She's been looking for her biological family. I showed them Jessica's profile. Same last name as Mom's Maiden name. Same distinctive birthmark mom has on her wrist. Jessica was born nine months after Mom's business trip to Chicago in 1995. Remember that trip, mom? The one where you couldn't be reached for three days? Mom's face went white. Dad stopped laughing immediately. Oh, it gets better. I continued scrolling through my phone. Jessica wasn't the only surprise. I have three half siblings from Mom's various work conferences. I showed them photos. This is Michael from Denver, born in 1998. Ring any bells about that marketing seminar you Attended alone. Sarah grabbed the phone. That's not possible. And here's little Emma from Portland. Born in 2,001. Funny how she has the same rare eye condition as Mom. Dad's face was turning red, but not from laughter anymore. Linda, what the hell is this? The best part. I pulled out a thick envelope from my jacket. I've been in contact with all three of them for months. They all want to meet their biological mother. In fact, they're driving here right now. Mom stood up shakily. You didn't. I did. Jessica should be here in about an hour. Michael's flying in from Denver tonight. Emma's parents are bringing her tomorrow morning for Christmas brunch. I looked at Sarah, who was still holding the DNA kit. So tell me again about not being part of this family. Because it looks like you're about to have a lot more family than you bargained for. Dad was staring at mom like he'd never seen her before. 26 years, Linda. 26 years of marriage, and you've been lying about three children. Actually, I said checking my messages.

Teachers, what's the saddest thing you found out about a student? I taught 5th grade for a few years and had to stay up really late one night to grade some essays. I was exhausted, but I remember reading one of them and couldn't believe what I saw. I told my class to write about a funny story, and this girl, Kelly, wrote about how her mom had almost killed her. She said her mom woke her and her brothers up one morning yelling at them because someone ate a candy from her room. All of them denied it, so they had to stand in a corner until one of them admitted they had eaten it. After an hour, nobody said anything. So their mom stepped it up. She was determined to find who did it, so she made all of them drink an entire cup of salt water until they vomited. She said her throat hurt so much she started crying. I couldn't believe I was reading this and thought she had to have been making get up. I knew her mom and she seemed so nice. She said whoever ate it would have to sleep outside that night. And when she was about to get another glass of salt water, her brother stepped up. He said he took it and her mom was furious. She was literally moving his bed outside. But as she did, their dad came home, had no idea what was going on. When he Found out it was because of the candy. He told them he was the one who ate it. This was supposed to be her funny story. This girl was 9 and there was no way she was making this up. I couldn't just go to bed. So I called and woke our student advisor up and read her essay word for word over the phone. She, too, didn't believe it was real. So we asked her about it the next day at school. Apparently she just thought it was a funny story and didn't think her mom was being too mean. We had to report, but as soon as someone went out to talk to her parents, she took her daughter out of the school. I hope she's doing okay. Update, I just saw her on the news. She was arrested and put in jail last.

At dinner, dad asked if my allowance was enough. When I said, what allowance? His face went white. The fork froze halfway to his mouth. Mom stopped chewing her pot roast and stared at me like I just announced I was dropping out of college to join the circus. What do you mean, what allowance? Dad's voice came out strangled. I looked between them, confused. I've never gotten an allowance, ever. I've been working at the grocery store since I was 14 to buy my own clothes and pay for gas. Mom set down her fork. Honey, your father has been giving you $200 every month since you were 12. My stomach dropped. No, he hasn't. Dad's face had gone from white to green. He pushed back from the table and walked to his office without a word. We could hear him frantically opening and closing doors, papers rustling. Lila, Mom said carefully, your dad set up automatic transfers from his account. He showed me the bank statements. I pulled out my phone and opened my banking app, turning the screen toward her. Mom, look, I've got 11 hundred dollars total. That's from working 20 hours a week for the past four months. She studied my account balance, her frown deepening. That's impossible. He's been transferring money for six years. Dad returned clutching a folder. His hands were shaking as he spread bank statements across the dinner table, knocking over the salt shaker. Look, he said, pointing at line after Line of transactions, 200 dollar transfer to Lila Morrison every month for six years. I leaned forward. Dad, that's not my account number. The silence stretched until I could hear the kitchen clock ticking. Mom grabbed the statement, comparing it to my phone screen. Richard, she whispered. This account number, it's different. Dad sank into his chair like someone had pulled his plug. That's impossible. I set this up.

Wish I could help. I say genuinely meaning it. I liked the Hollowgate team. By 10:45, Marcus, our CEO, is calling me personally. Randy, there's been a misunderstanding. Can you come in? No misunderstanding. I was terminated yesterday effective immediately. Look, maybe Jessica was hasty. We can work this out. Sorry, Marcus, but I can't legally represent the company anymore. I'm not an employee. As a consultant, then name your rate. I'm not available. Which was true. I had a phone interview with Drift Shade limited at two PM, Hollowgate's biggest peditioner. According to Beth's increasingly frantic texts, the hollowgate team gave Jessica exactly 23 minutes to produce the technical documentation they'd specifically flown into review. When she couldn't deliver, they politely excuse themselves and said they'd reassess their partnership options. At noon, Jessica calls me directly, voice shaking. Randy, you have to help me. This is sabotage. This is consequences. Jeff, Jessica, I can report you for withholding company information. What information? I took my personal belongings when you terminated me. All official files remain on your servers. Those notebooks contain proprietary data. Those notebooks contain my personal work. Notebooks purchased with my own money. Check my employment contract. She hung up. Two hours later, my wife forwards me a screenshot from LinkedIn. Jessica had posted about exciting restructuring opportunities, trying to spin the disaster as strategic plan. The comments were brutal. Three former clients asking where I'd gone, two competitors offering condolences. Even our supplier in Germany asking If we were still operational by four PM after a promising interview with Drift Shade, I had my answer to Jessica's sabotage accusation. I hadn't sabotaged anything. I simply taking my knowledge with me when they showed me the door. Monday morning, I accepted Drift Shades offer, senior director of Client Relations, 35% salary increase, equity options and a signing bonus. Wednesday, Beth texted me, Holgate canceled their contract. They're switching to Drift Shade. Also, Jessica got fired. discovered she'd been inflating her performance metrics for months. Thursday, my new phone at Drift Shade rang. Randy, this is Tom Chen from Hollowgate. We heard you joined the team. When can we schedule that technical review? Sometimes the best revenge is simply stepping out of the way and letting people destroy themselves.

The messages got more demanding each day. She deserves this opportunity. Grandpa would have wanted this. You owe the family. It was like he thought my property was some kind of family commune. He could just read, distribute. After a week of constant harassment, I'd had enough. I called my friend Samuel, who's a local police officer, and asked him how to get a trespass order. Thirty minutes later, I walked out of the state with legal paperwork in hand. Then I asked another close friend, Peter, to take a road trip with me. I need backup for a family reunion, I told him. He didn't ask questions, just grabbed his keys. It took us 10 hours to drive to Dad's house. I needed that time to clear my head and plan exactly what I was going to say. Peter kept offering to drive, but I needed something to do with my hands while I processed everything. We pulled up to Dad's modest two bedroom house around seven PM. Before we even got out of the car, we could hear a woman screaming inside. Not screaming in fear. Screaming at someone. Pure rage. That's probably your sister, Peter said. Sounds like she's having a great day. My friend pulled out his phone. Start recording, he said. Trust me on this one. I'm glad he thought of it, because what happened next was unbelievable. I walked up to the front door and knocked. The screaming immediately stopped, but steps, then the Door opened. Dad's face went from confusion to shock to pure terror in about two seconds. He looked exactly the same as I remembered. Greying hair, beard, gut. That defeated look in his eyes. Except now he looked scared. Here's your family reunion, I said, holding up the trespass order. You abandoned me once. Now I'm returning the favor. Behind him, my half sister appeared in the doorway. She looked rough. Unwashed hair, wrinkled clothes. The desperate look of someone who's been fighting losing battles for too long. When she saw me, her face went confused. Wait, your. She started to say. Yeah, I'm the brother you've never bothered to call, I interrupted. The one who's supposed to hand over his life's work because daddy says so. Dad tried to scam her. Something I wasn't done. Oh, and Dad. Grandpa left me everything because he knew who really cared about family. You know what he told me about you before he died? That abandoning me was the best thing you ever did for me. The look on Dad's face was worth the 10 hour drive. My half sister started crying. Dad's new wife appeared behind them, looking mortified. I handed him the trespass order. If any of you contact me again, call my lawyer. His numbers on the back. Peter and I walked back to the car. As we drove away, I can see them all standing in the doorway, watching us disappear.
NA

How did your twin betray you? My twin Jamie and I were identical. Like, completely identical. Our own mom couldn't tell us apart. Sometimes teachers would call me Jamie and her Jenna all through elementary school. We thought it was hilarious. When we were little, we'd switch classes for fun or confuse our babysitter. It was just innocent twin stuff. But Jamie started using our identical looks differently. In middle school, she'd asked me to take her math test because I was better with numbers. Just once, she said. Then it became every test. I felt bad saying no because she was my twin. We were supposed to help each other, right? In high school, it got worse. Jamie would sneak out to parties while I stayed home studying. She'd come back smelling like beer and cigarettes and beg me to cover for her if mom asked. I always did. When teachers saw Jamie acting weird the next day, they were actually seeing me tired from staying up worried about her. See, senior year was when I decided to apply to college. I'd wanted to go to state university since I was 12. They had the best education program in our state. I spent months writing essays. Rewrote them like, 10 times. My GPA was perfect. I took the SAT twice to get a better score. I was obsessed with getting in. The acceptance letter was supposed to come in March. I checked the mailbox every single day after school. When March ended and nothing came, I started panicking. Maybe they were running late. Maybe it got lost Brooke and went nothing. Then in may, I found a rejection letter in my room. It was addressed to me, but I never remembered getting it from the mailbox. I was devastated. I cried for three days straight. How could I not get in? My grades were perfect. My essays were good. I thought I had everything they wanted. My mom felt so bad. She took me out for ice cream. She kept saying, maybe community college for a year, then transfer. But I felt like such a failure. All my friends were going to their dream schools, and I couldn't even get into state university. Jamie was being really nice to me during this time. She brought me tissues and chocolate and told me the admissions people were idiots. She said I was way too smart for that school anyway. I thought she was just being a good sister. Summer came, and I enrolled in community college.

Oh my god, why is the universe on straight demon time this week? So it turns out that three governments collapsed in the past few days, Nepal voted for their new prime minister from fucking discord of all things, and a doctor left mid surgery just to have fun time with a nurse. In this week's events, we have France's government basically falling apart after months of protests, a weak economy, and rioting over their new prime minister so hard the whole government's hanging on by a thread. Over in Asia, things are also falling apart. Indonesia just split their coalition like a K pop group. Half the cabinet gone and nobody knows who's running anything. And then Nepal. Oh yeah, they didn't just collapse, they basically rage quit real life and respond their new prime minister from a discord server. A discord server? Bro's probably still muted in VC passing laws while getting called trash by a 13 year old. 3 governments gone in only a few days and the rest of the world is trying really hard not to freak out about it. And as if the world wasn't already cooked, a doctor literally walked out mid surgery to go hook up with a nurse. M. I. D. Surgery. Like this scene is straight out of fifty shades of grey. My guy really put the operation in operation. At this point we'll have another World War by tomorrow.

I'm going to die soon, and my daughter has no idea. A month ago, everything in my life was normal. I dropped my daughter off at daycare one morning, and right after went to my routine doctor's checkup. Halfway through, he starts asking me strange questions about if I had been getting headaches or if I was seeing correctly. This was the first time I realized I did have trouble seeing, and he asked if I could get an emergency scan later that day. I thought nothing of it, and I thought I was perfectly healthy. Three hours later, I find out I have brain cancer. He told me all at once that if I'm lucky, I'll live for a few more months. Still doesn't feel real. I'm supposed to get married soon and still haven't been able to tell everyone. I won't make it until then. My daughter has no idea I only have a few weeks to live. I overheard her ask her mom why she's crying in the bathroom. Because she didn't want me to hear her. I'm not gonna make it for her first day of kindergarten. And wonder if she'll remember the way I make her pancakes and read her stories. Every day, I try my best not to cry in front of her while we do fun things. But this morning, I couldn't do it. She ran up to me with a huge smile and asked if we could dress up as the Incredibles. This Halloween, she said I could be Mister Incredible since I'm strong and keep her safe. I broke down right there. I so badly don't want to leave my little girl behind.

Police officer, what is the kindest thing a suspect ever said to you? I've been working late shifts for two years when I got the call about a kid shoplifting. Friday night, 11:30. Another routine run to the grocery store on Fifth Street. The manager was standing outside when I pulled up, shaking his head and pointing toward a scared looking boy sitting on the curb. Caught him trying to walk out with formula and diapers. Manager said, but here's the weird part. No baby with him. Just stuffed everything under his jacket and tried to bolt when I called out. The kid looked maybe 14, all elbows and knees, wearing a torn jacket that was way too big for him. His eyes were red like he'd been crying, but he was trying to act tough. I walked over and sat down next to him on the curb. What's your name, son? He just stared at his shoes, wouldn't say a word. I helped him into the back of my cruiser. No handcuffs. Just trying to get him somewhere warm where we could talk. For 10 minutes he sat there silent, arms crossed, jaw set, like he was ready for a fight. Look, I'm not trying to jam you up here, I told him, but I need to understand what's going on. You steal baby stuff, but no baby? Help me make sense of it. That's when he finally broke. Tears just started pouring down his face and the whole story Came tumbling out. His 17 year old sister had a baby two weeks ago. Their mom walked out six months before, and their dad was doing time upstate for armed robbery. No adults, no money, no help from anybody. The baby had been crying non stop because they ran out of formula three days ago. My sister's too scared to leave the apartment, he said, wiping his nose on his sleeve. She thinks people will see how young she is and take the baby away. So I figured I'd just, I don't know, take what we needed. I asked him why he hadn't called social services or asked for help somewhere else. He looked at me like I was crazy. Because people don't help kids like us, he said quietly. They call CPS and split us up. Then the baby goes to strangers and we never see each other again. Something about the way he said it hit me hard. This wasn't some delinquent causing trouble. This was a scared kid trying to keep his family together the only way he knew how. I didn't say much on the drive to his apartment. Just told him we'd figure something out. The place was worse than I expected. Third floor, walk up, half the windows cracked, barely working. Inside was this tiny studio apartment with almost no furniture. The sister was maybe 90 pounds, soaking wet, holding a baby that was sleeping in a dresser drawer because they didn't have a Crib. She looked terrified when she saw my uniform. Started stammering about how they weren't doing anything wrong, how she was a good mom, even though she was just 17. The baby was tiny, but looked healthy. Just thin, like his mom. I told them I'd be back in 30 minutes and left.

Did my friends wedding photos in front of them. My best friend Jess was getting married and asked me to be her photographer. I've been doing photography for like three years now, mostly just for fun and some side cash, but nothing super professional. She said she trusted me more than some random person and honestly couldn't afford a real wedding photographer. Anyway, the wedding was beautiful. I spent the entire day running around getting shots of everything, her getting ready, walking down the aisle, the first kiss, all the family photos. I was exhausted but felt good about it. I probably took like 800 photos that day. After the reception just pulled me aside and said she couldn't wait to see them. He was literally glowing with excitement. I told her I'd edit them and have them ready in a week. That's when things got weird. Two days later, Jess texted me asking if I could rush the photos because her and her husband Jake wanted to post them on social media. I said, sure, no problem. But then she started texting me every single day asking for updates like multiple times a day. Then she called me crying saying her mom was asking about the photos and could I please just send her like 5 unedited ones. I sent her a few thinking that would calm her down. Wrong. The next day she showed up at my apartment unannounced. She had Jake with her and they both looked Stressed. She said they needed to talk about the photos. Apparently, just's mom had been showing the unedited photos I sent to family members and now everyone was asking why the photographer didn't know how to use proper lighting. Just said she was embarrassed and needed me to fix them immediately. I explained that editing takes time and I was working on them. But she cut me off and said she'd found another photographer who could fix my mistakes for $500. He wanted me to send her all the raw files so this other person could edit them instead. I was honestly hurt. These weren't even bad photos. The lighting was a little dim in a few shots because the venue was dark, but nothing that couldn't be fixed in editing. That's literally what editing is for. But here's where it gets really messed up. When I hesitated about sending the raw files, Jake stepped in and said they weren't paying me anything anyway, so I should just hand them over. He said they'd already been more than generous letting me practice on their wedding. Practice. I had busted my ass for 12 hours straight on their wedding day. I barely ate, missed most of the reception, and my feet were killing me from running around in heels all day. That's when Jess said something that made my blood boil. She looked me dead in the eye and said, if I was a.

What is the pettiest reason you've rejected someone? Whenever I met someone new through dating apps or friends, I take them to this little Italian place called Nana's on our first date. Not because the food was amazing, though it was pretty good, but because their service was intentionally slow. I'm talking like you'd wait 20 minutes just to get water. The kitchen was always backed up because they only had two cooks for the whole restaurant. Most people who went there regularly knew this and just enjoyed the atmosphere. But I used it as my own personal dating filter. My coworker Jess set me up with this guy, Daniel she knew from her gym. He seemed decent enough over text, had a good job, liked dogs, the usual green flags. We agreed to meet at Nana's on a Thursday night. I got there first and warned the hostess Maria that I was doing my usual test. She laughed and said she'd make sure our table got the full experience. I been coming there for two years so the staff knew my deal by now. Daniel showed up right on time wearing a nice button down and jeans. Good start. We sat down and Maria handed us menus, then disappeared for exactly 15 minutes before coming back for our drink order. That's when I noticed Daniel's first reaction. He kept checking his phone and looking around like he was trying to flag down a waiter. When Maria finally came back, He ordered a beer with this tight smile that didn't reach his eyes. Our drinks took another 20 minutes. I watched Daniel's jaw clench as he started tapping his fork against the table. When Maria brought the bread basket, he muttered under his breath, finally, Jesus. I pretended not to hear it and asked him about his work. He answered, but I could tell he was distracted. Every few minutes, he'd glance toward the kitchen or check the time on his phone. By the time our entrees came out, we'd been there for over an hour. Daniel's chicken Parmesan looked amazing, but his face was pure frustration. I apologized and said the service was usually faster, which was a complete lie. He waved me off and said, yeah, well, some people just don't know how to run a business properly. Then he took a huge bite and chewed aggressively. That's when Maria walked by our table and Daniel raised his voice loud enough for half the restaurant to hear. Hey, think we'll get dessert before midnight, or should I just order it for tomorrow? I felt my stomach drop. Maria's face went red, but she just nodded and hurried away. I knew she had absolutely no control over how fast the kitchen worked. I was just trying to do her job. But Daniel wasn't done. When she brought our check, he pulled out a calculator app on his phone and started doing math out loud. Eighteen percent of 43 dollars Nah, that's way too much for this kind of service. He left exactly two dollars on a 43 dollar Bill. Two dollars. I stared at the money on the table. That's only like 4%, he shrugged. I'm not here to fund incompetence. Maybe next time they'll get their act together. I pulled out a 20 and put it next to his $2. The waitress doesn't control how fast the kitchen works, Daniel laughed. That's their problem to figure out. I paid for a service and the service sucked. We walked to our cars in complete silence. He tried to.

Ever heard my girlfriend say he's going to propose tonight, watch me say no and make him cry? I still took her to the rooftop, got down on one knee, then pulled out her texts with her gym buddy and said loudly, actually, I'm not proposing. I'm here to say goodbye. In front of everyone you tried to impress? This happened three weeks ago, and I'm still processing it. My girlfriend Danielle and I had been together for three years. She been dropping engagement hints constantly, showing me rings, talking about weddings. I've been secretly saving for months. Even picked out a ring. The plan was to propose at her company's rooftop holiday party. She kept mentioning how romantic it would be with the city lights and all her co workers there. But last Tuesday changed everything. I came home early from my hospital shift. I heard Danielle on Facetime upstairs, laughing. Melissa, he's definitely doing it at the party tomorrow. He's been acting all secretive. I stopped on the stair. That's exciting. Are you ready? Her sister asked. Here's the thing. I'm saying no right in front of everyone. My blood went cold. Danielle. What? Why? He needs a reality check. Plus, you know Anthony from Crossfit? He just started his own business. Way more ambitious than a nurse. Anthony? The guy she'd been training with three nights a week? You're really going to humiliate him at your work party? Picture this. All my co workers watching. He gets Down on one knee. And I just say, sorry, but no. Maybe he'll understand. He can't coast through life helping sick people all day. They both giggled. I quietly went to my car and sat there for an hour. That night, Danielle was all over me. Babe, I love you so much. All I could think about was her planning my destruct. Wednesday morning, her phone buzzed with a text from Anthony. Can't wait to celebrate tomorrow. She'd left it unlocked. I scrolled through their messages. So tomorrow's the big day, Anthony had written. Yep. Poor guy has no idea what's coming. You sure you wanna do this at work? Seems harsh. He needs this wake up call. Besides, I'll need someone to comfort me after. Always here for you. Can't wait to see his face. Weeks of messages like this. I took screenshots. That afternoon, Danielle called me, bouncing with excitement. Tom, I can't wait for tonight. Everyone's going to be there. My boss, the whole team. It's going to be perfect. Perfect for my public destruction. Can't wait, I said. The party was on the 40th floor with incredible downtown views. Danielle Network introducing me as my boyfriend, Tom. He's a nurse. Like she was embarrassed. Anthony showed up around eight PM. Big guy, Crossfit shirt, giving me this smug look. Around 9:30, Danielle got antsy checking her phone constantly. The view is incredible. So romantic with the. These lights. It really is beautiful. Perfect setting for something. Special to happen. You're absolutely right. Could you get everyone's attention? I have something to say. Her eyes lit up. She called out everyone. Tom has something to share. The room quieted. Her boss smiled. Anthony pulled out his phone. Probably to record my humiliation. I got down.

Someone's petty rules completely backfire. My boss, Joseph, wasn't bluffing about the no workplace dating policy. Anyone caught dating got fired immediately. That couple from the business department fired. Mr and Mrs. Wolowitz divorced. Even my friend Sasha got transferred to another branch for carpooling with another guy to work. If anyone was caught even just talking for more than 5 minutes, they'd get called to his office to get lectured. So things were pretty rough in the office. A few people did try to reason with him, but he refused to budge. Workplace romances hurt productivity, he'd say. But everyone knew he was just bitter about the messy divorce with his secretary wife. So now we were all suffering. I'd always been careful about that rule until I met Lance from it. That day, I was completely panicking. I'd worked all night for an important project only for my laptop to freeze. One hour before the meeting, Lance came over from the fourth floor and helped me recover for my files while making terrible puns to calm me down. Hey, why was the computer cold? It left its windows open. God, it was bad. But I laughed anyway. When he finally saved everything, I almost hugged him. Then we both froze, right? The rule. Before I left for the meeting, he wrote his number on a sticky note and handed it to me shyly. Here in case you run into more computer problems. I felt my cheeks flush. I Stared at that sticky note for three days before texting him, we met up at a tiny coffee shop two blocks from the office during lunch time. We sat in the back corner covering ourselves like criminals. Every time the door opened, we both look up panicked. I watched him duck into the table when someone from his department walked in to pick up coffee. I laughed. Wow, crazy first date, huh? He grinned back at me from underneath the table. I love crazy. We were still pretty paranoid on the next few dates, but after three months, we started to get comfortable, maybe a little too comfortable. That's when it happened, a close call when we were out at an Italian restaurant to celebrate my promotion. Lance suddenly went ghost white. We need to leave now. But it was too late. Our boss, Joseph, entered the restaurant and locked eyes with us. He marched over, practically foaming at the mouth. Mind telling me what's going on. Lance and Beatrice from marketing. Lance stood up slowly. Dad, I can explain. Dad, I choked. Joseph glanced at our table full of candles and rose petals, clearly not for a casual meeting. You're dating my son in my company, breaking my rules. The entire restaurant got quiet, watching months of secret dating all go down the drain. You're fired. You can forget about the Japanese presentation tomorrow. I won't have liars and rule breakers in my company. I got up and managed To squeeze out a, have a good evening before running out next morning. I came in early to pack my desk before everyone arrived, but Lance was already there waiting.

Your parents say to you as a kid that still affects you today. My mom had me when she was just 13. She was a child herself, but she tried her best. I still remember the day my second grade teacher made us draw our families. Other kids drew stick figures of dads and siblings. I just drew mom. When I got home, Mrs. Peters had written incomplete assignment in red pen across the top. Mom looked at my drawing, then at the red Mark, without a word, she took a marker and drew a giant circle around me and her. This, he said, is a complete family. By middle school, I was a straight a student. Mom would tape my report cards to our fridge like trophies. She'd come home from double shifts at the diner, her uniform stained with grease and still help me with homework. Education is your ticket out, she'd say. Then Cassie Mitchell happened. She cornered me by the lockers surrounded by her friends. Hey, charity case. Is it true your mom was a pregnant middle schooler, but you don't even know who your dad is? They were right. I didn't. The whispers followed me everywhere. Trailer trash, they'd say just loud enough for me to hear. Your mom's a SLT. I started skipping school. When my straight A's turned to F's, school called. Mom took a rare day off from the diner. I expected her to be furious. We couldn't afford lost wages, but When she got home, she just sat beside me on our porch steps, still in her waitress uniform. What's happening, baby? She asked, her voice tired but gentle. I stared at the concrete. Those kids at school, I finally whispered, they say I'm nothing but a mistake, that I ruined your life. Mom was quiet for so long, I thought she might have fallen asleep. Then she grabbed my shoulders, her eyes suddenly fierce. Listen to me, she said, her voice shaking. Everyone in this town expected me to fail to give you up. My own parents threw me out, but you're the best decision I ever made. She wiped her eyes. So tomorrow we're going to show them exactly what we're made of. The next morning, mom, transform.
NA

What made the girls girl turn her back on every girl who needed her? We all knew Howell would let the world burn if it meant keeping girls safe. She literally treated female friendship like a sacred religion. She'd walk wasted girls home from parties, share her last tampon with girls she'd never met and somehow knew which guys to avoid before anyone else did. Every girl had her number saved for emergencies because they could all count on her to fix things. There was this one time at lunch when the football players were ranking girls by their bodies out loud. Hallie walked right up to their table, took photos of all of them and announced she'd post them on the school's parent Facebook age with exactly what they'd been saying unless they apologized to every single girl individually. That was Hallie's whole identity. She lived for female solidarity. She'd stay up all night talking girls through break UPS, pretend to be someone's girlfriend to get creeps to back off, fight with teachers who dress coded girls unfairly. During junior year when the cheerleaders started that toxic diet competition, Hallie brought homemade cookies every day until they stopped weighing themselves. The girls would cry on her shoulder, trust her with their darkest secrets and she treat protecting them like her life's purpose. Then winter break passed and Halley showed up wearing headphones, staring at her phone, completely ignoring the circle of girls who'd been waiting to tell her their Break drama. When Nebe ran up crying about her boyfriend cheating, Halley lit literally stepped around her and kept walking. She didn't hold the door for the freshman girl carrying too many books, didn't smile back at anyone. During lunch, Amira was sobbing about her parents divorce first and Halley would have normally dropped everything to comfort her, but she sat alone the entire time. The worst part was when Sienna fainted in the hallway from not eating. Old Halley would have been the first one there. This Halley glanced over, watched the nurse handle it and went back to her homework. Girls kept approaching her all day. Summer needed a tampon. Halley shrugged and said she didn't have one. Freya asked for a ride home because she felt unsafe. Halley said call an Uber without looking. We all thought she was going through something heavy, maybe seasonal depression, maybe family problems. Some girls organized an intervention. They cornered her after school with flowers and her favorite coffee. Holly took one look at them and said, I'm not interested, just that, then walked to her car. Days turned into weeks. The girls went from concerned to desperate. They made a schedule to check on her, left notes in her locker, even got the counselor involved. Hallie told the counselor she was focusing on herself and there was nothing wrong. When that didn't work, they told one of our teachers. She asked Hallie why she wasn't helping organize the Women's Empowerment Assembly. Hallie responded, that's not my responsibility anymore. Then we all found out what happened. During a massive New Year's Eve party at Wyat's house, Hallie had gone with her closest friends, prepare to be designated driver and protect anyone. But then someone spiked her drink and she started feeling really sick and disoriented. She'd managed to lock herself in an upstairs bathroom when she realized something was serious wrong. Holly had texted the group chat with her friends, the ones she called her Soul Sisters. She typed, please help. Something's wrong. I think someone put something in my drink. I'm scared. I locked myself in Wyatt's bathroom. Please come get me now. Then another, I can't stand up properly. Please hurry. Then someone's trying to.
NA

If you want to bury a dead body, simply bury it 9 feet deep, then place a dead animal four feet above it. This way if a police dog smells something unusual, they will only find the dead animal. If you want to get rid of a crime weapon, the best way to do it is to melt it down into a block of steel, then throw it in the ocean. This way it will sink to the bottom and if someone finds it, they will never know what it originally was. If you want to trespass onto someone's property, bring a dog leash with you. If someone asks why you're there, just tell them your dog ran off and you're trying to find it. If your grandmother is racist, create a photo montage of your brother or sister in a situation that will upset her. She will remove them from her will so you will inherit a larger share. To skip class, wait for the break and hide your bag somewhere. Then when you have to go back to class, go to the teacher and explain that your school bag has disappeared and that someone probably took it as a bad joke. Now he will let you look for your things and you can even ask your best friend to accompany you in the search. So tag him in the comments.

You ever had your ankle monitor go off during sex? The judge said house arrest was a gift. Six months for a bar fight? That wasn't even my fault. My buddy threw the first punch. I just finished it. Still better than actual jail. The ankle monitor was waterproof, amperproof, and would alert my probation officer if I stepped one foot outside my apartment boundaries. Don't test it, Officer Burton warned me. I get notifications immediately. Midnight, 3:00 am. Whenever you violate, you violate your plea deal. For three months, I was a model prisoner. Work from home, groceries delivered. Friends visited me instead of the other way around. The monitor became part of me, like metallic parasite I'd Learned to ignore. Then I matched with hyper on a dating app. Her profile said she was into bad boys with good hearts, which felt targeted. I was honest about my situation, sort of told her I had a minor legal issue that me homebound temporarily. She found it intriguing. Like a mysterious hermit. She texted hot. She came over on a Thursday night with takeout and a bottle of wine she definitely shouldn't have brought. I wasn't supposed to drink either. But Officer Burton didn't have cameras in my apartment, just the monitor tracking location. Piper was everything her photos promised and more. Funny, smart, with this raspy laugh and tattoos that told stories. Talked until 2:00am about everything except why I was really stuck at home. So what did You do? She finally asked. Whine. Brave and curious. Rob a bank? Kill someone? Got in a fight defending someone's honour, I said. Which was technically true if you counted my drunk buddies honour. She kissed me. Then, right in the middle of my kitchen, with her hands in my hair and her body pressed against mine like she was

What's a small lie you told that snowballed so much you had to keep it up? When I was 24, I was basically a walking disaster. I've been rejected from Target, Walmart, even the gas station down the street. I was sleeping in my beat up Honda Civic after losing my apartment and had like $12 to my name. So when I saw this job posting for a receptionist at this fancy law firm downtown, I figured, what the hell, right? The posting said bilingual preferred. And without thinking, I just checked the Spanish box. I mean, I took two years of Spanish in high school. How hard could it be? The interview was with this older lady in a sharp suit who looked like she could buy and sell me 10 times over. Everything was going fine until she smiled and said something in Spanish. I panicked and mumbled the only thing I could remember, me. Llamo Lila em Gustala pizza. She laughed and said, good enough. Our Spanish speaking clients will love having someone who understands their culture. I thought for sure they'd figure it out on day one. But turns out all I had to do do was answer phones and look professional. Most of the Spanish speaking clients brought their own translators. Anyway, whenever someone called speaking Spanish, I put them on hold and frantically use Google Translate to figure out what they wanted. Un momento por favor became my best friend. This went on for Months. I started watching Spanish soap operas at night in my car, trying to pick up phrases. I downloaded Duolingo and did lessons during lunch breaks. I even befriended Rosa at the coffee shop and practiced ordering in Spanish until she got annoyed with me. Then everything went sideways. One of the firm's biggest clients, an old guy named Miguel, who owned half the restaurants in the city, passed away suddenly. His widow only spoke Spanish and was devastated. And somehow, because I was the bilingual guy, they assigned me to be the translator at his funeral. I begged my boss to let someone else do it. This is huge, Elijah. It shows how much we trust you, she said. There was no backing out without blowing my cover. The night before the funeral, I didn't sleep at all. I used every translation app I could find, watched YouTube videos about funeral phrases, even called my friend's mom, who was from Mexico, to practice what I might need to say. But when the actual day came, I sweating through my only good suit. The service was packed. Lawyers, business owners, family members, everyone staring at me like I was supposed to be some expert. The widow dressed in black was clutching an urn with her husband's ashes. The priest started talking and I was doing okay translating the basic stuff. Then she broke down. She walked to the front holding that urn and started sobbing these rapid emotional words in Spanish. Everyone turned to look at me. The whole room went quiet except her crying. I froze. I didn't understand half of what she was saying. She was talking about memories, about love, about forgiveness, but it was all mixed up with grief and tears. So I did the only thing I could think of. I translated what I thought she meant to say. She says, Miguel was the love of her life. I started making my voice soft and respectful. She says he taught her that love isn't perfect, but it's always worth fighting for. She forgives him for the times he worked too late and she hopes he forgives her for the times she was too proud to say she was sorry. I kept going, adding things that felt right, about how he made her laugh when she was sad, how he always saved the last piece of cake for her, how their love story wasn't ending, just changing. The whole room was crying. Even the lawyer who hired me had tears in his eyes. When I finished, the widow walked over and grabbed my hands. She whispered something in Spanish that I still didn't understand, but I could tell it was grateful and heartfelt. I just nodded and squeezed her hands back. After the service, everyone kept coming up to thank me. That was beautiful. They said. You really captured her heart. I felt like the biggest fraud in the world, but also weirdly proud that I'd Help this woman share her love story. Back at the office Monday morning, my boss called me in. Elijah, that was incredible work at the funeral. We're promoting you to full time translator with a raise. My stomach dropped. A promotion meant more responsibility.

Gamers, what's the craziest thing you've ever heard over voice chat? I was speed running Minecraft at 3:00am when someone joined my discord with no profile picture, just the username, please help me 2024. Before I could kick them for the spam looking name, I heard heavy breathing and what sounded like running through trees. This wasn't a gaming headset. It was someone on their phone actually running through wood in real life. Is anyone there? Please? I need gamers specifically. You're the only ones awake right now who might believe me. It was a girl, maybe 16 or 17, completely out of breath. My first instinct was to disconnect. This had to be some elaborate ARG or prank. But then I heard something that made my blood freeze. Dogs barking, not normal barking police dog. I escaped from a conversion therapy camp in Utah, she gasped. They told my parents I ran away 3 weeks ago, but I've been locked in solitary. I stole a counselor's phone when they came to give me food. I remembered this discord server from before. They took me my chat. Twelve viewers suddenly became 50, then 100 as people started sharing the stream. Someone typed F a K E. But then we all heard it, a man's voice shouting in the distance. She went this way. Check sector 7. They're hunting me like an animal, she whispered. These camps are legal because parents sign custody over. If they catch me, I disappear forever. Other kids have disappeared. That's when my viewer Kevin, a tech genius from Seattle spoke up. Turn on your location sharing now screenshot and send it to the chat. She did. Middle of nowhere, Utah, 40 miles from the nearest town. Kevin immediately started working magic. I'm overlaying your position with Google Earth. There's a road 800 meters northeast. Head that way. How do you know this is real? Someone challenged. The girl laughed bitterly. Google Wilderness Reformation Academy Utah. Check their reviews. Parents praising them for fixing their kids. Kids who never post anything again. After a viewer count hit 500, someone had already clipped this and it was spreading across Twitter. But we had a bigger problem. Battery at 12% she said. And I can hear the dogs getting closer. That it's when the stream chat became Mission Control. Sarah from Germany found an Uber driver forum for Utah. Marcus from Japan was Google Earth ing escape route. Tony from New York was documenting everything for evidence. And Kevin, Kevin did something insane. I'm spoofing a 9 1 1 call from the camp's main building, he announced, reporting a fire in the administration office should pull their security team back. In minutes, we heard distant sirens through her phone. The shouting changed direction. Moving away from her. The road, she gasped. I can see the road but it was empty. Middle of the night, middle of nowhere. That's when viewer Emma from Colorado typed, my sister lives in Cedar City That's 45 minutes away. She's getting in her car right now. The next 20 minutes were the longest of my life. Her phone died but not before she sent one last message. White Honda Civic, license plate starts with Q7. The stream chat stayed active all night, waiting, praying, sharing stories of their own experiences or close calls with these camps. At 7 a. M, Emma's sister joined the discord. I have her. She safe. We're at the police station. But they're saying the camp has legal custody. We need lawyers. Within an hour, the streaming community had raised $50,000 for legal fees. Three lawyers volunteered pro Bono. News stations picked up the story from the viral clips. Two weeks later, she joined discord again, this time with video on sitting next to her mom who was crying. You saved my daughter's life. That camp, we had no idea. The FBI is investigating them now. 17 other kids have come forward. The camp shut down a month later. She started streaming last week, mostly Minecraft. Her username isn't please help me anymore. It finally free 2,024. She has 200,000 followers and counting. But here's what haunts me. In her first stream, she mentioned something. There were other kids who tried to run. They didn't know to call gamers. They called their parents and.

My gross dad started dating a girl younger than me. So I started dating a guy older than him. See how he likes it? I'm 22 and my dad is 48. Last year after my parents divorced, he started dating this 20 year old girl named Becca. Yes, she's literally two years younger than me. Disgusting, right? At first I thought it was just some midlife crisis fling. But then he started bringing her to family dinners and introducing her as his girlfriend. She'd sit there giggling at everything he said while I'm sitting across from them wanting to throw up. The worst part was watching my dad act like some teenage boy around her, buying her jewelry and taking her on fancy trips while my mom was still fighting for alimony money. Who would even try to give me advice about college and my dating life. Like, girl, you literally just graduated high school two years ago. She'd be like, oh, honey, you should totally try this new face mask I saw on TikTok while I'm thinking about how she's closer to my age than my dad's. The breaking point came when my dad announced they were moving in together. He called a family meeting with me and my little brother to tell us Becca would be around more often. My 16 year old brother just stared at his phone the whole time while I sat there fuming. That's when I decided to give my dad a taste of His own medicine. I started scrolling through dating apps, specifically looking for older guys. I found this 55 year old guy named Robert who owns a construction company. He's divorced, has kids older than me, but he's actually pretty cool and treats me well. Plus he looks way better than my dad, even though he's older. I started bringing Robert to family events. The look on my dad's face when I introduced my boyfriend at my cousin's birthday party was priceless. Robert showed up in his nice truck wearing a button down shirt, shook my dad's hand firmly and started talking about his business and his two kids who are 24 and 26. My dad kept shooting me these confused looks all night. Becca kept whispering to him, asking if Robert was really my boyfriend. Robert was being super.

My wife said, stop trying to be romantic, it's pathetic. So I put a stop to our fake marriage. We've been married for five years, and I thought I was being the perfect husband. I spent three hours cooking her favorite meal for our anniversary, set up candles, even dug out that playlist from our first date. When she walked through the door with her sister and best friend, she took one look at the setup, rolled her eyes, and said, loud enough for everyone to hear, stop trying to be romantic, it's pathetic. You look desperate. Then she turned to her friends. This is exactly what I was telling you about. He does this needy stuff constantly. The room went dead silent. Her sister looked uncomfortable, her best friend stared at the floor. I stood there holding wine, watching my wife destroy our marriage with one sentence. I set the wine down, looked her straight in the eye, and said, you know what? You're absolutely right. Expected me to apologize, to scramble. Instead, I started blowing out the candles. What are you doing? She asked, losing that confident edge. Stopping, I replied. Gathering the flowers. Romance is pathetic when it's one sided, so I'm done being pathetic. I tossed the flowers in the trash and ordered pizza. We can eat like roommates from now on. Pepperoni or cheese? That night, she tried damage control, talking about bad days, overreacting. But something had shifted in me. I heard you perfectly. I told her, message received. No more romantic gestures. No more pathetic behavior. She laughed it off. Maybe we both need to be more realistic about what marriage actually is. Those words would haunt her the next morning. I didn't bring her coffee in bed like I had every weekend for five years. When she came downstairs expecting her usual cup, I was finishing mine. Coffee's in the kitchen, I said without looking up. I saw our marriage clear. Really? For the first time. I was the one planning date nights she'd complain about. I was the one remembering anniversaries. I was the one keeping romance alive. When I stopped being romantic, I stopped with everything unnecessary. No more good morning kisses. No more asking about her day. No more caring where she went. By day 10, the cracks showed. Are you going to ask me about my presentation? She said, clearly fishing. Do you want to tell me about it? Well, it went well, she said, waiting for follow up questions that never came. Good for you. I went back to my phone. She stood there for a full minute, waiting for me to engage. When it became clear I wasn't playing that role anymore, she left without another word. Three weeks in, she was losing her mind. She mentioned male co workers, talked about her ex reaching out, brought up how attentive other husbands were. Each comment was fishing for jealousy. Any sign I still cared. My response, Was always, that's interesting. Then I'd return to whatever I was doing. I'd start. Started hitting the gym, reading books, learning guitar. Something she'd always dismissed as a waste of time. One month in, she cracked. She was waiting at the kitchen table when I got home. Papers spread everywhere. We need to talk. You're punishing me because your feelings got hurt? My feelings got hurt? I repeated. You humiliated me in front of your friends. Called five years of romantic gesture.

Waiting for my daughter to finish school, a parent turned to me and asked, did your ex husband have a beard? I giggled nervously. Um, yeah, why? No, no, no, no, no, she suddenly screamed while walking as far away from me as possible. I just laughed because moms can be so weird sometimes. But the next day, my daughter came home from school crying. Mommy, Leah said her mom said she can't talk to me anymore. Leah was her best friend. I immediately took out my phone and texted her mom asking if everything was okay. No response. I texted Emily's mom, one of the other girls in her trio. Still nothing. I had just managed to calm my baby girl down when the pizza arrived. Usually our delivery guy is the Apator 5,000. But tonight he just set the box on my doorstep and practically ran away. George, you forgot your tip, I yelled, waving a 20. He just kept going. The next few days were insane. At my daughter's soccer practice, Helen saw me walking towards her and held her phone to her ear. No one had even called her. Helen, what's going on? She mouth, sorry and walked faster. We used to complain about our husbands together. Parents were whispering and showing each other something on their phones. When I walked by, they'd quickly put them away. By Thursday, my daughter was refusing to go to school. They moved my desk away from everyone else. The Teacher said it was for space reasons, but there's like 10 feet between me and Leah now. I tried to bring her to the hairdresser to cheer her up, but when the woman saw me coming, she closed early. No apology. Just flipped the sign and pulled the blinds. My phone buzzed. It was my landlord. Heard what happened. So sorry, rent can wait this month. This was the same man who charged me a 50 dollar inconvenience fee when I paid rent at 12:00am instead of midnight. Then the birthday party, Emily's sleepover. My daughter found out that everyone was invited except her. She was having such a bad panic attack that I had to call a hospital. Mom, what did I do? Emily is my best friend. Enough was enough. I called the school office. Something is happening to my daughter. She's being systematically excluded and I need answers right now. The counselor called back within an hour, but her voice was off like she was choosing every word carefully. Mrs. Callahan, we just wanted to check in about your home environment. Is everything safe? If anyone new spending time around your daughter? What? What are you even asking me? I think it's best if we discuss this in person. Can you come in tomorrow morning? No. You'll tell me right now why my daughter is being tortured. Long pause. The principal will explain everything tomorrow. Beep. She hung up. Then at eleven PM, an email from my Gym membership terminated effective immediately. I've been going there for five years. Owner knew me by name. I was trying to figure out what to do when my daughter crawled into my bed at 2:00am sobbing, Mommy, am I ugly? It took everything in me not to burst into tears. The lunch lady wouldn't look at me today. She just pointed at my tray. I finally caved. On Saturday morning, I found myself walking towards the principal's office while being escorted by a security guard. Other parents there for Saturday sports held their kids against the walls as we passed. One mom literally shielded her son with her body like we were dangerous. In his office, the principal locked the door behind us. The click was so loud in the silence, he walked to the windows and twisted the blinds shut. My daughter grabbed my hand tighter. Please sit down. I'll stand. What is this about? He sat at his desk, fingers hovering over his keyboard, then pulled them back. Mister Griffin, you're scaring me. Missus Callahan. He was looking at his screen, not at me.

Gamers, what's the craziest thing you've ever heard over voice chat? I was speed running Minecraft at 3:00am when someone joined my discord with no profile picture, just the username, please help me 2024. Before I could kick them for the spam looking name, I heard heavy breathing and what sounded like running through trees. This wasn't a gaming headset. It was someone on their phone actually running through wood in real life. Is anyone there? Please? I need gamers specifically. You're the only ones awake right now who might believe me. It was a girl, maybe 16 or 17, completely out of breath. My first instinct was to disconnect. This had to be some elaborate ARG or prank. But then I heard something that made my blood freeze. Dogs barking, not normal barking police dog. I escaped from a conversion therapy camp in Utah, she gasped. They told my parents I ran away 3 weeks ago, but I've been locked in solitary. I stole a counselor's phone when they came to give me food. I remembered this discord server from before. They took me my chat. Twelve viewers suddenly became 50, then 100 as people started sharing the stream. Someone typed F a K E. But then we all heard it, a man's voice shouting in the distance. She went this way. Check sector 7. They're hunting me like an animal, she whispered. These camps are legal because parents sign custody over. If they catch me, I disappear forever. Other kids have disappeared. That's when my viewer Kevin, a tech genius from Seattle spoke up. Turn on your location sharing now screenshot and send it to the chat. She did. Middle of nowhere, Utah, 40 miles from the nearest town. Kevin immediately started working magic. I'm overlaying your position with Google Earth. There's a road 800 meters northeast. Head that way. How do you know this is real? Someone challenged. The girl laughed bitterly. Google Wilderness Reformation Academy Utah. Check their reviews. Parents praising them for fixing their kids. Kids who never post anything again. After a viewer count hit 500, someone had already clipped this and it was spreading across Twitter. But we had a bigger problem. Battery at 12% she said. And I can hear the dogs getting closer. That it's when the stream chat became Mission Control. Sarah from Germany found an Uber driver forum for Utah. Marcus from Japan was Google Earth ing escape route. Tony from New York was documenting everything for evidence. And Kevin, Kevin did something insane. I'm spoofing a 9 1 1 call from the camp's main building, he announced, reporting a fire in the administration office should pull their security team back. In minutes, we heard distant sirens through her phone. The shouting changed direction. Moving away from her. The road, she gasped. I can see the road but it was empty. Middle of the night, middle of nowhere. That's when viewer Emma from Colorado typed, my sister lives in Cedar City That's 45 minutes away. She's getting in her car right now. The next 20 minutes were the longest of my life. Her phone died but not before she sent one last message. White Honda Civic, license plate starts with Q7. The stream chat stayed active all night, waiting, praying, sharing stories of their own experiences or close calls with these camps. At 7 a. M, Emma's sister joined the discord. I have her. She safe. We're at the police station. But they're saying the camp has legal custody. We need lawyers. Within an hour, the streaming community had raised $50,000 for legal fees. Three lawyers volunteered pro Bono. News stations picked up the story from the viral clips. Two weeks later, she joined discord again, this time with video on sitting next to her mom who was crying. You saved my daughter's life. That camp, we had no idea. The FBI is investigating them now. 17 other kids have come forward. The camp shut down a month later. She started streaming last week, mostly Minecraft. Her username isn't please help me anymore. It finally free 2,024. She has 200,000 followers and counting. But here's what haunts me. In her first stream, she mentioned something. There were other kids who tried to run. They didn't know to call gamers. They called their parents and.

Lawyers, is there a case you regret winning? I was five years into my practice when they assigned me the case that still keeps me awake at night. Eric Walsh, 19 years old, accused of assaulting a girl named Jessica at some house party. Kid looked terrified when they brought him into the room. Kept saying over and over that he didn't do it. Jessica's story was intense. She gave all the these specific details about what happened, crying the whole time. Said Eric cornered her in the bathroom, described exactly what he was wearing, even remembered the song playing downstairs. It felt real, you know. But then I started digging deeper. Eric had three friends who swore he left the party early to grab cigarettes from a gas station across town. Tracked down the security footage from that night. There he was, clear as day buying Marlboroughs at exactly the time Jessica said he attacked her. The time stamp showed 11:47 p. M. Jessica claimed the assault happened at 11:45. I spent weeks building Eric's defense. Found more witnesses who remembered him leaving, got phone records showing he called his mom from the gas station, even found the receipt in his jacket pocket. Everything pointed to his innocence. During cross examination, Jessica's story started falling apart. She he couldn't explain how Eric could be in two places at once. Her friends admitted they hadn't actually seen him at the party that late. The prosecutor looked defeated. When I presented The footage. The judge dismissed all charges. Jessica, I got charged with filing a false report. Eric broke down crying right there in the courtroom. Hug me so tight I thought he might crack my ribs. He kept saying I saved his life, that nobody would have believed him without me. I felt good about it, really good. Here was this innocent kid who almost got destroyed by false accusations and I'd proven the truth. That's what lawyers are supposed to do, right? Two years later, I was having coffee before work when I saw Eric's mug shot on the morning news. Multiple victims, this time three college girls. They had video evidence, DNA, everything. He'd confessed to all of it during questioning. But what he said during that confession is what haunts me. He told the detective that getting falsely accused the first time had changed him, that he felt humiliated, angry at the system, said if everyone was going to treat him like a monster anyway, maybe he should give them something real to be scared of. My phone started ringing within an hour, reporters wanting to know how I felt about defending him. One victim's father called me directly screaming that I had blood on my hands, asked me how I could sleep at night knowing I'd helped a rapist walk free. The thing is, I still believe Eric was innocent the first time. The evidence was solid. But somehow fighting so hard to clear his name. Had planted this sick idea in his head that the world owed him something.

Mental asylum workers. Who's the most memorable patient you've ever worked with? His name was Gregory, and he only spoke once a day. Right after breakfast, he'd sit in the rec room, sip his orange juice, and say one sentence that made everyone's skin crawl. Someone's going to die today. At first, all of us ignored him. Gregory had been in and out of mental hospitals his whole adult life. Schizophrenia, they said. Delusions. Nothing new for us workers. But then Nurse Janet collapsed in the parking lot that same afternoon. Massive heart attack. Dead before the ambulance arrived. We figured it was just a coincidence. People die all the time, right? But the next week, Gregory did it again. Same routine. Orange juice, same chair, same creepy voice. Someone's going to die today. That night, our night cook, Eddie, never made it home. Car wrapped around a tree on Highway 9. Police said he fell asleep at the wheel. That's when we started paying attention. I mean, really paying attention. We began writing down everything Gregory said and checking obituaries, hospital records, anything we could find. For six straight months, Gregory was right every single time. Sometimes it was a patient who had a stroke in their sleep. Sometimes it was a staff member's spouse whose cancer suddenly got worse. Sometimes it was random people we'd never heard of, but their names would show up in the paper the next day. We called in specialists from the university, psychiatrists, Neurologists, even some professor who studied paranormal psychology. Nobody could explain it. Gregory couldn't explain it either. When doctors asked him how he knew, he just shrug and say he didn't want to know. He just did. The whole staff was on edge. Every morning after breakfast, we all gather around and wait for Gregory's daily prediction like it was the weather report from hell. Some nurses started calling in sick just to avoid hearing it. But then one Tuesday morning, Gregory said something different. Something that made my blood freeze. This place will burn. Holy shit. We took that seriously. Fire drills every day. The maintenance team checked every single outlet, every space heater, every piece of kitchen equipment. Twice the fire department came through and gave us a clean inspection. Nothing was wrong. Everything looked perfect. Two weeks later, we had a new patient. Seventeen year old Caleb, who tried to burn down his family's garage during intake security. Missed the tiny lighter he'd hidden under his tongue. Rookie mistake. It was 3 a m. When the smoke started. Caleb had lit a mop in the supply closet, and the whole thing went up fast. Our smoke detectors had been acting up for weeks. Budget cuts meant we kept putting off repairs. But Gregory was already awake, already moving. He pulled the emergency fire alarm before any of us even smelled smoke. Then he did something that still gives me chills. He LED four of us to a Window exit that hadn't been used in 15 years. The lock was rusted shut, but Gregory kicked it open like he'd done it 100 times before. We got everyone out through that window. All 36 patients and eight staff members. The main exits were already blocked by smoke. If Gregory hadn't known about that old window, half of us would have died.

My brother told my mom about my search history, so I turned him into a femboy and removed his virginity. Look, don't come for me until you've heard the full story. My little brother Liam decided to be a hero. Went through my phone, found my search history. You know, the usual stuff. Anime, memes, some specific art like femboys, furry as, and other stuff. Instead of being a bro, he printed it. I highlighted it, gave our mom a full Powerpoint presentation at dinner. I was grounded for a month. Mom looked at me like I drowned a puppy. I didn't scream, I didn't fight him. That's what he wanted. I got creative. Liam's a gym bro. All he cares about are his gains and his loser football friends. His biggest fear? Being perceived as soft or cute. So I became his personal stylist against his will. Phase 1. I swapped his manly body wash for my lavender and honey scrub. Within a week, his teammates were asking why he smelled like a bath and body works. The confusion on his face was priceless. Phase 2 laundry warfare. I started mixing my clothes with his. A lace trim from my fishnets tangled in his jeans. A revealing top snuck into his load. His gray sweats came out smelling like vanilla and shimmering under the lights. The masterpiece was the school charity event. I bought two dozen rainbow bracelets, paid his best friend 20 bucks to tell everyone Liam had A crush on some goth boy by the bleachers. And was changing his vibe to impress him. Overnight, the narrative shifted. Liam wasn't just a jock. He was the sensitive king. His friends thought it was hilarious. They dared him to wear a choker. Bought him a skirt as a joke. And the thing is, he didn't hate it. The attention was an addiction. He started asking me for advice. How to walk in platforms, how to do eyeliner. His search history quickly became way worse than mine. He started a TikTok. Pretty boy Liam. But I wasn't done. I introduced him to my friend Alex. Alex is persuasive. They started talking, hanging out. Then one night, I heard things from his room. Let's just say Alex fully educated him. Clapped his cheeks. Now, Liam doesn't just dress the part. He lives it full time. He never apologized for snitching. He probably doesn't even remember these days. He's too busy picking out fishnets and living his best life. So, yeah, I got revenge. I didn't just change his clothes. I changed his entire life. And honestly, he's never been happier. You're welcome, Liam. Maybe now mom will finally stop looking at me.

You ever made one joke and the universe just ran with it. Started when I jokingly told my bio teacher I was rehabilitating the local crow population after she caught me sharing my lunch with them. She laughed and said, sure, whatever keeps them from stealing from the cafeteria dumpsters. Thing is, I had no idea at the time that crows have facial recognition software better than the FBI. Within two weeks, my three Crow friends became 20. They'd wait for me at the bus stop, escort me to class and honestly, the littering problem disappeared. They'd literally steal trash from kids and bring it to the bins for my approval. I'd nod, toss them a fry. Environmental vigilantes. But here's where it gets insane. They started learning everyone's faces and their relationship to me. That kid who shoved me in the hallway, dive bombs during PE until he apologized. The group that kept cutting in lunch line suddenly found crows standing guard at their usual spot, calling menacingly my Spanish teacher who gave me detention. Her car was decorated extensively. The principal called me in. We need to discuss your associates. I tried explaining I don't control them, but mid sentence, five crows landed on his windowsill like the Mafia. One tap a glass with its beak. He gave me extra credit in environmental science and sent me on my way. Now the whole school calls me Crow Mother. The janitor brings me bags of peanuts and begs me To have them focus on the soccer field, the security guard asks which kids have been problematic lately? Teachers slit me snacks to ensure safe passage to their cars. Best part, my AP bio teacher convinced me to enter the whole thing as a science fair. Pod corvid behavioral patterns and social conditioning won regionals. The judge asked if it was ethical. A crow landed on his table with a bottle cap as a gift. He gave me first place. Now college essays are writing themselves. Describe a unique extracurricular done. My guidance counselor actually said it's the most interesting thing she's read in 20 years of applications. The local Audubon Society invited me to speak. Some grad student wants to study my murder for her thesis. My mom keeps the newspaper clipping on the fridge. Local teens unusual bird bond wins science recognition. So yeah, I joked about being a crow whisperer and the universe said, bet. Now it's my actual career plan.

I waited for the right moment to mention my ski trip. I have some news about my holiday plans, I began. That's when Sarah looked up from her phone with a huge smile. Oh, that's perfect timing, she said loudly. I was just about to tell you, we're all flying to Hawaii tomorrow morning. My stomach dropped. Everyone started smiling and nodding. They all knew everyone except me. Me, Tom, Emma, David, mom and dad. We're all going for a week, Sarah continued. The flights are booked. The hotel is paid for. What about the kids, I heard myself asking. Sarah waved her hand dismissively. Oh, we're dropping them off at your place tomorrow morning before we head to the airport. You don't mind, right? It's just for a week. Just for a week. A week of three kids in my tiny apartment while I was supposed to be skiing with my friends. You didn't ask me, I said. You didn't ask if I could watch them or if I'm even available. Sarah laughed. Come on, Nina, you're always available. You work from home. Those words hit me like a slap. Always available. Because my life, my work, my plans, none of it mattered to them. No, I said. The silence was deaf. What do you mean no? Mom asked. I mean, no, I'm not available to babysit next week. I have plans. What plans? Dad demanded you never go anywhere. I have my own plans for the holidays. I Repeated firmly plans that don't involve babysitting. Sarah slammed her hand on the table. This is unbelievable. Do you realise you could ruin our entire vacation? We can't just cancel everything now.

The most entitled thing a family member has demanded from you. After seven months of failed attempts, my husband Kyle and I announced that we were finally pregnant. Everyone erupted with cheers, except for my sister Jacqueline, who smashed her wine glass against the marble counter. How dare you! She shrieked. You know how long I've been trying for a baby. I deserve to be the first. Mom tried to tell her nineteen year olds aren't ready for a baby, but Jacqueline refused to back down. She grabbed her purse and dramatically stormed out, yelling that I better abort my baby within one week, or else she's getting the police involved. The next morning, she showed up at our door with printed pages from abortion clinics, shoving them into Kyle's chest while he was still in his boxers. I made appointments for her at three different places. She announced to our entire cul de sac, she just needs to pick one. When Kyle tore up the papers, she called the whole family, demanding an emergency intervention. That Sunday, 23 relatives crammed into my mom's living room while Jacqueline stood at the fireplace like she was delivering a T E D. Talk on why I was destroying her life by having a baby first. She actually had a Powerpoint. Our uncle Jeffrey, who's a lawyer, finally told her, there's no legal precedent for forcing someone to abort because you want to be pregnant first. She pointed at me with tears streaming. Down her face and said if I didn't terminate by Monday, she'd never speak to any of us again. But we called her bluff, and all 23 of us told her, see you, Felicia. She actually left sobbing, and we didn't hear from her for a long time. And then, seven months into my pregnancy, we were having our baby shower. When the door flew open. It was Jacqueline. She walked in with her hand on a massive belly, wearing a shirt that said first grandchild loading. Everyone went silent. Mom dropped her cake knife. Surprise! I'm almost due! She announced, spinning around so everyone could see. I got pregnant right after that horrible meeting where you all betrayed me. I'm 10 weeks away from giving birth. Nobody was impressed. And when I decided to screw with her and mentioned my due date that was eight weeks. Weeks away, her face turned deep red with anger. She grabbed my arm and whispered the dates didn't matter because she'd make sure hers came first, then left before anyone could respond. My mom called me that Tuesday, bawling her eyes out. She'd found out from Jacqueline's roommate that Jacqueline have been taking black market labor induction substances she'd bought from some website in Romania, risking her baby's life to deliver before me. Now Jacqueline was in the ICU, but not because of the substances. Turns out Jacqueline had found some girl on Craigslist whose mother used to be a midwife in the Philippines and paid this girl to perform a C section in her living room. The girl kept refusing, saying Jacqueline was only 31 weeks. But my sister threatened to do it herself with kitchen knives if she didn't help. They used box better sterilized with vodka. Jacqueline lost so much blood that her neighbor saw it seeping under the apartment door. The baby somehow came out alive, but he was purple and barely breathing. They both nearly died in the ambulance. The baby went straight to the NICU on a ventilator, and Jacqueline needed a full hysterectomy. She'd never have another child. When she came to, the first thing she did was call me from her hospital bed. You did this? She gasped through the oxygen mask. My baby is dying because you couldn't wait until me to have a child. The craziest part about all this is now that she was fighting for life. Suddenly, the fam

Did my allergen literally drop her clipboard when she saw what I was reacting to on the test panel? I was 15 when my life basically flipped upside down in the weirdest way possible. For months, I've been having these crazy stomach cramps that made me double over in the middle of class. My parents kept saying it was just stress from school, maybe too much coffee or whatever, but our family doctor wasn't buying it and sent me to get a full allergy panel done. I remember sitting in that sterile clinic room, rolling my eyes as the nurse prepped, like, 50 different allergen samples. I was thinking, great, I'm probably allergic to peanuts or milk like every other kid. Maybe shellfish if I'm unlucky. The nurse started pricking my arm with tiny needles, each one containing a different substance. Dust, mites, pollen, cat dander, the usual suspects.
