She kept checking her watch and marking down reactions as little red bumps appeared on my skin. Most were barely visible, just tiny dots that looked like mosquito bites. But then I noticed her face change when she looked at one specific spot on my arm. The area around this one test site was literally bubbling up like a balloon. My skin was bright red and swelling so fast, I could actually watch it grow. The nurse called in Doctor Kim. The allergist took one look at my arm, and I swear her clipboard hit the floor. She whispered, oh, no, Under her breath. And immediately started ordering additional tests. I was like, what the hell is happening? What could possibly be that bad? Turns out I was severe.

I told my roommate that the name she chose for her baby is ridiculously stupid. So my roommate Ashley is this huge game of Thrones fanatic. Like, she has posters all over her room and she's constantly rewatching episodes. She's 24 and pregnant with her first kid. About two weeks ago she comes up to me all excited talking about baby names. She tells me she wants to name the baby Aria. I actually thought that was pretty cool since Aria means noble in Sanskrit. But I mentioned that tons of people have been naming their kids after game of Thrones characters lately, so it might be super common. I wasn't trying to be mean or anything, just being honest. The next morning I'm making coffee and Ashley comes bouncing into the kitchen like she just solved world hunger. She's all like, I figured out how to name my baby Aria, but make it totally unique so she won't be just another goatee kid at school. I'm thinking maybe she found some different spelling or something. Boy was I wrong. She pulls out her phone and shows me what she wrote down. I had to read it three times before I could even process what I was looking at. Augria. I'm not even kidding. That's how she wanted to spell Aria. She explained it like she was teaching me rocket science. See, it's Augregia, which sounds like Aria, but nobody will connect it to the show. I just stared at Her for like 10 seconds. Then I asked if she was serious. She got this confused look and asked what I meant. That's when I told her straight up that Augregia looks ridiculously stupid and she should just stick with regular Aria. I mean, come on, that poor kid would spend her entire life spelling out her name for people. Teachers would butcher it on the first day of school every single year. Ashley's face went completely red and she started yelling about how I was the one who said Aria was too common. She said her and her boyfriend Tyler spent hours coming up with the spelling to make me happy. I tried to explain that having a common name is way better than having a name that looks like someone sneezed while typing, but she wasn't having it. She storms off to her room and starts texting Tyler about how mean I was being. I can hear her through the thin walls going on and on about how I crushed her creative baby naming dreams. Later that day, Tyler shows up at our apartment. He's this skinny guy who works at GameStop and thinks he's way smarter than everyone else. He starts lecturing me about how unique names build character and help kids stand out. I asked him to write down Agrigio without looking at Ashley's phone. He couldn't do it. He got to Auger and then just stared at the paper looking confused. That's when I was Like dude, your own kids name is going to stump you every time you fill out forms. Think about that. Ashley came out of her room crying and said I was ruining everything. She kept going on about how she just wanted her daughter to be special and not blend in with all the other arias. I felt kind of bad seeing her cry, but honestly someone had to tell her. I said, look, if you want your kid to be special, teach her cool stuff and help her develop her personality. Don't saddle her with a name that looks like a typo. The whole apartment got super awkward after that. Ashley wouldn't talk to me for three days. When she finally did, she announced that they decided to go with a completely different name

My husband won't let me sleep. I work 12 hour shifts running dangerous machinery at the steel plant. I need every minute of sleep I can get just to keep my fingers attached. You mess up for even a second around those machines and you're going home missing body parts. My husband has this buddy Troy who drives trucks. Troy calls every single night between 1 and 4 in the morning and my husband answers every time. Then he proceeds to have these loud hour long conversations right next to me in bed. The first few times I figured it was an emergency or something, but no, they're just talking about random stuff, always complaining about his dispatcher or talking about some diner he stopped at. Normal everyday stuff that could easily wait until normal hours. I asked my husband nicely to maybe take the calls in the living room so I could sleep. He said, no, Troy needs someone to talk to while he drives or he'll fall asleep at the wheel. I said, okay, but can you at least whisper or step outside? He said Troy can barely hear him as it is. So I tried earplugs. Didn't work. Sound travels right through them. I tried moving to the couch, but our couch is this ancient thing from his college days that feels like sleeping on concrete blocks. After two weeks of getting maybe three hours of sleep at night, I was starting to see things. I nearly Took my thumb off at work because I was so tired I couldn't focus. My supervisor pulled me aside and said if I kept messing up, I'd be written up. That night, Troy called it 2:30, right on schedule. My husband answered and started talking at full volume about football scores. I snapped. I got up and went to the guest bedroom. We don't really use it except when his parents visit, but it has a bed and a door I can close. I slept better that night than I had in weeks. The next morning, my husband was furious. He said it hurt his feelings that I wasn't sleeping next to him. I explained that I literally cannot sleep when he's talking on the phone for an hour every night. He said that was my problem to figure out. So I've been sleeping in the guest room for two weeks now. Every morning he gives me the silent treatment. He makes these little comments about how I'm abandoning our marriage over a phone call. He told his mom I moved out of our bed dream and now she's calling me dramatic. But here's the thing, my job is dangerous. I make good money, but one mistake and I could lose a finger or worse. I need to be alert. I need to sleep. Last night he tried a new approach. He came into the guest room at midnight and shook me awake. He said we needed to talk about Our relationship issues. I told him we could talk in the morning and he said, no, we're talking now. He kept me awake until 3 in the morning going in circles about how I'm being selfish and how marriage is about compromise. Then Troy called and my husband answered it right there in the guest room. I grabbed my pillow and went to sleep on that awful couch. This morning, I woke up with my back completely messed up. I could barely bend over to tie my work boots at the plant. I was moving slow and my supervisor noticed. He asked if everything was okay at home. I realized I've been going to work exhausted and in pain for weeks now, all because my husband refuses to take his phone calls anywhere else. His friend could call him at a normal hour. He could step outside. He could go to the basement, but he won't. When I got home today, he was on the phone with Troy again at 6 in the evening. This time I asked him why Troy was calling so early and he said Troy wanted to apologize for keeping me awake. Then he handed me the phone. Troy said he had no idea I worked such dangerous hours. He said he could easily call during the day when he takes his breaks. I seem genuinely sorry and confused about why this was even an issue. My husband grabbed the phone back and told Troy not To worry about it, that I was just being dramatic about needing sleep. Troy got quiet and said he had to go.

Why did my makeup routine save my life during a home invasion? So I'm obsessed with Halloween makeup tutorials on YouTube and decided to practice this insane zombie look at like eleven PM because I'm weird like that. I'm talking full on rotting flesh, fake blood dripping down my face, the works. I had my bedroom light on and was sitting right by the window because that's where my good mirror is. I'm in the middle of adding some gnarly scabs when I noticed this guy walking up my driveway super slowly. First I thought maybe he was just lost or something, but then he starts looking in windows and trying door handles. My heart literally stops. Like I'm home alone because my roommate went to visit her parents for the weekend and suddenly I'm watching this stranger case my house like he's shopping for groceries. I freeze completely. My hands are shaking so bad I dropped my makeup brush and it clatters on my desk. I'm thinking, okay, don't panic. Maybe he's just checking if anyone's home before knocking. But deep down I know this isn't normal. Normal people don't peek into windows at eleven PM normal people don't try door handles on houses that aren't theirs. My brain starts going into overdrive. Should I call 9, 1 1? Should I hide? Should I grab something to defend myself? All I have nearby is a curling iron and some makeup brushes, which suddenly feel like the world's most pathetic Weapons. I'm literally sitting there with fake blood all over my face having an existential crisis about whether a flat iron could be used as a weapon. Then my phone buzzes with a text from my mom asking if I'm okay because she had a weird feeling. Moms and their intuition. I swear I wanted to text back. Actually, there's literally a potential burglar outside my house right now, but I was too scared to look away from the window. Plus, how do you even explain that you're currently dressed like a zombie extra while watching someone try to break into your house? The worst part was that I had spent two hours on this makeup look and I was actually pretty proud of how realistic it looked like this was my best work yet. The irony wasn't lost on me that my best artistic achievement was about to become my scariest real life moment. Here's where it gets crazy. He walks right up to my bedroom window and sees me sitting there with my zombie face on. I'm talking exposed skull.

Boyfriend wanted me to pretend we weren't together at his work party. My boyfriend Nathan told me this while we were getting ready for his company holiday party tonight. We need to act like we're not together, he said. While messing with his watch. I stopped putting on my makeup and look at him. What? Just don't tell anyone you're my girlfriend. Don't hold my hand. Don't stand near me. I couldn't believe what I was hearing. We've been together for two years. Why? He let out this annoyed sigh like I was being ridiculous. My boss only promotes single guys. He thinks relationships make you weak, less focused. I been telling him I'm single since I started gunning for this promotion three months ago. I felt my stomach drop. Three months of lying about me. He said everyone brings plus one, so it would look weird if he came alone. But I had to pretend to be someone from his apartment building. The promotion decision was Monday. I looked at him in the mirror and felt something shift inside me. I put on my earrings real slow. Okay, Nathan, whatever you need. The second we got there, Nathan walked in way ahead of me, like he didn't even know me. I headed straight to the bar where his coworker Brian was getting a drink. I don't think we've met, Brian said with a friendly smile. I'm Nathan's neighbor from his building. It was the cover story Nathan wanted. Brian Smiled bigger and got me a drink. We were talking for about 20 minutes when he asked, are you seeing anyone? I looked over at Nathan, who was pretending I didn't exist. No, I'm single. Brian's whole face lit up. Wanna meet my buddy Louise from accounting? He waved over a guy from across the room. Louise was actually really charming and kept touching my arm while we talked. Nathan showed up at the bar acting like he just needed a drink. Nathan, meet this gorgeous woman who lives in your building. Louis was excited. Nathan had to shake my hand like we were complete strangers. Nice to meet you, he said, and I could hear how mad he was. You too, I said back. Louis jumped right back in. I was just about to get her number. He handed me his phone. I typed my number in while Nathan stood there, his jaw clenching. About 10 minutes later, Nathan's boss came over to our group. Who's this lovely lady? He asked with this big smile. While she's single and lives in Nathan's building, Louise announced, looking pretty proud of himself. The boss's eyes got all bright. Nathan, you seeing this? While you're focused on work, Louise is out here meeting beautiful women from your own building. Nathan forced out this fake laugh. His boss kept going, though. This is what I mean. You stay single, you stay hungry. Relationships kill ambition. No offense. Turn to me when he said, That last part. None taken. I agree completely. I was looking right at Nathan when I said it. The boss just wouldn't stop. Nathan here is my best example. Three months without a single date. That's dedication. That's why he's getting promoted. Monday, everyone raise their glasses to toast Nathan's promotion. I raise mine, too. To staying single, I said, staring straight at Nathan. His hand was literally shaking when he took a drink. Luis asked me to dance after that. While we were on the dance

When did your friends realise you weren't starving yourself? We're halfway through freshman year and my friends still grab my wrist to show people how their fingers overlap or joke that I could share my metabolism with them. Not last week. My roommate Leah literally put extra fries on my plate when I wasn't looking because someone needs to feed you, babe. Finding this friend group three months into college felt like finally breathing. They adopted me instantly. Leah pulling me into their booth at the dining hall, Sophie looping her arm through mine at parties. At every party they joke I was their pocket sized friend. Leah makes comments like eat a burger skinny whenever we go out. For months it was relentless but weirdly affectionate. You're gonna blow away. Real women have her bones are for dogs. Every meal was commentary. How are you full already? Must be nice to eat whatever you want. from their guy friend group literally picked me up with one arm once just to prove he could. But it felt like belonging, like finally having friends who cared enough to tease me. Besides bringing up my celiac seems dramatic. I'd rather take the skinny jokes and be the friend who needs special accommodations. Then three weeks ago, something shifted. The comments stopped. No more eat a burger jokes. No more grabbing my wrists. Instead, they got weird, careful, like they were walking on eggshells. Leah started buying extra snacks for the room. Casually leaving them on my desk. Sophie stopped making the metabolism jokes with random compliments about my personality. Olivia began suggesting restaurants with lots of options. When we went out Thursday night, I'm coming back early from Bio Lab and I hear them through the door. Our whole crew is in there. Leah, Sophie, Olivia, Jade, Madison. They never hang without me. Saturday at the pregame, before everyone else shows up, Leah's saying we have to be supportive but direct. The signs were all there. Jade says she never finishes meals, goes to the bathroom right after eating. She's getting thinner. My heart stops. They think I'm bulimic. Madison adds something about nutrition labels and restrictive behavior. Leah's voice gets soft, talking about doing this with love. They're planning an intervention for me. I text Sam from home about what I just heard. She asks what they could possibly be staging an intervention for. And when I tell them they think I'm bulimic, she points out the obvious. It's because of my celiact, but they don't know about that. She tells me to just tell them. But I have a better idea. I'm going to make a point. Saturday arrives. I've been at the library all day, giving them time to set up. At 5:45, I hit up the only gluten.

My husband threw a B B Q party for his friends. I refused to help, so the party was a disaster. My husband Ryan decides on Wednesday that he's throwing a B B Q party this Saturday for his work buddies. Not asks me, not mentions it in passing, just walks in the door and goes, hey, babe, the guys are coming over Saturday for my famous ribs. Famous ribs, my ass. The only thing famous about them is how I do literally everything except flip the meat. I'm talking about getting all the drinks, cleaning our entire back deck, washing every plate and cup we own because god forbid we use paper plates, prepping all the sides, refilling drinks every 5 minutes and cleaning up after grown men who apparently never Learned to put their own plate in the dishwasher. Meanwhile, Ryan just stands there with his stupid beer in one hand and tongs in the other soaking up compliments like he's some kind of grill master. But this time was different. I looked at him dead in the eye and said, cool, have fun with your guys night. He got this confused look and goes, what do you mean? I told him exactly what he said, guys night. So I'll be in my craft room with my wine and my painting and he can handle his own party. He laughed it off like I was joking. Come on. You know how these things work, right? There made me See red? Yeah, I know exactly how these things work. I do all the work and he gets all the credit. Saturday rolls around and I'm watching through the window as he realizes he's screwed. First, three of his work friends show up and our back deck looks like a tornado hit it. Dog toys everywhere, cushions all dirty from our lab mixbuster. And the table still has dried coffee rings from last weekend. Ryan's running around trying to clean up while the grills already going. Then the text start, where are the good plates? I text back that he said he'd handle everything. Where's the beer? Did you not buy beer? Nope, he said he'd handle it. What about potato salad? What about it, honey? Pour myself a massive glass of wine and turn my music up louder. Through my craft room window, I can see the whole disaster unfolding. One of his friends had to drive to the gas station for drinks. Another guy ordered pizza because there's literally just meat and nothing else. They're eating off our everyday plates with plastic forks because we only have like 6 real forks and Ryan couldn't figure out where we keep the rest. The funniest part was watching Ryan try to explain where everything is. He's lived in this house for three years and apparently never noticed that we keep the extra dishes in the basement storage room or that beer needs to go in the fridge ahead of time. To actually be cold or that people might want something other than unseasoned ribs. I checked on them around 8 and it looked like a frat house after a party. Random takeout containers everywhere. Someone spilled barbecue sauce on our outdoor cushions and they're all drinking warm beer out of coffee mugs because Ryan gave up looking for proper cups. Sunday morning comes and Ryan stomping around the house all pissy. He has the nerve to tell me I embarrassed him in front of his co workers and made our family look bad. I laughed so hard I nearly choked on my coffee. I told him, buddy, you embarrassed yourself. I'm not your personal party planner. He goes, you could have at least helped a little. These are important people from my work. So I asked him, when's the last time you helped me? When my friends came over? Silence. Because when my book club meets here, guess who cleans the house, makes the snacks and sets everything up while he plays video games in the basement? He tried to argue that it's different because his friends are from work and it matters for his career. I told him maybe next time he should ask me before volunteering our house and my labour for his networking events.

My brother told my mom about my search history, so I turned him into a femboy and removed his virginity. Look, don't come for me until you've heard the full story. My little brother Liam decided to be a hero. Went through my phone, found my search history, you know, the usual stuff, anime, memes, some specific art like femboys, furry as and other stuff. Instead of being a bro, he printed it. I highlighted it, gave our mom a full Powerpoint presentation at dinner. I was grounded for a month. Mom looked at me like I drowned a puppy. I didn't scream. I didn't fight him. That's what he wanted. I got creative. Liam's a gym bro. All he cares about are his gains and his loser football friends. His biggest fear, being perceived as soft or cute. So I became his personal stylist against his will. Phase 1, I swapped his manly body wash for my lavender and honey scrub. Within a week, his teammates were asking why he smelled like a bath and body works. The confusion on his face was priceless. Phase 2, laundry warfare. I started mixing my clothes with his. A lace trim from my fishnets tangled in his jeans. A revealing top snuck into his load. His gray sweats came out smelling like vanilla and shimmering under the lights. The masterpiece was the school charity event. I bought two dozen rainbow bracelets, paid his best friend 20 bucks to tell everyone Liam had A crush on some goth boy by the bleachers and was changing his vibe to impress him. Overnight, the narrative shifted. Liam wasn't just a jock. He was the sensitive king. His friends thought it was hilarious. They dared him to wear a choker, bought him a skirt as a joke. And the thing is, he didn't hate it. The attention was an addiction. He started asking me for advice, how to walk in platforms, how to do eyeliner. His search history quickly became way worse than mine. He started a TikTok pretty boy, Liam. But I wasn't done. I introduced him to my friend Alex. Alex is persuasive. They started talking, hanging out. Then one night, I heard things from his room. Let's just say Alex fully educated him, clapped his cheeks. Now, Liam doesn't just dress the part. He lives it full time. He never apologized for snitching. He probably doesn't even remember these days. He's too busy picking out fishnets and living his best life. So yeah, I got revenge. I didn't just change his clothes. I changed his entire life. And honestly, he's never been happier. You're welcome, Liam. Maybe now mom will finally stop looking at me.
NA
NA

How can you train yourself to fall asleep quickly like they do in the military? College completely destroyed my sleep schedule. I'd study until 3:00am, then lie in bed wide awake until sunrise. Energy drinks during the day, panic attacks at night. Nothing worked. Then my roommate's boyfriend, who was in the Marines, saw me looking like death during finals week. Dude, you look terrible, he said. That night he taught me the military sleep hack his sergeant used in combat zones. Here's exactly what you do. Lie down and relax every muscle in your face, especially around your eyes and jaw. Most people don't realize they clench their jaw all day. Next, drop your shoulders completely and let your arms go limp beside you. Now comes the secret part. Breathe in through your nose for exactly four seconds. Hold your breath for seven seconds. This is crucial. Don't skip this step. Then exhale through your mouth for eight seconds, making a whoosh sound. The long exhale tricks your nervous system into thinking you're safe. Do this 4, 7, 8 pattern exactly four times. While picturing yourself somewhere peaceful, I imagine floating on a lake at sunset. The first night I tried it, I was convinced it wouldn't work. By the third breath cycle, I was completely out. Now I can fall asleep in under two minutes, even with my noisy neighbors throwing parties. After practicing for just one week, my brain Learned to recognize this as sleep time. Last Month I aced all my finals without a single all nighter for the first time ever.

What did your child say in court that saved someone's life? The first time she opened her mouth in court, I didn't expect her words to stop a sentencing. We were packed into that courthouse like sardines. The walls felt too close, the benches too hard, and my heartbeat too loud. My daughter Olivia, just 8 years old, sat beside me, swinging her feet. She looked so small in that big room. Her Sunday dress too formal. Her hair and braids I'd redone three times that morning just to keep my hands busy. Across the aisle sat the man who had taken everything from us. He was just 20. A kid, really. He didn't look dangerous. Just tired. Like he hadn't slept since the night he pulled the trigger. But I didn't care how tired he looked. My husband was gone, and he was still breathing. The widow of the store clerk, my husband's boss, sat silently, her eyes hollow. Next to her was her son, maybe 10, clinging to her arm. I wanted to reach for Olivia's hand, but she was busy twisting the edge of the paper heart she'd made that morning. The one I didn't have the strength to ask about. The prosecutor spoke first. Cold, clinical. The victim was an innocent man. A father, a husband. This was a violent, senseless act. Then came the defense. They talked about his upbringing. Broken home, drug addicted mother, foster care. They showed pictures of his bruises, his grades, His attempts at rehab. This doesn't excuse the crime, his lawyer said. But we asked the court to consider who he was before he picked up the gun. I hated how calm they all sounded, how measured, like this was just another case. The judge asked if anyone else wished to speak. I felt the weight of the room tilt toward me. Everyone expected the grieving wife to stand, but I couldn't. I'd written 10 different versions of a statement and tore up every single one. The only thing I wanted to say was, give me my husband back, and that wasn't an option. Then Olivia raised her hand. I didn't even realize what she was doing until she was already standing. Walking to the front like it was show and tell. The courtroom murmured. The bailiff looked to the judge, who gave a small nod. And just like that, my daughter stood before the man who murdered her father. My name is Olivia, she said, her voice small but steady.

Did you realize you raised your daughter right? My daughter Elia destroyed our neighbor's face with a baseball bat. I was in the middle of a work meeting when my phone lit up with a call from my neighbor, Roman. His voice was shaking with fury. Your daughter Elia is psychotic. She attacked me with a baseball bat. I was just checking on her like you asked, and she broke my effing nose. The cops are already here. My blood ran cold. Elia was a straight a student and had never been in a fight in her life. I ran to my car and started driving. The 20 minute drive home felt like hours. My mind racing through every possible scenario. Roman's words kept echoing in my head. Psychotic, attacked, broke my nose. What could have possibly happened? By the time I reached our driveway, my shirt was soaked with sweat. The scene that greeted me was even worse than I'd imagined. Police cruisers were parked outside with their lights flashing and half the neighborhood had gathered on their lawns to stare. Roman was on our front porch and was holding a towel to what was clearly a broken nose. His white polo shirt was stained red and he was gesturing wildly at two officers who were taking notes. She, he needs to be locked up, he was shouting. This is assault with a deadly weapon. I want charges pressed. Elia sat on our front lawn with her knees pulled To her chest, staring at the grass. She looked so small, so defeated. The female officer approached me as I got out of the car. Sir, your neighbor claims your daughter attacked him unprovoked with a baseball bat. If he presses charges, we're looking at aggravated assault. That could mean juvenile detention. My stomach dropped. Roman saw me and immediately started ranting, she's violent, unhinged. I was just checking on her like you asked, making sure she got home safe from school. And she came at me like a wild animal. Look at my face. My nose is broken. I might need surgery. The male officer showed me photos they taken of Roman's injuries. His nose was definitely broken, already starting to bruise. Your daughter hasn't said a word since we arrived, the officer said quietly. We need to know what happened here. I walked past Roman, ignoring his continued shouting about pressing charges and teaching violent children a lesson. Then I knelt down beside Elia on the grass and I put my hand on her shoulder. She flinched but didn't look up. Ella, sweetheart, I need you to tell me exactly what happened, every detail. She finally raised her head and I saw her eyes were red from crying. But there was something else there, too, anger, maybe even disgust. I was in my room, she said, her voice barely a whisper.

I changed my name because my parents named me Corstal. Crystal. My parents actually looked at a Newborn baby and thought, let's spell Crystal like we're trying to unlock a cheat code. For 18 years, I dealt with this disaster of a name that looked like someone sneezed while typing. Every first day of school was the same nightmare. Teachers would get to my name on the roll call and just stop, dead silence. Then they'd attempt some butchered pronunciation like curse style or quest illie. I'd have to raise my hand and say it's just crystal, but spelled like my parents hate me. The worst part wasn't even the pronunciation. It was the assumptions. People would see my name written down and immediately think I was some exotic foreign exchange student or that my family was super religious. I got asked if I was Muslim at least once a week. Random people would come up to me asking what country I was from or what language my name came from. I'd have to explain that, no, my parents just thought they were being creative when they were really just being cruel. My mom was the worst about it. She'd email every single teacher at the beginning of each, well, year with a whole paragraph about how to pronounce my name correctly and the cultural significance behind the spelling. There was no cultural significance. She just saw the name Crystal in a baby book and decided to make it look Fancy. When I was 15, I started telling people to just save my name as Crystal in their phones. It made everything easier. But my mom found out when she saw a text from my friend Jess that just said Crystal and she completely lost it. She grounded me for two weeks and made me write apology letters to all my friends explaining the proper way to spell my name. That's when I knew I was changing it. The second I turned 18, the day after my birthday, I marched down to the courthouse with all my paperwork. The clerk was super nice about it. She.

You ever wanted to slap your boyfriend's girl? Best friend Tessa had been in my boyfriend's life since kindergarten. She called him Babe in front of me, touched his arm during conversations, and somehow always needed emotional support. At eleven PM, my boyfriend would insist she was like a sister, that I was being paranoid. Maybe I was. Until I decided to surprise him with homemade lasagna after his study group. I used my spare key, expecting to find him exhausted over textbooks. Instead, I found Tessa curled up on his couch in one of his oversized shirts, the same shirt I bought him, watching Netflix like she owned the place. She didn't move when she saw me, just said he was in the shower and they were hanging out. Something in her tone made my stomach twist. When I asked about his shirt, she shrugged, claimed she'd spilled wine on hers, and he'd offered. When my boyfriend emerged from the bathroom, hair damp, he froze seeing me there. Not happy. Surprise. Guilt. He thought I was working late. I told him I'd finished early and wanted to surprise him, holding up the container. But he already had company. Tessa stretched dramatically and announced she should go, thanked him for listening about her breakup drama. Breakup drama? This was news to me. After she left, my boyfriend launched into explanations. How Tessa was going through a rough patch, how she needed a friend, how I was being jealous over nothing. I pointed out she was practically naked in his apartment. Protested she was wearing a shirt. Would I rather he let her walk around covered in wine? The gaslighting was masterful. Almost made me doubt what I'd seen. Two weeks later, I found her hair tie on his nightstand. When I confronted him, he had another perfect explanation. When I found her lip gloss in his bathroom, she'd been getting ready for a job interview. Every piece of evidence had a logical explanation. That made me feel crazy. The breaking point came during my birthday dinner. Halfway through appetizers, his phone buzzed. Tessa was having a panic attack. He needed to go check on her. I asked if it had to be now, watching my birthday candles flicker. Couldn't someone else help her? She only trusted him. He said, already standing, he'd be back in an hour. He never came back. I sat with our friends, making excuses until the restaurant closed. When he finally called at midnight, Tessa had needed him to stay overnight on my birthday. That's when I realised the truth. I wasn't his girlfriend. I was the other woman in his relationship with Tessa. The next morning, I showed up at his apartment with all his belongings and garbage bags. As I answered the door, in his shirt again, she said smugly that he wasn't there, but she could take the bags for him. I pushed past her, explaining I was actually there for her. What I found confirm

Forgot I had a camera in our house and have never been the same. My boyfriend and I waited for months for our baby to say his first word. But he kept telling me not to worry, that boys develop slower. I was starting to get anxious because Cody was way past when he should have been talking. Then one Tuesday morning while I was feeding him breakfast, it finally happened. Cody looked right at me, smiled and clear as day said may. I screamed with excitement, immediately calling Jake into the kitchen. He, he said his first word. He said may. But Jake's face went weird when he heard it. He shook his head and said I must have misheard him, that babies don't usually say random months as their first words. But I knew what I heard. Over the next few days, Cody kept saying it, may, may, always the same word, always with this happy little giggle. Afterward, Jake kept insisting I was wrong, that he was just babbling. But something about how defensive he got made me uneasy. After a week of Cody only saying may, I started getting concerned. Other babies said Mama or Dada. I tried teaching him other words, pointing at myself, saying Mama over and over, but he just smile and say may again. The weird part was how Jake reacted every single time he tense up, change the subject or suddenly need to leave the room. One afternoon, our babysitter Kenna Was over while I was getting ready for work and Cody said it again, May. Kenna and I looked at each other. I saw panic in her face. There was something she wasn't telling me and Cody knew about it. She sat down at the kitchen table and said she had something to tell me, something she'd been feeling guilty about for months. Kenna was bobbing so hard she could barely get the words out. I had to wait five minutes for her to contain herself, dying to know what she was about to tell me. Then she admitted that sometimes we were out, she'd been bringing her friend over to help watch Cody. Her friend's name was Shay. I'm so sorry, Kenna kept saying. I know I should have asked permission. My mind was racing. Shay, not may. I actually laughed, hugging Kenna and telling her it was okay. I was just glad to finally understand what Cody was trying to say. However, I wanted to see it for myself. So I got an idea. The next day before Kenna came over, I put a camera in our living room to see if she'd bring her friend over. Sure enough, about an hour after I left, girl with blonde hair came in. Kenna introduced her to Cody saying, this is Shay. Can you say Shay? And Cody responded with his usual may. It was actually adorable seeing him try to pronounce her name. I felt silly for being so Paranoid and decided to take the camera down. When I got home, I forgot about the camera and the next day while I was at work, I decided to check again. I wanted to see my boyfriend playing with our sweet Cody and text him I loved him. He was on the couch with Cody and I smiled watching them together. Then I heard it. May Cody said, reaching his arms up. That's right, buddy, he said.

Mercedes was doing 115 miles per hour when it flew past my hidden patrol car on the highway. Not just speeding, weaving through traffic like a video game, forcing a minivan with a baby on board sticker to swerve onto the shoulder. This wasn't reckless driving anymore. This was attempted murder on wheels. When I finally got him stopped after a three mile pursuit, the driver was already on his phone. Dad, I need you to handle something now. How? He looked at me through designer sunglasses with pure disgust. You have no idea who you just pulled over. Rookie, 23 years old, reeking of alcohol at two PM on a Tuesday. When I asked for his license, he laughed. Call Chief Morrison. Tell him you pulled over his son. This conversation will be over in 30 seconds and you'll be directing traffic at elementary schools for the rest of your career. Chief Morrison, my boss's boss's boss. The man who controlled every promotion, every assignment, every career in our department. His son Tyler Morrison was legendary among cops, untouchable. D U. I s disappeared. Assault charges vanished. Even that hit and run last year somehow became a misunderstanding. Sir, I need you to step out for a field sobriety test. Are you seriously this stupid? He held up his phone showing me his father's contact. One call. One call. Your badge goes in the trash tomorrow. I've gotten 12 cops fired or transferred, 12. Their families couldn't pay their Mortgages because they thought they were heroes. My body cam was recording everything. But body cam footage had mysteriously disappeared before when Tyler was involved. I thought about my daughter's college fund, my wife's medical bills, my mortgage. Then I smelled it. Marijuana smoke, but something else. Chemical, burnt plastic. I looked in the back seat and my blood froze. Clear plastic bags with blue crystals. Not just possession amounts, distribution weight, federal prison weight. That's not mine, he said. Instantly, his arrogance finally cracking. Someone planted that. You planted that. This is a setup. I called for backup, typically requesting internal affairs and state police, not local backup. Tyler went pale. Wait, wait, wait. We can work this out. My dad has connections you could make detective tomorrow, lieutenant, by 30. Just let me make one call. While searching the vehicle, I found something that made my hands shake. Department issued radio, an actual police badge, not fake, but reported stolen eight months ago. And worst of all, a Manila envelope with photos of three female officers, soccer photos taken at their homes through windows. Officer Patricia Chen was one of them. She filed multiple harassment complaints against an unknown stalker after refusing Tyler's advances at a department Christmas party. She requested transfers three times, been denied three times. State police arrived first. As they cuffed Tyler, he screamed at me. You're done. My father owns the city. Your kids will grow up without a father because you'll never Work again. One hour later, Chief Morrison himself showed up, face purple with rage. He pulled me aside, body cam still rolling.

My gross dad started dating a girl younger than me. So I started dating a guy older than him. See how he likes it? I'm 22 and my dad is 48. Last year after my parents divorced, he started dating this 20 year old girl named Becca. Yes, she's literally two years younger than me. Disgusting, right? At first I thought it was just some midlife crisis fling. But then he started bringing her to family dinners and introducing her as his girlfriend. She'd sit there giggling at everything he said while I'm sitting across from them wanting to throw up. The worst part was watching my dad act like some teenage boy around her, buying her jewelry and taking her on fancy trips while my mom was still fighting for alimony money. Who would even try to give me advice about college and my dating life. Like, girl, you literally just graduated high school two years ago. She'd be like, oh, honey, you should totally try this new face mask I saw on TikTok while I'm thinking about how she's closer to my age than my dad's. The breaking point came when my dad announced they were moving in together. He called a family meeting with me and my little brother to tell us Becca would be around more often. My 16 year old brother just stared at his phone the whole time while I sat there fuming. That's when I decided to give my dad a taste of His own medicine. I started scrolling through dating apps, specifically looking for older guys. I found this 55 year old guy named Robert who owns a construction company. He's divorced, has kids older than me, but he's actually pretty cool and treats me well. Plus he looks way better than my dad, even though he's older. I started bringing Robert to family events. The look on my dad's face when I introduced my boyfriend at my cousin's birthday party was priceless. Robert showed up in his nice truck wearing a button down shirt, shook my dad's hand firmly and started talking about his business and his two kids who are 24 and 26. My dad kept shooting me these confused looks all night. Becca kept whispering to him, asking if Robert was really my boyfriend. Robert was being super.

My mom's birthday party. My aunt looked at me and asked, why does your online boyfriend's voice sound exactly like your cousin Brett? I nearly dropped my plastic cup of punch. What? That's. That doesn't make any sense. My laugh came out high and strained, nothing like my normal laugh. Aunt Sue stood there with her perfectly plucked eyebrows raised, holding her phone like evidence in a courtroom. I heard you on a video call when I went upstairs to get my purse earlier. That was definitely Brett's voice, honey. My stomach turned violently. Across the room, Brett suddenly became fascinated with rearranging the birthday presents on the gift table, his shoulders tensing in that cowardly way I'd seen a thousand times at family gal. The tissue paper crinkled loudly in the sudden quiet that had fallen over our corner of the living room. You're confused, I said, forcing my voice to stay steady even as bile rose in my throat. Wade lives in Seattle. Breath. Literally right there. I gestured toward my cousin, who still wouldn't turn around, his pathetic hands fumbling with a bow that definitely didn't need adjusting. The relatives nearby had stopped their conversations mid sentence. My mom's best friend Pearl was frozen with a chip halfway to the spinach dip. Even my little nephew had stopped playing with his tablet to stare at us. Aunt Sue pulled out her phone with a determination of someone about to destroy my entire world. I recorded it because It was so strange. Listen. She hit lay, and Brett's voice filled the space between us, unmistakable and intimate. I can't wait to see you again, baby. Last night's call was amazing. I thought I might vomit right there on my mother's carpet. My entire body went cold, then hot, then cold again. I stared across the room at Brett, who had given up all pretense of gift arranging and stood perfectly still, his back to me, like the coward he was. That's no, I whispered, my mind racing through 18 months of photos, videos, late night calls where I'd whispered my deepest secrets. Wade sent me pictures, videos of his apartment, his cat, his. Brett's really good at that face swap app stuff. My brother interrupted, setting down his beer with a soft. Remember when he made that fake dating profile to catfish? That guy who bullied him in high school? The room started spinning. My cousin looked up from her phone, her face dawning with horrible realization. My God. Brett asked me for photos of random guys from my college last year. Said it was for a graphic design project. The puzzle pieces were clicking together with sickening precision, each revelation making me want to claw my own skin off. All those times Brett had asked about Wade, offered relationship advice. Seemed to know exactly what to say when I was sobbing about my long distance relationship. Brett always knew when you and Wade had fights. Before you told anyone, my sister Grace added quietly, her voice carrying perfectly in the now silent room where even the background music seemed muted. He kept asking me about long distance relationship tips, my other cousin said, looking between Brett and me with growing horror. Said it was for a friend who was too shy to ask. I walked across the room on shaking legs, my body feeling like it might collapse at any second. Each step felt like walking through broken glass. Brett still wouldn't turn around. The spineless piece of garbage you've been, Wade, this whole time. His voice came out, strangled, desperate, disgusting. It started as a joke. A joke. The word ripped from my throat. I told Wade everything. My panic attacks, the night I wanted to die. The therapy I couldn't afford. Those photos I sent when I trusted. I couldn't finish. My cousin had seen intimate photos meant for someone I loved. Someone who didn't exist. The entire party had gone silent except for someone's phone still playing Happy Birthday music from an earlier video. 23 family members stood frozen, witnessing my complete humiliation. I remember when Wade and I thought about him. Never want

What's the most entitled thing someone did that completely backfired? Picture this. I'm at my lemonade stand, just trying to raise money for my dog's cancer surgery. I'm currently bawling my eyes out and my eight year old brain thinks I'm going to jail. All because some middle aged lady whose face is contorted like a plant's v. Zombie squash nut is screaming at me, your stand is illegal! I will have you arrested and put in jail! She ran her own skincare stand at the opposite end of the street and was mad. I was feeling her customers. I'm going for lunch until 2. Your stupid stand better be gone by the time I'm back or I'll get unreasonable. You don't wanna see me get unreasonable. She stormed off saying, see you at 2. I didn't wanna be arrested, so I started packing up, but my parents saw me. My dad rushed out, and when I explained, he got this look. By the time she's back, son, your stand will be selling lemonade so fast, Coca Cola won't be able to keep up. But she'll call the police, she can call the Pope, I don't care. A smile came across my face. You know what he added? I'll even have something special for her when she comes back. Called my mom out, whispered something in her ear, and got in his minivan and drove off. Mom's thumbs went nuclear on her phone and before I knew it, everyone I could Think of was suddenly pulling up near our driveway. The elderly lady from two doors down ran over. I'll take three cups. Actually, make it five. She shoved a 20 at me. Keep the change, sweetheart. For Max. My. My hands were shaking as I counted $20 from one person. Then my dad's best friend showed up with most of his kids soccer team still in their attire. Post match lemonade. The kids swarmed my stand. That's Deborah who sells that overpriced crap? One mom whispered. She screamed at you? I nodded. That absolute witch can't wait till she sees this. I kept pouring lemonade, my money jar filling up so fast I couldn't keep track. One hundred dollars, mom. I have a hundred dollars. Where did dad go? I asked. Remember? His car was gone. He'll be back soon, sweetie. He's gonna get something real special. Mom winked. Running inside every 5 minutes. New car is pulled up. Your mom texted our group chat. Can't believe Deborah did that. $150, mom. One fifty. I was bouncing. Now baby Max really would get a surgery. Clarks arrived with their twins. That Debra tried to sell me a fifty dollar miracle cream that was literally Cetaphil, Mrs. Clark said. Buying six cups. Been waiting for karma to get her. It's already one o'clock, someone said. One hour until she's back. Let's make her explode with rage. I was counting money when a familiar van pulled up. My heart. I jumped. The Door opened and my cousin Axel hopped out with my dad. Guess what, buddy? Dad grinned, pulling out another lemonade stand from the van. Axel setting up shop right next to you. All money still goes to Max. Two stands! I screamed. Axel high fived me as we set up his stand. When Deborah sees this, Axel started giggling. She was mad about one stand. Can't imagine what's gonna happen with two. Dad laughed.

Did your hardcore vegan daughter accidentally eat meat and love it? My 17 year old daughter Jade has been vegan for 3 years and I mean aggressively vegan. She once broke up with a guy because he ate a cheeseburger on their date. She named our chickens so we couldn't eat eggs. Last month, Jade got diagnosed with leukemia. The oncologist, doctor Gabe, is this serious, no nonsense guy. He sits us down and says very gravely, Jade needs to increase her protein intake immediately. Her body needs complete proteins to handle chemotherapy. Jade crosses her arms. I'm not eating animals. Find another way. Doctor Gabe blinks. Jade, this is life or death. You need at least eight, 80 grams of protein daily. Then I'll die with a clear conscience. The next week was like a sitcom from hell. My wife tried sneaking chicken broth into Jade's soup. Jade took one sip, spit it out and yelled, mom, this tastes like blood. I attempted hiding ground Turkey in her spaghetti sauce. She took one bite, ran to the bathroom and came back with a toothbrush. I need to scrub the death from my mouth. We brought in a nutritionist who suggested protein powder. Jade screamed, way protein? That's cow juice powder. You're trying to turn me into a dairy vampire. By week two, Jade had lost 8 pounds and Doctor Gabe was getting desperate. He tried reasoning with her. Jade, even plants want to live. You're still ending life, Jade. Gasped dramatically. Did you just compare a carrot to a cow? A carrot doesn't have feelings, Doctor Gabe, how do you know? Because carrots don't have faces. Then my wife had this brilliant idea. She went to this fancy vegan restaurant and explained the situation. The chef created these protein shakes that looked like green smoothies but were packed with pea protein, hemp hearts and spirulina. Jade drank them religiously, calling them her life force elixirs. Her protein levels shot up. But here's where it gets AB absolutely hilarious. Jade needed a minor surgery to insert her chemo port. When she woke up from anesthesia, she was completely loopy. The nurse brought her some chicken broth to help with no nausea. Still high as a kite, Jade took a big sip and went, mmm, this is the best vegetable broth ever. What kind of vegetables taste this good? My wife and I are dying trying not to laugh. The nurse whispers. Should I tell her? I shake my head frantically. Jade finishes the entire cup and asks for more. This magical vegetable juice is healing my soul. I can feel the plants giving me their energy. She drank three more cups before or the anesthesia wore off. When she finally came to her senses, she looked at the empty cups and asked, what was that amazing broth? The nurse trying to keep a straight face said, it was, um, special healing broth. I knew it. I could taste the life. Force vegetables are so generous, we never told her the truth about her magical vegetable juice. But the real comedy came during her second chemo session. Jade was so nauseous she couldn't keep anything down. The hospital served her this sad piece of grilled chicken. Jade stared at it for 10 minutes. Then she looked at me and whispered, dad, I think the chicken is judging me. Honey, it's dead. It can't judge you. But what if its spirit is watching? What if there's a chicken afterlife and I'm about to commit a hate crime? Finally, she picks up the fork, closes her eyes and takes a tiny bite. Then she opens her eyes wide and goes, oh, my god, what? What? It tastes like that magical healing broth from surgery. Why didn't anyone tell me this could taste this good? She devoured the entire piece in about 30 seconds, then immediately started crying. I'm a hypocrite. I'm a carnivore. I'm everything I hate. The chickens will never forgive me. The nurse walked in during this breakdown and Jade grabbed her arm. I ate a chicken. I'm a monster. Do you think it had a family? The nurse, bless her heart, just patted Jade's hand and said, honey, that chicken lived its best, best life so you could live yours. Jade sobbed harder. That's the most beautiful thing anyone's ever said to me. Three months later, Jade's in remission. She's still mostly vegan, but now she eats what she calls Medical meat twice a week. She convinced the animals are sacrificing themselves for her health. Last week, she was eating a Turkey sandwich and suddenly stopped mid bite. Thank you, Turkey. Your death was not in vain. Now she refers to me and my wife as her protein dealers and asks us to handle the dirty work. While she maintains plausible denialability, she still doesn't know about the magical vegetable juice incident.

Making it actually work out for you. I pretended to be my cousin, the substitute teacher for a day and accidentally got my dream job. I was 19, broke as hell and still waiting to hear back from community college. My cousin Tyler was a substitute teacher who sometimes paid me to drive him around since his car was trash. One Tuesday morning he calls me freaking out, dude, I just rear ended someone. I'm supposed to be at Westbrook Middle School in 20 minutes. If I miss another day, they'll cut me from their sub list. I was eating cereal in my pajamas. That sucks, man. Wait, he said, you still have my school ID from when you helped me move those boxes last month? Yeah. Why? I'm serious. Let's go. Pretend to be me. Take attendance. Keep them quiet. It's just study hall. I laughed. You're insane. Please. They won't even check. Most subs. Just sit there anyway. It's one period. Something about the desperation in his voice got to me, plus I needed money. I threw on Tyler's spare button down shirt that was way too big and drove to the school with his laminated badge. The front desk lady barely looked up. You must be the sub for Miss Peterson's class. Room 2, 13. Here's your clipboard. I walked down that hallway trying to look confident while my heart was pounding. The kids were loud but not crazy. I took attendance, reading names off the roster. When they asked where their teacher was, I said she had a family emergency and today was independent study. Can we work on homework, this girl asked. Absolutely, I said. Having no clue what else to tell them. For an hour, I just walked around pretending to supervise while they did whatever. Some kid asked me about math and I said I'd get back to him. Another wanted to use the bathroom and I let like 5 kids go because I didn't know the rules. Then the bell rang and a whole new group of kids walked in. Nobody had told me there were multiple periods. I panicked but tried to play it cool. Same routine, independent study day. The projector wasn't working, so sorry, no video today. I made them read silently and told them I'd be grading papers instead. I just stared at Tyler's lesson plan book trying to figure out what I was supposed to be doing. Third period came, then fourth. I was making it up as I went. When kids got too loud, I'd say stuff like, remember, this affects your participation grade, even though I had no idea how grading worked. During lunch, I hid in an empty classroom and texted Tyler updates. He kept saying, you're doing great, just get through the day. Fifth period, this kid asked me about the Revolutionary War assignment. I panicked and said, what do you think the most important battle was? Then I made them debate it. While I googled stuff on my phone under the desk. By 6th period, I was actually getting comfortable. These kids weren't that different from my little brother and his friends. I started a trivia game about random stuff, and they were actually into it. Then the assistant principal walked in my.
NA

Everything that's mine when my roommate asked me to move out. So I was living with this girl, Megan, who I thought was my friend. We've known each other since freshman year. And when she said she found this perfect apartment and wanted me to sign the lease with her, I jumped at it. Five months of splitting everything, 50 50, doing dishes like good little roommates, never fighting over anything. Then one random Tuesday, I get this text while I'm at my job at the campus bookstore. Hey, we need to talk when you get home. That's never good, right? So I'm driving back thinking maybe she wants to talk about whose turn it is to buy toilet paper or something stupid like that. But when I walk in, she's sitting on our couch with this weird serious face he starts with. So I've been thinking and I already know I'm screwed. She tells me she doesn't think living together is working out and that she already talked to our landlord about me moving out by January 1st. I'm just sitting there like, what the hell? Because we literally never fought. I paid my half of everything on time. I cleaned up after myself and I even bought all the good stuff for our place. But she's acting like I'm some nightmare roommate who's been making her life miserable. I don't argue because honestly, why would I want to live with someone who doesn't want me there? So I tell Her fine, I'll start looking for a new place. She seems relieved like she was expecting me to throw a fit or something. That night I'm lying in bed thinking about how I need to pack everything and that's when it hits me. I look around our apartment and realise I bought literally everything that makes it nice. The 50 inch TV mounted on the wall, mine, the leather couch were always watching Netflix on. I saved up three paychecks for that thing. The coffee maker, the good plates instead of paper ones, the router for our internet, even the freaking shower curtain. Next morning I tell Megan I'll be taking all my stuff when I move out. She just says okay, like it's no big deal. I don't think she really thought about what that meant. I spent the next two weeks apartment hunting and found this decent one bedroom across town. On moving day, I rented one of those big U Haul trucks because I knew I'd need it. Megan wasn't even home, which was probably for the best. I started with the obvious stuff like my clothes and my desk. Then I unplugged the TV and carefully took it down from the wall. I wrapped up the coffee maker, packed all the dishes I'd bought from target and loaded the couch onto the truck with help from my buddy Jake. The router was the last thing I grabbed. I unpacked all the Ethernet cables and took the Whole setup. As I'm walking out with it, I realized.

You ever wanted to slap your boyfriend's girl? Best friend? Tessa had been in my boyfriend's life since kindergarten. She called him babe in front of me, touched his arm during conversations and somehow always needed emotional support. At eleven PM, my boyfriend would insist she was like a sister, that I was being paranoid. Maybe I was, until I decided to surprise him with homemade lasagna after his study group. I used my spare key, expecting to find him exhausted over textbooks. Instead, I found Tessa curled up on his couch in one of his oversized shirts, the same shirt I bought him, watching Netflix like she owned the place. She didn't move when she saw me, just said he was in the shower and they were hanging out. Something in her tone made my stomach twist. When I asked about his shirt, she shrugged, claimed she'd spilled wine on hers and he'd offered. When my boyfriend emerged from the bathroom, hair damp, he froze seeing me there. Not happy. Surprise, guilt. He thought I was working late. I told him I'd finished early and wanted to surprise him, holding up the container, but he already had company. Tessa stretched dramatically and announced she should go, thanked him for listening about her breakup drama. Breakup drama. This was news to me. After she left, my boyfriend launched into explanations how Tessa was going through a rough patch, how she needed a friend, how I was being jealous over nothing. I pointed out she was practically naked in his apartment. He protested she was wearing a shirt. Would I rather he let her walk around covered in wine? The gaslighting was masterful, almost made me doubt what I'd seen. Two weeks later, I found her hair tie on his nightstand. When I confronted him, he had another perfect explanation. When I found her lip gloss in his bathroom, she'd been getting ready for a job interview. Every piece of evidence had a logical explanation that made me feel crazy. The breaking point came during my birthday dinner. Halfway through appetizers, his phone buzzed. Tessa was having a panic attack. He needed to go check on her. I asked if it had to be now, watching my birthday candles flicker. Couldn't someone else help her? She only trusted him. He said, already standing, he'd be back in an hour. He never came back. I sat with our friends making excuses until the restaurant closed. When he finally called at midnight, Tessa had needed him to stay overnight on my birthday. That's when I realized the truth. I wasn't his girlfriend. I was the other woman in his relationship with Tessa. The next morning, I showed up at his apartment with all his belongings and garbage bags. As I answered the door in his shirt again, she said smugly that he wasn't there, but she could take the bags for him. I pushed past her, explaining I was actually there for her. What I found confirm.

Last week I took my grandchildren to a restaurant. My 8 year old grandson asked if he could say Grace. As we bowed our heads, he said, god is good, god is great. Thank you for the food. And I would thank you even more if grandpa gets us ice cream for dessert. And liberty and justice for all. Amen. Along with the laughter from the other customers nearby, I heard a woman remark, that's what's wrong with parenting these days. Kids today don't even know how to pray. Asking god for ice cream, why I never hearing this, my grandson burst into tears and asked me, did I do it wrong? Is god mad at me? So after I assured him that he had done a terrific job and that god was certainly not mad at him, an elderly gentleman approached the table. He winked at my grandson and said, I happen to know that god thought that was a great prayer. Really? My grandson asked, cross my heart, the man replied. Then in a theatrical whisper, he added, indicating the woman whose remark had started this whole thing, too bad she never asks god for ice cream. A little ice cream is sometimes good for the soul. Naturally, I bought my grandchildren ice cream. At the end of the meal, my grandson stared at his ice cream for a moment and then he did something I will remember the rest of my life. He picked up his sundae. And without a word, walked over and placed it in front of the woman. With a big smile, he told her, here, this is for you. Shove it up your ass, you grouchy old bitch.
NA

Therapist here, what was your biggest, I'm not supposed to judge, but holy shit moment I had this teenage boy, 15, who was referred to me for anger issues. That's what the school called it, anger said he snapped at teachers through a chair once, barely spoke to anyone, always wore a hoodie with the drawstring tight so you couldn't see his face. They wanted to expel him, but some one on staff suggested therapy first. I agreed to take him. First few sessions he just stared at the floor, shrugged a lot. I asked him his name, it's whatever that was his answer for most things. But he kept showing up, always on time, always quiet. I noticed he never sat with his back to the door, always chose the corner. That's not nothing. So one day I said, look, you don't have to talk, but I'm gonna talk and you can interrupt if I'm wrong. I started guessing. People say you're angry, but I don't think you are. I think you're scared. I think something happened and you're still living inside it still no reaction. Then I left a deck of cards on the table, not normal cards, but this trauma therapy set. It has pictures instead of words. I told him pick one that feels like your day yesterday. He picked the card with a shattered window, didn't say anything, just set it down and waited. Next week he picked the same one week after that, a Drawing of a wolf with blood on its teeth. I didn't push. I just started saying things like some, sometimes the person who hurt you lives in your house. And he looked up just for a second. That was the first time he made eye contact. Few weeks go by. He starts telling me tiny things, not about him, about this dog he used to have named Max, Black Lab. Said Max would sit outside his bedroom door every night like a guard. I asked, why did Max need to guard your door? And he went silent again. But next week he.
NA

What did your child say in court that saved someone's life? The first time she opened her mouth in court, I didn't expect her words to stop a sentencing. We were packed into that courthouse like sardines. The walls felt too close, the benches too hard and my heartbeat too loud. My daughter, Olivia, just 8 years old, sat beside me, swinging her feet. She looked so small in that big room. Her Sunday dress too formal. Her hair and braids I'd redone three times that morning just to keep my hands busy. Across the aisle sat the man who had taken everything from us. He was just 20, a kid, really. He didn't look dangerous, just tired, like he hadn't slept since the night he pulled the trigger. But I didn't care how tired he looked. My husband was gone and he was still breathing. The widow of the store clerk, my husband's boss, sat silently, her eyes hollow. Next to her was her son, maybe 10, clinging to her arm. I wanted to reach for Olivia's hand, but she was busy twisting the edge of the paper heart she'd made that morning, the one I didn't have the strength to ask about. The prosecutor spoke first, cold, clinical. The victim was an innocent man, a father, a husband. This was a violent, senseless act. Then came the defense. They talked about his upbringing, broken home, drug addicted mother, foster care. They showed pictures of his bruises, his grades. His attempts at rehab. This doesn't excuse the crime, his lawyer said, but we asked the court to consider who he was before he picked up the gun. I hated how calm they all sounded, how measured, like this was just another case. The judge asked if anyone else wished to speak. I felt the weight of the room tilt toward me. Everyone expected the grieving wife to stand, but I couldn't. I'd written 10 different versions of a statement and tore up every single one. The only thing I wanted to say was give me my husband back. And that wasn't an option. Then Olivia raised her hand. I didn't even realize what she was doing until she was already standing, walking to the front like it was show and tell. The courtroom murmured. The bailiff looked to the judge, who gave a small nod. And just like that, my daughter stood before the man who murdered her father. My name is Olivia, she said. Her voice small but steady.

I lost weight before my sister's wedding. My sister Emma had been planning her wedding for two years and I was supposed to be her maid of honor. She kept dropping hints about how all the bridesmaids needed to look cohesive in the photos and how important it was for everyone to put their best foot forward for her big day. Look, I'm not stupid. I knew what she was getting at. I gained about 40 pounds over the past few years since I started working from home. Emma never said it directly, but every time we talked about the wedding, she'd mention some diet she saw on Instagram or asked if I was getting ready for the wedding season. The breaking point came three months before the wedding when we went dress shopping. I tried on the bridesmaid dress in my size and Emma just stared at me in the mirror with this tight smile. She asked if maybe we should size up for comfort and then suggested I might wanna start doing some pre wedding prep with her. That weekend she texted me a link to some fitness app and said, thought this might help with your confidence for the big day. I screenshot that text and sent it to my boyfriend Tyler who said she was being a total bitch. But I decided I'd show her. I downloaded my fitness pal that night and started tracking everything. I cut out all the late night snacking, stopped getting Coffee with extra syrup and started walking to the grocery store instead of driving. I wasn't trying to do anything extreme. I just wanted to lose enough weight that Emma couldn't make her little comments anymore. The first month, I lost 12 pounds. I noticed right away when we met for brunch and kept asking what I was doing differently. I told her I was just eating better. And she got this weird look on her face like she didn't expect me to actually do anything about it. By month two, I was down 25 pounds and feeling amazing. I bought new jeans that actually fit.

My husband ignored me until he got mistaken for my boy best friend. I've given up on even trying to mention our anniversary. That's how many times my husband, Landon, had forgotten about it. But this year, his sister must have said something because two weeks after our missed anniversary, he insisted we should go to the Italian place where we had our first date. He didn't apologize or acknowledge what day we were supposedly celebrating. He just made a reservation and told me to wear something nice. We sat down at the same table where I patiently waited for him to arrive. During the last three years, every time he told me he couldn't make it due to work, I'd even grown close with the staff because they all joked about my ghost husband who was never here. Katie. Oh, my goodness. Llama, the waitress, gasped with delight. You actually brought someone, she beamed at me, then turned to Landon with warm approval. I'm so glad she finally took my advice about bringing a friend instead of waiting. Landon glanced out, confused, but llama was already pouring water, gushing at me. Three years of sitting alone on your anniversary and you finally decided to move on. Good for you, honey, she winked at Landon. You must be the coworker she mentioned, the one who actually remembered her promotion. Landon's brow furrowed as llama continued. Make sure to order the good wine tonight. She always gets the house red since She's paying alone. She patted my shoulder sympathetically before walking away, leaving Landon staring at me. What was that about? He asked. But I just looked at the menu, my chest tightening with three years of humiliation. The bartender walked by and did a double take. Llama is that, he gestured at our table. Llama nodded excitedly. Yep, she finally brought a date. No more Phantom Husband stories. The bartender laughed about time. Three years of he's running late got depressing. They weren't even being quiet. Landon's face was changing. His phone low. Bring to the table, Phantom husband, he said slowly. A bus boy clearing nearby tables chimed in. Yeah, the lady who cries into her tiramisu. Every year we take bets on whether a guy will actually show up. Landon's jaw tightened. The sommelier approached with genuine enthusiasm. Ma'am, since you have actual company tonight, might I suggest a real bottle? Not like when you nurse a single glass. For hours, Landon was completely still now, watching the staff treat him like my savior while discussing my abandoned anniversaries, I remembered how alone I felt whenever I came here, how I'd wish that Landon would bring me a gift and pick me up in his car, but he'd always let me down. Llama returned with her notepad, still glowing with approval at Landon. You know, sir, she orders the same thing every anniversary, a Butternut squash ravioli. Her husband apparently loved it on their first date here. Landon Was starting to squeeze his knuckles, realizing how badly he'd been ignoring his wife. She even brought him a gift once llama continued talking to him like they were conspirators, a Rolex. It sat wrapped on this table for four hours. She shook her head. Can you imagine forgetting your wife exists for three straight years? The sous chef passed by and called out, hey, is that the anniversary lady finally got smart and brought real company. Lama nodded proudly. Someone who actually shows up. Landon's breathing was getting shallow. I'm not, he started, but Lama was already taking my order. The usual honey and.

What nickname seems sweet as a kid, but hit different when you got older. So growing up, everyone in my family called me mittens. My mom, dad, both brothers, even my grandma. It was constant, mittens, come eat, mittens, clean your room. Where's mittens? I just assumed it was a quirky little pet name. I mean, I liked cats, and I had tiny hands as a kid, so I figured it was something sweet about that. I even had a onesie with cat mittens sewn on it that I wore into elementary school. My lunch box said mittens. Had no reason to question it. It was just me. The nickname stuck all through childhood and into my teens. Teachers at parent night would call me mittens because that's what my parents wrote on my lunch containers. I didn't mind. I thought it was unique. At sleepovers, my friends would tease me about it, but I just shrugged it off. It's just what my family calls me. But deep down, I always kind of wondered why. There was no origin story, no cute moment that kicked it off. I just. Always been. I remember one day in seventh grade, my older brother brought a friend over, and the friend heard my mom call out, mittens, dinner! He paused and asked my brother, why do you call her that? My brother just grinned and said, it's a long story. Then they both started laughing. I was like, what? What's funny? But they Waved me off. Nothing. It's just a cute name. I dropped it, but it stuck in my head for years. Fast forward to high school. I'm a sophomore, and we're doing this icebreaker activity in Spanish class where we have to share our childhood nicknames and what they meant. I proudly told the class that mine was mittens and that it was because I had little hands and liked cats. That's when this kid, Tyler in the back, snorted and whispered something to the guy next to him. The teacher didn't hear, but I did. Bet she doesn't know what that really means. It bothered me all day. I went home and googled it. Nothing came up except, well, actual mittens. No. It stirred something in me. I started casually asking family members about the nickname. Everyone deflected. My mom said, you were just such a cozy baby. And my grandma said, your hands were so warm. But my brothers would exchange these smug looks and crack up when I brought it up. Then two Christmases ago, I finally found out. I was 24 and home for the holidays. We were doing our usual gift exchange. I got a big box from my dad. Inside, a brand new pair of fuzzy mittens with a note that just said full circle. Everyone burst out laughing. I smiled awkwardly and asked, okay, seriously, what's the deal with this nickname? My dad held up his hands like, okay, okay. It's time you knew. And my mom covered her face already laughing. So apparently, when I was a Newborn, I had this weird obsession with my hands. Always be chewing on them, sucking my fingers to the point where they were red and raw. They tried giving me pacifiers, teething rings. Nothing worked. But what did work? Putting baby mittens on me. Except I hated them. I would scream and cry and throw full tantrums trying to pull them off. One night, they caught it on video. Me in my crib, growling like a gremlin, struggling to yank off the mittens. But here's the thing. I'd only managed to pull one off. Then I'd stare.

Why is the McDonald's ice cream machine always broken? My first week at McDonald's, I kept having to tell customers our ice cream machine was broken, so I did what nobody else would. Their faces would drop every single time, especially the kids who just wanted a cone or Mcflurry after their Happy Meal. It had been broken for two months, according to my coworkers, who just shrugged and said that's how it always was. I used to makes equipment at my uncle's restaurant all the time. Fryers and drink machines and even some refrigeration units. So when it was slow on a Tuesday afternoon, I decided to take a look at the ice cream machine. Manager Karen was off that day, and the shift supervisor told me to go for it if I thought I could help. The machine wasn't that complicated once I got the panels off. The main issue was a clogged valve and some sensors that needed cleaning. Years of dried milk product had gunked up the works. I spent three hours taking it apart piece by piece and cleaning everything with the approved sanitizer. My coworkers started gathering around as I worked. Kaylee, who had been there five years, said she'd never seen anyone even try to fix it. Jason started taking bets on whether I'd get it working. Even some customers at the counter were watching and cheering me on like I was performing surgery. When I finally got everything back together and hit The power button. The machine hummed to life. The display showed all green lights for the first time in months. I ran a test patch, and out came perfect soft serve vanilla ice cream. The whole crew erupted in cheers and applause. Words spread fast through the restaurant. Customers who had been turned away earlier came back for ice cream. We sold more cones and Mcflurries in two hours than the store usually sold in a week. Everyone was so happy. Kids were getting their desserts, and employ employees didn't have to deal with disappointed customers anymore. I felt like a hero, honestly. My coworkers kept patting me on the back and saying I should get a raise. One older lady bought an extra cone just to thank me for fixing it. The shift supervisor even let me take an extra break as a reward. I went home that night feeling proud of taking initiative and solving a problem that had been plaguing the store. The next morning, I walked in to find Karen waiting for me in the office. She. I had this look on her face, like I'd burned down the building. Before I could even clock in, she handed me a termination notice dated two weeks out. I stood there confused, trying to understand what I was reading. You tampered with the ice cream machine, she said in this cold voice. I tried explaining that I fixed it and customers were happy and we were selling ice Cream again. She cut me off and pulled out this thick manual. Turns out McDonald's
