Friend said I share too much about my feelings, so I stopped sharing anything at all. Jess came over to my place Friday night and I could tell something was bothering her by the way she kept sighing. You know what Britney told me today? She said flopping down on my couch. Her boyfriend is so mysterious and she's obsessed with him. Meanwhile, you texted me 12 times about being nervous for your presentation. The way she said it made me feel like I was some kind of burden. I wish you were more mysterious, more of a challenge. I should have known this would end badly when three weeks later she'd be crying at my door. But that night I just felt hurt and said, fine, I'll be mysterious that night. I usually would have texted her goodnight, but I didn't and it felt wrong not doing it. She sent me three question marks right away and I just wrote back, all good and left it at that. Saturday morning came and normally I text her about my coffee and ask what she was up to, but I kept my phone in my pocket. By noon, she was texting you okay and I just sent a thumbs up, which killed me because I actually wanted to talk to her. Monday was the worst because I got the promotion I've been working for and all I wanted was to call her and celebrate. When we went to dinner that night, She asked about my day and I just said same old while scrolling through my phone, even though inside I was bursting to tell her. She leaned across the table trying to figure out what was going on with me. You seem different, she said. Good, different. And the crazy part was she seemed more into me than she had in months, which made me feel powerful but also completely hollow inside. The second week, she started showing up at my place without calling first and cooking these fancy dinners, basically doing anything to crack me open. I can't figure you out anymore, she said. Wednesday night and she sounded excited about it. Britney so jealous. She as I got the mysterious boyfriend Jackpot. I wanted to tell her how dumb this whole thing was and how much I missed just talking to her normally, but I just shrugged and kept watching TV. my dad called because my mom was in the hospital for minor surgery and he was freaking out. I spent three hours calming him down while Jess sat next to me trying to figure out what was happening. After I hung up, she asked, is everything okay? And I wanted to fall into her arms and tell her everything, family, stuff. I said instead, it's handled. She killed me harder than she had in months and whispered, you're so strong. But I wasn't strong at all. I was just pretending. The third, Thursday night at eleven, PM Jess showed up at my door with her makeup running down her face, shaking.
NA

Dads, how did your child UNO reverse your rules? I thought I was being a clever parent when my 12 year old daughter Piper kept complaining about our two hour daily screen time limit. She'd constantly argue that all her friends got unlimited gaming time and that two hours wasn't enough to properly raid with her guild in Final Fantasy 14th. Instead of just saying no or caving to her demands, I decided to create an innovative system that would teach her about time management and delayed gratification. Spent an entire Sunday afternoon crafting what I called the screen time banking system. The concept was simple but brilliant. Piper could earn extra screen time minutes by reading books. For every page she read, she'd earn one minute of gaming time that she could bank for the weekend. Even created a fancy spreadsheet where she could log her reading and track her accumulated minutes. Picture books didn't count. They had to be proper chapter books at her reading level. Piper's eyes narrowed as I explained the system, and I could practically see the gears turning in her head. She asked a few clarifying questions about whether manga counted, no, if she could read multiple books at once, yes, and if there was a maximum she could bank. I foolishly said no. We shook on it, and I mentally patted myself on the back for encouraging reading while still allowing her gaming hobby. The first few days were incredible. who usually Had to be dragged to do her assigned reading for school. Suddenly turned into a bookworm. I'd find her reading at breakfast, during car rides, and even walking between classes. According to her teachers, she devoured the entire Percy Jackson series in five days. Her English teacher emailed me to say how impressed she was with Piper's sudden enthusiasm for literature. By the end of the first week, Piper had logged over 2,000 pages. I was thrilled. Sure, she'd earned about 33 hours of extra weekend screen time, but she'd also read more in one week than she had in the previous three months combined. I shared my success story in the Parent WhatsApp group, and several moms asked for the details to try with their own kids. Second week, Piper's reading intensified. She discovered that our library had a massive collection of graphic novels that, while not manga, technically counted as proper chapter books at her reading level. She plowed through the entire amulet series, all of smile and its sequels, and made a significant dent in the Dog Man collection. Her page count was astronomical because graphic novels have way more page numbers despite being mostly pictures. Friday evening of week two, Piper presented me with her spreadsheet. She had logged 8 347 pages over two weeks. That translated to roughly 139 hours of banked screen time. She informed me, very matter of factually, that she intended to use it all that weekend for a massive Final Fantasy 14th gaming Marathon with her guild, who was attempting some world first raid completion. I laughed and said that was impossible. She couldn't physically stay awake for 139 hours straight. That's when Piper pulled out her second spreadsheet. She calculated that if she gained for 16 hours a day, with breaks for meals and bathroom, she could use 48 hours per weekend. At that rate, her current bank would last her three weekends, and she planned to maintain a sustainable reading pace of about 1,000 pages per week to keep her weekends fully stocked with gaming time. I tried to argue that this wasn't the spirit of the agreement, but Piper calmly pointed out that I'd said there was no maximum banking limit and that the goal was to encourage reading, which had clearly worked.

Happened when someone refused to take your life saving advice. I told a teenage girl she was gonna get assaulted working the night shift at a truck stop and she kicked me out for harassment. I've been driving trucks for 12 years now and I've seen people, men especially at their darkest late at night on the road. I started driving trucks after my daughter was born because it paid better than warehouse work. My route takes me from Dallas up through Arkansas and into Tennessee. There's this one gas station that I try to avoid like a plague. It's one of those places where the parking lot lights are half broken and there's always sketchy stuff going down. Some nightmare on Elm Street shite. Last time I was there some tweaker tried to sell me a chainsaw at 3 in the morning. But sometimes you need gas and it's the only stop for 40 miles. This happened about six months ago. I pulled in around 11 at night and noticed something was different right away. The old guy who usually work nights wasn't behind the counter. Instead there was this young girl who couldn't have been older than 19. She had bright purple hair and enough piercings to make her head explode in an MRI, full sleeve, tattoos on both arms too. She was reading a textbook when I walked in so I figured she was a student. I grabbed an energy drink and some beef jerky and went Up to pay? You new here, I asked while she rang me up. Yeah, started last week, she said, without looking up from scanning. They had a help wanted sign in the hour. Work with my class schedule. My stomach dropped a little. This girl had no idea what she'd signed up for. So I told her very respectfully, listen, I don't mean to pry, but you might want to find somewhere else to work. This place gets rough, especially at night. She finally looked up at me and her face went hard. I can take care of myself, thanks. That annoyed me a little, but I needed her to understand. I'm sure you can, but the drivers that come through here aren't your average cost. Some of these guys have been on the road for days straight. They get weird ideas in their heads, especially when they see a young woman working alone. Is that supposed to be a threat? Her voice got sharp. No, I'm trying to warn you. I've been stopping here for years and I've seen some bad stuff go down. You need to at least keep some heat under the counter for Protection. Get out. She pointed at the door. I don't need some random trucker man explaining danger to me. I, but I can handle myself. I don't even know what mansplaining is. I said, look, I have a daughter about your age and I'd want someone to tell her before I could even Say anything else, she screamed out, before I call the cops and report you for harassment. I held up my hands and backed away. Fine, I tried. Some people just won't listen when you're trying to help them. I paid for my stuff and left without another word. Back in my truck, I popped open the energy drink and did my usual safety check. Tires looked good. Load was cure. I was just about to pull out when I remembered I'd promised my wife I'd grab diapers on the way home. My wife just had another baby girl. She goes through them like crazy and we were almost out. I sat there for a minute debating whether to go back in. The girl clearly didn't want me there, but I really needed those diapers. I waited about five minutes to let things cool down, then headed back inside. The store was empty. That purple haired girl behind the counter, I hoped for the best and told myself maybe she was in the bathroom or on break. Then I heard.

Food delivery driver asked me, ma'am, are you alone right now? My husband's on the way home. I lied immediately, feeling nervous from his question. The delivery driver held my Chinese food, peeking into my house. What does your husband look like? He asked. Sorry, listen, I have a movie to catch. Here's an extra tip. I pushed a five dollar Bill at him and reached for my food. What does he look like? He pressed more desperately, his tone making all the hair on the back of my neck stand up straight. I grabbed my food and practically slammed the door in his face before turning the dead bolt. Now, I know weird people deliver food all the time, but I wasn't ready to become a true crime story that people will make YouTube videos about. But 20 minutes later, just as I'd forgotten all about him, I walked into the kitchen to get some ice cream and noticed that his car was still parked on the street with the engine running. When his eyes met mine through the window, I closed the blinds in a panic and fell to the floor, covering my mouth. My phone buzzed with text from an unknown number. This is your delivery driver. Where is your husband? Are you still by yourself right now? I didn't respond, but my hands were shaking. Another text came through immediately. Please answer, it's important. Through a crack in the blinds, I watched him get out of His car and walk back toward my house. The pounding of my heart filled my ears. I crawled around, turning off all the lights, closing all the blinds on the first floor. Then a third text. I'm outside. Two words that made my spine tingle. I heard his footsteps on my front porch, gently knocking like he didn't want to scare me even more than I already was. Annabelle, he said, voice calm and Mary. Annabelle, I know you're in there. Please come out. I couldn't take it anymore and figured if I threatened him with the cops, he'd leave. I stupidly opened the door just a crack with the chain still on. You need to leave or I'm calling the police. Before I could react, his hand shot through the gap and unhooked the chain. He grabbed my arm and dragged me out of my house. I tried to scream, but he was already throwing me into it.
NA
NA

The finding out was biblical. I show up to practice Thursday night at the regular time, and my three bandmates are sitting in a circle without their instruments like they're about to hold an intervention. Lead singer says we need to talk about the band's future. Battle of bands is in 10 days, and apparently we need. Need to level up our image. That's when I noticed the drummer's girlfriend standing in the corner holding a bass. My bass, actually, that I let him borrow last week. She's holding it upside down. Lead singer looks at me. Look, you're great and all, but she has the look we need. She's been learning bass for, like, two months. Two months? I've been carrying this band for three years. But sure, let's get the girl who thinks a bass has six strings. They vote 3 to 1 to replace me right there with me, watching like I'm getting voted off a reality show. The guitarist, who still can't play an F chord cleanly, actually says, it's nothing personal. Nobody's looking at the bassist anyway. Might as well have someone pretty back there. Nobody's looking at the bassist. I wrote half our songs, but okay, Brad, tell me more about how music works. The drummer's girlfriend tries to be nice. You can still come to the show if you want to support us. Support them. Sure. Let me buy a ticket to watch you play my bass badly. Sounds like a dream. Friday. Night. I don't argue, don't yell. Just say okay if that's what you all want. The lead singer seems surprised I'm not fighting back. Probably expected tears. Sorry to disappoint. They're already talking about keeping the band name and the set list for battle of bands. Acting like everything's normal. Planning tomorrow's practice like I was never even there. Like I'm already a ghost. Guitarist mentions they'll see me around and I just nod, give them a smile that doesn't reach my eyes, walk out quietly. I can hear them talking about stage positions as the door closes. How she'll look great in the back, how the judges will love having something nice to look at. They think this is over. They think I'm just going to crawl away and cry. That's cute. I'm sitting in my car in the driveway and my brain starts doing math. Tomorrow's practice. They kept saying see you at practice tomorrow to each other. But wait, that's my amp the guitarist uses because his sounds like a dying cat. My mixing board that makes our lead singer not sound like he's singing through a kazoo. The mic system I bought with birthday money. The cables, the stands, hell, even the extension cords are mine. I check the battle of bands registration on my phone. The song list they submitted. Breaking Chains I wrote that. Midnight Drive wrote that in my bedroom. Phoenix Rising? That's literally about my ex boyfriend. I have the notebooks with The original lyrics in my handwriting. The van we use for gigs. Mine. Well, technically my mom's, but she lets me use it. And then it hits me. This is my dad's garage. Dad only lets them practice here because of me. I text him, hey, the band just kicked me out for not being pretty enough. He text back immediately. Are you kidding me? They're banned. I'll change the garage code right now. My dad's the best. They kept saying, see you at practice tomorrow. They actually think they're still practicing here tomorrow. In my dad's garage, with my equipment, playing my songs. The delusion is actually impressive. Next day, five PM, I'm home.
NA

I changed my name because my parents named me Corstal. Crystal. My parents actually looked at a Newborn baby and thought, let's spell Crystal like we're trying to unlock a cheat code. For 18 years, I dealt with this disaster of a name that looked like someone sneezed while typing. Every first day of school was the same nightmare. Teachers would get to my name on the roll call and just stop, dead silence. Then they'd attempt some butchered pronunciation like curse style or quest illie. I'd have to raise my hand and say it's just crystal, but spelled like my parents hate me. The worst part wasn't even the pronunciation. It was the assumptions. People would see my name written down and immediately think I was some exotic foreign exchange student or that my family was super religious. I got asked if I was Muslim at least once a week. Random people would come up to me asking what country I was from or what language my name came from. I'd have to explain that, no, my parents just thought they were being creative when they were really just being cruel. My mom was the worst about it. She'd email every single teacher at the beginning of each, well, year with a whole paragraph about how to pronounce my name correctly and the cultural significance behind the spelling. There was no cultural significance. She just saw the name Crystal in a baby book and decided to make it look Fancy. When I was 15, I started telling people to just save my name as Crystal in their phones. It made everything easier. But my mom found out when she saw a text from my friend Jess that just said Crystal and she completely lost it. She grounded me for two weeks and made me write apology letters to all my friends explaining the proper way to spell my name. That's when I knew I was changing it. The second I turned 18, the day after my birthday, I marched down to the courthouse with all my paperwork. The clerk was super nice about it. She.
NA

What did your child say in court that saved someone's life? The first time she opened her mouth in court, I didn't expect her words to stop a sentencing. We were packed into that courthouse like sardines. The walls felt too close, the benches too hard and my heartbeat too loud. My daughter, Olivia, just 8 years old, sat beside me, swinging her feet. She looked so small in that big room. Her Sunday dress too formal. Her hair and braids I'd redone three times that morning just to keep my hands busy. Across the aisle sat the man who had taken everything from us. He was just 20, a kid, really. He didn't look dangerous, just tired, like he hadn't slept since the night he pulled the trigger. But I didn't care how tired he looked. My husband was gone and he was still breathing. The widow of the store clerk, my husband's boss, sat silently, her eyes hollow. Next to her was her son, maybe 10, clinging to her arm. I wanted to reach for Olivia's hand, but she was busy twisting the edge of the paper heart she'd made that morning, the one I didn't have the strength to ask about. The prosecutor spoke first, cold, clinical. The victim was an innocent man, a father, a husband. This was a violent, senseless act. Then came the defense. They talked about his upbringing, broken home, drug addicted mother, foster care. They showed pictures of his bruises, his grades. His attempts at rehab. This doesn't excuse the crime, his lawyer said, but we asked the court to consider who he was before he picked up the gun. I hated how calm they all sounded, how measured, like this was just another case. The judge asked if anyone else wished to speak. I felt the weight of the room tilt toward me. Everyone expected the grieving wife to stand, but I couldn't. I'd written 10 different versions of a statement and tore up every single one. The only thing I wanted to say was give me my husband back. And that wasn't an option. Then Olivia raised her hand. I didn't even realize what she was doing until she was already standing, walking to the front like it was show and tell. The courtroom murmured. The bailiff looked to the judge, who gave a small nod. And just like that, my daughter stood before the man who murdered her father. My name is Olivia, she said, her voice small.

My gross dad started dating a girl younger than me, so I started dating a guy older than him. See how he likes it? I'm 22 and my dad is 48. Last year after my parents divorced, he started dating this 20 year old girl named Becca. Yes! She's literally two years younger than me. Disgusting, right? At first I thought it was just some midlife crisis fling, but then he started bringing her to family dinners and introducing her as his girlfriend. She'd sit there giggling at everything he said while I'm sitting across from them wanting to throw up. The worst part was watching my dad act like some teenage boy around her, buying her jewelry and taking her on fancy trips while my mom was still fighting for alimony money. Who would even try to give me advice about college and my dating life? Like, girl, you literally just graduated high school two years ago. She'd be like, oh, honey, you should totally try this new face mask I saw on TikTok, while I'm thinking about how she's closer to my age than my dad's. The breaking point came when my dad announced they were moving in together. He called a family meeting with me and my little brother to tell us Becca would be around more often. My 16 year old brother just stared at his phone the whole time while I sat there fuming. That's when I decided to give my dad a taste of His own medicine. I started scrolling through dating apps, specifically looking for older guys. I found this 55 year old guy named Robert who owns a construction company. He's divorced, has kids older than me, but he's actually pretty cool and treats me well. Plus he looks way better than my dad, even though he's older. I started bringing Robert to family events. The look on my dad's face when I introduced my boyfriend at my cousin's birthday party was priceless. Robert showed up in his nice truck wearing a button down shirt, shook my dad's hand firmly, and started talking about his business and his two kids who are 24 and 26. My dad kept shooting me these confused looks all night. Becca kept whispering to him, asking if Robert was really my boyfriend. Robert was being super.

My graduation ceremony. My father looked confused and asked, why does the university have no record of the $75,000 I wired for your tuition? My heart stopped to see if graduation caps around us blurred as his words sank in. What do you mean? I whispered, clutching my diploma case tighter. Dad pulled out his phone, showing me a screenshot from the registrar's office stating I had no outstanding payments and had never received any wire transfers. My mother's face paled as she leaned over to see the email. The happy family streaming past us had no idea my world was collapsing. I sent $25,000 each year for three years that continue. His voice low but intense. Every transfer confirmed. Where did that money go if not to your education? I felt dizzy with confusion. I don't understand. I've been getting confirmation emails from you about payments going through. I fumbled for my phone, but as I scrolled through my inbox, the emails were gone. All financial communications with my father had vanished. Cold realization crept over me as I remembered who had access to my accounts. Tyler, I whispered, my boyfriend of two years who had helped me set up my student portal when we first started dating. The same boyfriend who mysteriously wasn't at my graduation today despite promising to attend. We drove straight to Tyler's apartment. The landlord confirmed what I already suspected. Tyler had moved out three days ago, leaving no forwarding address inside my car. I called the bank while dad paced outside. The customer service representative confirmed the devastating truth. Someone had created a dummy account mimicking university payment portals. Dad's money had been going to this account for three years with email confirmations automatically generated to both of us. I remembered how Tyler always insisted on handling my complicated financial aid situation because he'd been through the system before. My mother called the police. While dad and I drove to my apartment, Tyler's belongings were gone, along with my laptop, jewelry and the family heirloom watch my grandfather had given me. Detective Wilson asked detailed questions about Tyler's background. The truth was humiliating. I knew almost nothing concrete about him. The university he claimed to have graduated from had no record of him. The tech company he supposedly worked for remotely didn't exist. Family emergencies that regularly took him out of town were fabricated. For two years, I had been living with a complete stranger who had systematically stolen my family's money. The investigation revealed Tyler had created an elaborate network of accounts to receive dad's tuition payments, immediately transferring the money through multiple channels. The dummy website he created to mimic the university's payment portal was professionally designed.

Did you realize you raised your daughter right? My daughter Elia destroyed our neighbor's face with a baseball bat. I was in the middle of a work meeting when my phone lit up with a call from my neighbor, Roman. His voice was shaking with fury. Your daughter Elia is psychotic. She attacked me with a baseball bat. I was just checking on her like you asked, and she broke my effing nose. The cops are already here. My blood ran cold. Elia was a straight a student and had never been in a fight in her life. I ran to my car and started driving. The 20 minute drive home felt like hours. My mind racing through every possible scenario. Roman's words kept echoing in my head. Psychotic, attacked, broke my nose. What could have possibly happened? By the time I reached our driveway, my shirt was soaked with sweat. The scene that greeted me was even worse than I'd imagined. Police cruisers were parked outside with their lights flashing and half the neighborhood had gathered on their lawns to stare. Roman was on our front porch and was holding a towel to what was clearly a broken nose. His white polo shirt was stained red and he was gesturing wildly at two officers who were taking notes. She, he needs to be locked up, he was shouting. This is assault with a deadly weapon. I want charges pressed. Elia sat on our front lawn with her knees pulled To her chest, staring at the grass. She looked so small, so defeated. The female officer approached me as I got out of the car. Sir, your neighbor claims your daughter attacked him unprovoked with a baseball bat. If he presses charges, we're looking at aggravated assault. That could mean juvenile detention. My stomach dropped. Roman saw me and immediately started ranting, she's violent, unhinged. I was just checking on her like you asked, making sure she got home safe from school. And she came at me like a wild animal. Look at my face. My nose is broken. I might need surgery. The male officer showed me photos they taken of Roman's injuries. His nose was definitely broken, already starting to bruise. Your daughter hasn't said a word since we arrived, the officer said quietly. We need to know what happened here. I walked past Roman, ignoring his continued shouting about pressing charges and teaching violent children a lesson. Then I knelt down beside Elia on the grass and I put my hand on her shoulder. She flinched but didn't look up. Ella, sweetheart, I need you to tell me exactly what happened, every detail. She finally raised her head and I saw her eyes were red from crying. But there was something else there, too, anger, maybe even disgust. I was in my room, she said, her voice barely a whisper.

During our divorce hearing, my wife walked in six months pregnant, claiming it was mine and that I was abandoning my new family. Then I stood up and told the judge I had a vasectomy. Since 2,018, my wife Tara and I were married seven years. In 2,017, I was diagnosed with a genetic condition that causes progressive nerve damage, the same disease that put my father in a wheelchair by 50, with a 50% chance of passing it to children. I refused to risk condemning a child to my fate. Initially, Tara seemed supportive, but by March 2,018, she started leaving fertility clinic brochures around and making comments about how genetics aren't everything. The arguments escalated until July 2,018 when I discovered she'd been tampering with our birth control. Her browser history was full of searches like how to poke holes in condoms and how to get pregnant when husband doesn't want kids. Most disturbing was a forum post where someone suggested getting me drunk enough that I wouldn't notice if Protection wasn't used. I had replied, that might work. He rarely remembers details when he drinks whiskey. When I confronted her, she broke down crying saying I'd come around once a baby was on the way. She actually believed tricking me into fatherhood was helping me see what I really wanted. I called my doctor the next morning and scheduled a vasectomy. I didn't tell her I couldn't trust her anymore. The procedure happened in August 2,018. While She was visiting her sister. When she returned, she asked for a divorce. Can't waste my fertile years on someone who won't change his mind, she said coldly. But two months later, she wanted to reconcile. She showed up at my apartment with takeout and tears saying maybe she could accept a child free marriage. Suspicious but hopeful, I agreed to try counseling. For 10 months, things seemed better. Then in September 2,019, her phone kept buzzing while she was in the shower. The preview text from Mark W. Made my stomach drop. Miss you too, baby. Mark was her boss. Opening the messages revealed they'd been having an affair for over two years, starting before my diagnosis, continuing through our fertility fights and even through our reconciliation. She put me on hold while he was relocated to London. I filed for divorce the next day. Four months into the contentious meetings came the hearing for asset allocation. That's when I saw her walking down the courthouse hallway and my jaw nearly hit the floor. Tara was visibly pregnant, at least six months along. Her belly prominently displayed in a form fitting dress. She made deliberate eye contact, cradling her stomach with both hands, a triumphant smile on her lips. In court, her lawyer immediately addressed the pregnancy, claiming it significantly changed the fight financial considerations. He accused me of attempting to abandon my responsibilities to my unborn child. Tara dabbed her eyes with tissue. I just want what's best. For our baby, she said softly. The judge's expression grew cooler toward me. Mister Harmon, were you aware of this pregnancy? Before I could answer, her lawyer claimed I'd known about it during our reconciliation, saying my.

When did you have to choose between your children? I was shopping at Walmart when a kid asked me, sorry, ma'am, can you pretend to be my mom at my parent teacher meeting? I stared at him and he continued. It's just that my mom's an alcoholic and she never shows up. If she misses one more, they'll call CPS. My heart broke as he was almost crying, please, I'll do anything. If you have kids, you'll even take their test for them. He pulled out a crumpled report card showing straight A's. See, I get all A's. I'll do it. Well, I wiped his tears and asked him to tell me about himself. He sniffled before saying, I'm Mikey. I know I sound crazy right now, but if mom gets taken away, they'll separate me and my little sister. She's only 7. I can't let her be alone. I pulled him into a hug and gave him my number. That night, I stared at my son Merrick's progress report. Three F's, two. His dad had already threatened to pull him from the team if grades didn't improve. So I texted Mikey at 2:00am. Deal, but strictly business. You take his tests. I play your mom. We met at a Dunkin Donuts the next day to practice. Ask about my grades with concern but not panic. Mention you work two jobs so you can't help with homework much. I nodded, taking notes like this was a corporate presentation. The conference Is Thursday at three thirty PM bring tissues in case they mention my absences. He slid me his class schedule and disappeared. Thursday came fast. Mikey's teacher, Mrs. Yet, greeted me warmly. So wonderful to finally meet you, Mrs. Tyrel. Mikey talks about you constantly. I forced a smile, pulling out the tissues as instructed. I worry about him. The divorce has been hard and I work so much. I squeezed my hand. He's doing beautifully academically, but I do worry about his attendance. I dabbed my eyes perfectly. His father isn't reliable with pickups. I'm trying my best. The meeting lasted 12 minutes. Mikey waited by the exit, handed me merricks algebra test with an a minus circled in red, and we went our separate ways. I started leaving protein bars in random places. I knew he'd find them. He started adding small notes to merricks tests. Tell him the Lakers game was sick or he should try this equation method. By month 3, I knew his coffee order and he knew I parked in the back lot to avoid my ex. When teachers praised my son, I felt oddly proud. When he won the science fair, I clapped louder than necessary. Still, we kept our distance. Then came the call that shattered everything. Missus Tyrel.

What immediately tells you someone is a trashy parent? I was 12 when I threw my first real birthday party. My parents finally let me invite whoever I wanted, and I was so excited. I invited literally everyone in my class, even the quiet kids who usually got left out. One of those kids was Marcus. He never talked much, always wore the same t shirts, and ate alone at lunch. But when I handed him the invitation, his whole face just lit up. He said it would be his first real birthday party ever. The day arrived, and my backyard looked amazing. My dad set up games, strung lights everywhere, and built this elaborate obstacle course. My mom made this incredible three layer chocolate cake, and we had pizza, soda, candy stations. Kids started showing up, and everyone was having a blast. And Marcus arrived with his mom. She said hello, complimented the decorations, brought a small wrapped gift. Marcus was practically bouncing with excitement, running around trying to talk to everyone. I'd never seen him so happy in my entire life. But then I started noticing weird things. Marcus's mom kept walking around the party, picking up little items and examining them closely. She'd flip through my mom's magazines on the patio table, check out the brand names on our outdoor furniture. When my mom caught her, she'd just smile and say she was admiring our beautiful home. During the games, Marcus was finally coming out of his Shell. He was laughing, high fiving other kids, screaming with joy. During the water balloon toss, other kids were actually talking to him for once. His mom, though, kept checking her phone and walking around our yard with this strange intensity, like she was mapping out every corner of our property. When we moved inside for pizza, I caught her in our hallway, just standing there looking at family photos on wall. Just using the bathroom, she said. When she saw me, my mom started keeping a closer eye on her. After that, the party games continued, and Marcus was having the time of his life. He won the treasure hunt, nailed the limbo contest, and was finally acting like a normal kid. When we brought out the cake, Marcus practically glowed. All 15 kids gathered around, singing Happy Birthday, and I made my wish. As I was cutting the cake, Marcus's mom appeared right next to me. This is such a nice setup you have here, she said, her eyes scanning the presents table loaded with gift bags and wrapped boxes. You're so lucky to have all this nice stuff. Some kids don't get anything. I just nodded and kept cutting cake. After everyone finished eating, we moved to present time. My favourite part. Marcus sat right in front, watching me open everything with this amazed expression, like he couldn't believe he was really here experiencing a real birthday party. I was halfway through the pile when Marcus's mom Tapped my shoulder. Hey, sweetie, Marcus and I need to leave early. He has a doctor's appointment. I completely forgot about Marcus's face absolutely crumbled. Mom, no, the party's not over. You promised we could stay the whole time. Please, we have to go right now. Get your

I didn't let my sister see her kids. Back in 2,018, I got custody of my sister Emma's three kids after she left them alone for two weeks to go on what she called a vacation. The nine year old Caleb was basically raising his two little sisters, changing diapers and trying to feed them cereal for dinner. When the neighbors called the cops after hearing the baby crying for hours. Found Emma's drug stash under the couch and arrest warrants piling up on her kitchen counter. The kids were a mess when they came to live with me. Caleb had this haunted look, like he'd seen way too much for a seven year old. At the time, the middle one, Sophie, was four and kept asking when mommy was coming back. The baby, Grace, was only 3 months old and had diaper rash so bad it made me want to cry. The first few months were brutal. Caleb would wake up screaming from nightmares, and Sophie would hide food under her bed because she was scared there wouldn't be any tomorrow. I had to move them to a new school district, find new daycare, basically rebuild their entire world from scratch. My apartment wasn't ready for three kids, so I slept on the couch for months while they figured out sleeping arrangements. Caleb refused to sleep alone for the first year, so he'd camp out on the floor next to my couch with his blanket every single night. Emma Went to prison for child endangerment and drug possession. The whole family was furious with me for betraying her. But what was I supposed to do? Let those kids suffer? During her trial, she sat there crying about how I ruined her life, never once asking how the kids were doing. For six years, I've been mom, dad, homework helper, bedtime story reader, everything. Caleb Learned to ride a bike in my driveway. Sophie had her first day of kindergarten holding my hand. He took her first steps in my living room. These kids don't remember Emma as their mom anymore, because, honestly, she never really was one. Last month, Emma got out of prison early for good behavior. Her first call wasn't to apologize or ask how the kids were doing. She called demanding I bring them to see her immediately because she was ready to be a mother now. She actually said I could give them back like they were borrowed lawn equipment or something. I sat down with Caleb, who's 15 now, and asked what he wanted. He looked me dead in the eyes and said he never wanted to see her again. He remembered everything. The hunger, the fear. Having to take care of his sisters when Emma would disappear for days. Sophie, who's 10 now, barely remembers Emma at all. She calls me mom and has for years. Grace doesn't know Emma exists, and honestly, I've never brought her up. But my family won't let It go. My parents keep calling, saying I'm being cruel, that Emma deserves a second chance, that blood is thicker than water. My aunt even showed up at my house last week yelling about how I'm poisoning the kids against their real mother. She said it was my fault the little ones don't remember Emma because I never took them to visit her in prison. The thing is, I did try to maintain some connection at first. I sent Emma pictures and updates when she was locked up. She never responded. Not once. Never asked about birthdays, school plays, nothing. When Caleb broke his arm falling off his skateboard, I called the prison to let her know. She couldn't be bothered to call back. The kids are thriving now. Caleb made honor roll last semester and plays varsity soccer.

Dad pulled out his phone, showing me a screenshot from the registrar's office stating I had no outstanding payments and had never received any wire transfers. My mother's face paled as she leaned over to see the email. The happy family streaming past us had no idea my world was collapsing. I sent $25,000 each year for three years that continue. His voice low but intense. Every transfer confirmed. Where did that money go if not to your education? I felt dizzy with confusion. I don't understand. I've been getting confirmation emails from you about payments going through. I fumbled for my phone, but as I scrolled through my inbox, the emails were gone. All financial communications with my father had vanished. Cold realization crept over me as I remembered who had access to my accounts. Tyler, I whispered, my boyfriend of two years who had helped me set up my student portal when we first started dating. The same boyfriend who mysteriously wasn't at my graduation today despite promising to attend. We drove straight to Tyler's apartment. The landlord confirmed what I already suspected. Tyler had moved out three days ago, leaving no forwarding address inside my car. I called the bank while dad paced outside. The customer service representative confirmed the devastating truth. Someone had created a dummy account mimicking university payment portals. Dad's money had been going to this account for three years with email confirmations automatically generated to both of us. The university he claimed to have graduated from had no record of him. The tech company he supposedly worked for remotely didn't exist. Family emergencies that regularly took him out of town were fabricated. For two years, I had been living with a complete stranger who had systematically stolen my family's money. The investigation revealed Tyler had created an elaborate network of accounts to receive dad's tuition payments, immediately transferring the money through multiple channels. The dummy website he created to mimic the university's payment portal was professionally designed.

I was helping my eight year old foster daughter, Lily, into her pajamas when I asked, sweetie, how did you get these bruises on your arms? She pulled away from me quickly. Just playing at school. My stomach tightened because after three years of fostering, I knew that look. Lily, you can tell me anything. Was someone rough with you? No. Can I go to bed now? She practically ran to her room. Before I could follow, my phone buzzed with a text from my other foster son, Jason. Is Lily okay? She was crying in the bathroom earlier. Do you know if anyone's been bothering her? No, but she's been acting weird, like, really tired all the time. The next morning, the school nurse called while I was at work. Missus parks, I. We need to discuss Lily's injuries. She has bruising on her arms and what looks like scratches on her legs. My mouth went dry. She said it was from playing. She told me they happened at home. I'm required to document this. The threat hit me like ice water. They thought I was hurting her. I'll need to file a report with child services. Someone will be contacting you within 72 hours. After hanging up, I sat in my car shaking. Three foster kids under my roof, and now I was being investigated. They could take all of them away. That night, I watched everyone like a hawk. Jason was doing homework. My youngest foster daughter, Kia was colouring. Normal evening, except Lily kept nodding off at dinner. Didn't you sleep well? I asked. I had weird dreams, she mumbled into her Mac and cheese. What kind of dreams? She. I shrugged and asked to be excused two days until the home visit. I found pine needles in Lily's hair while braiding it, which made no sense since we lived in a suburban neighborhood with only oak trees. Are you playing in someone's yard? No, but her hands twisted her rabbit's ears nervously. Jason pulled me aside that night. Something's up with Lily's window. I followed him to her room, where she was already asleep. At seven PM. The window lock was loose and there were tiny scratches on the sill. My blood went cold. I installed a baby monitor app on my phone without telling her. That night at eleven PM, I checked and she was in bed. But when my alarm went off at 3:00am for the bathroom, I checked again the it was empty. I ran to her room and she was there, sound asleep. But her pajamas were different. The pink ones I'd put her in were replaced with purple ones. The social worker called to confirm.

My sister wore a white dress to my wedding, but it backfired in the best way possible. Emma had always been the attention seeking sister. When I got engaged to Tyler, she immediately started planning ways to make my wedding about her. She dropped hints about how she wished someone would propose to her, how she was getting older, how weddings made her so emotional. I ignored most of it because I was too busy planning the actual wedding. Two weeks before the big day, Emma casually mentioned she'd found the perfect dress. She showed me a photo on her phone. It was clearly white. Not cream, not ivory, not off white. Pure white with lace details that looked almost bridal. Emma, that's a white dress. I said, it's champagne. She lied, even though we could both see it was white. You can't wear white to my wedding. Oh, please, it's 2024. Those rules are so outdated. Besides, it'll look different in photos. I told my mom, who just sighed and said Emma would probably change her mind. I told my maid of honor, Katie, who offered to spill wine on Emma if needed. But honestly, I was too stressed with last minute wedding planning to fight about it. The morning of my wedding, I was getting ready in the bridal suite when Katie burst in. Your sister just walked in wearing that white dress, and it's worse than the photo. I looked out the window and saw Emma Posing for photos with our cousins. The dress was absolutely white, floor length, and had this dramatic train. She looked like she was trying to be a second bride. But here's where it gets good. My husband's family is Italian, and his grandmother, Nona Rosa, takes traditions very seriously. She's this tiny 85 year old woman who doesn't speak much English, but somehow always knows what's happening. During the ceremony, I could see Nona Rosa staring at Emma with this look of pure disgust. After we set our vows during the cocktail hour, Nona Rosa marched straight up to Emma. You wear white to someone else's wedding, she said in her broken English, loud enough for everyone nearby to hear.

Doing my usual deadlifts when these two girls approached me at Gold's Gym, one of them visibly pregnant. We need you to be my boyfriend, the pregnant one blurted out. Then quickly added, and my baby's father. Just for today at my baby shower, we'll give you $500 for it. I nearly dropped the 405 pounds I was holding. Here's the thing about being 6 feet, 4 inches and 240 pounds of muscle. Everyone assumes you're this tough, intimidating guy. But I was the kid who cried during Toy Story 3. when she explained that her ex had threatened to reclaim what's his at the baby shower and the cops said they couldn't do anything unless he caused actual harm, my mom's voice echoed in my head. You're big for a reason, son. Protect those who can't protect themselves. The baby shower was in three hours. She's said she'd pay for my Uber and feed me. Against every logical thought screaming in my head, I heard myself saying, yes, I'm Tony, by the way, I said. She smiled. I'm Giselle. Nice to meet you, Tony. As we drove to the venue, Giselle coached me on our fake relationship story. We met at a coffee shop six months ago, she instructed, her hands nervously rubbing her belly. Her friend chimed in from the front seat. Her ex's name is Chad. He's about 5 feet 10. He used to abuse Giselle on a daily basis and only stopped when she threatened To go to the police, always wears a backwards cap like he's still in high school. He's been texting her that he's coming to set things straight and that no restraining order will keep him from his kid. Giselle showed me photos on her phone, ultrasounds, a nursery she painted mint green, and then screenshots of Chad's messages that made me angry. I just need him to see I've moved on, she said quietly, that I have someone who actually wants this baby. She even gave me a shirt that said daddy loading 90% complete and taught me that the baby was a girl due in six weeks and we'd supposedly named her Lily. Oh, and you tear up whenever someone mentions her tiny fingers, Giselle added. That's your thing. You're a gentle giant who can't wait to have tea parties. The venue was her aunt's backyard decorated with pink balloons and a banner reading, baby coming soon. About 30 people were already there, mostly middle aged women who immediately swarmed us. I was making up stories about feeling Lily kicked during action movies and how I'd already babyproofed my entire apartment. When Chad arrived, he strutted through the back gate with this unsettling smile and made a B line for Giselle. I felt her whole body tense up beside me. Without even thinking, I stepped in them. Hey, babe, I said loudly to Giselle, wrapping my arm around her shoulders. I could feel her shaking. You need anything? Water? Somewhere to sit. Chad stopped dead, his eyes traveling up and up and up to meet mine. I watched his confidence drain from his face like water as he saw how much bigger I was than him. And suddenly he didn't want to reclaim what's his anymore. He retreated to a corner but kept watching us like a hawk. The rest of the shower became this bizarre performance where I had to be the doting boyfriend while my skin crawled knowing Chad was always there, always watching. During the gift opening, I held Giselle's hand and felt how sweaty her palm was. When she got emotional over a handmade blanket, I pulled her close and kissed her forehead. She melted into me, whispering thank you so quietly, only I could hear. Chad inched closer. I could see his face getting redder. When Giselle's aunt asked me to feel the baby kick, I, I placed my hand on Giselle's stomach and felt actual movement. Something shifted in my chest. She's strong, just like her mom, I said, and found myself meaning it. Giselle's eyes got glossy and she covered my hand with hers. That's when Chad snapped. He stormed right over, shoving past Giselle's mom. This is bullshit, Giselle. You think I'm stupid? This roided up freak isn't Lily's father. I am. His voice cracked with desperation. He reached for Giselle's arm, but I caught his wrist. Let's take a walk, little buddy, I suggested. But my grip suggested it wasn't A request in the backyard. Chad puffed up his chest and said, you don't scare me, man. That's my kid. He shoved me, or tried to, but what really happened was his hands just bouncing off my chest. I could see the fear flash in his eyes. When I did my return push, barely 10% effort, I sent him flying backward onto the grass. He scrambled up with grass stains on his jeans and tears of humiliation in his eyes, looking at me like I was the Terminator. She's done with you, I said simply, though my own hands were shaking with adrenaline. And if you come near them again, we'll have a different conversation. Chad left without another word, peeling out in his Honda Civic with a modified exhaust that fooled nobody. When I walked back to the party, Giselle ran to me and hugged me so tight I could barely breathe. The whole yard was silent. Then someone started clapping and suddenly everyone was cheering. My legs felt like jelly. Giselle said, Lily's lucky to have you as her pretend dad for a day. Well, I ended up turning into Lily's real dad, but that's a story for another day.

How did your dad lose his custody rights? I was 12 when a tornado warning Siren went off at 2:00am. Most kids never think about what their parents would actually do in a real emergency until it happens. I found out the hard way. The sirens were screaming outside our house and I could hear the wind picking up something fierce. I'd done tornado drills at school a million times. Teacher always said the same thing. Have a plan. With your family, nowhere to go, stick together. So when I heard that awful wailing sound, I did exactly what I was supposed to do. I ran straight to my parents bedroom, heart pounding in my chest. The door was already open and mom was frantically pulling clothes out of dresser drawers while dad grabbed boxes from under the bed. Grab the photo albums! Mom shouted at him, pointing to the bookshelf. What about me? I asked, standing there in my pajamas with my hair all messy from sleep. Neither one of them even looked at me. Dad rushed past me carrying our old wedding albums and some jewelry boxes. Mom was right behind him with her arms full of important papers and more pictures. I followed them downstairs, my bare feet cold on the hardwood floor. I could hear the thunder getting louder outside, and the rain was starting to hammer against the windows. The emergency radio was crackling with warnings about rotation. Spotted just a few miles away. When We got to the basement door. Mom turned around and saw me standing there. There's no more room, she snapped, like I was asking for something unreasonable. Then they shut the door right in my face. I stood there in that dark hallway alone, while the whole house shook from thunder. The sirens kept wailing, and I could hear the wind outside getting stronger and stronger. It sounded like a freight train was coming straight for us. I tried knocking on the basement door, but they didn't answer. I called for them, but nothing. So I crawled under the kitchen table with Buster, our old golden retriever, and wrapped my arms around him. He was shaking just as bad as I was. That's when it really hit me. If that tornado came through our neighbourhood, my parents weren't going to open that door for me. They'd rather save their stupid photo albums than make sure their own daughter was safe. The storm lasted about 20 minutes. It felt like hours. When the sirens finally stopped and the wind died down, I heard the basement door creek open. Mom and dad came upstairs looking all annoyed, like the whole thing had just been a big inconvenience. You should have knocked harder, mom said when she saw me still under the table. You could have been hurt if you came down with all that stuff, dad added, gesturing to their precious boxes. You'll thank us one day when we still have the Photo albums. I'm finished. But I didn't thank them. Not that night, not ever. The next week at school, missus Coleman asked our class to talk about emergency preparedness. What's something you'd grab in an emergency? She wanted to know. Kids raised their hands with all the normal answers. Jamie said she'd grab her baby brother. Tyler said his cat. Lisa said her parents

My ex left me and our kids with a note saying she'd be back in a few years. She returned 6 years later to find I divorced her and moved on. The note was taped to our bathroom mirror. Going to live with my sister in California. Need space to figure things out. Back in 2, 3 years Max. Change the locks. She left while I was at work and the twins were at school. No goodbye, no explanation to our 8 year olds. That first night was brutal. Skyler kept asking when Mommy was coming home and Walter just stared at his untouched dinner. I had no idea how to explain that their mother had essentially abandoned them for a midlife crisis. But something weird happened after the initial shock wore off. Our house became peaceful. No more constant arguing about money. No more her undermining my parenting decisions. No more walking on eggshells around her mood swings. Year one was learning mode. I figured out how to braid Skyler's hair after watching YouTube tutorials for hours. Taught Walter to throw a curve ball in our backyard. We established routines that actually worked. Homework at the kitchen table, then dinner together every night. Year 2 brought unexpected changes without the stress of a failing marriage. I got promoted at work. The kids'grades improved dramatically. We started family game nights and camping trips. I realized I've been so focused on fixing my marriage that I'd forgotten how to enjoy my Children. Year 3 changed everything. At Walter's baseball game, I met Eleanor, another single parent. She was a third grade teacher, patient and kind. When Skyler spilled juice all over herself, Eleanor calmly helped clean her up without making a big deal about it. That small moment showed me what partnership could actually look like. Eleanor and I took things incredibly slow. The kids had been through enough upheaval. But gradually she became part of our routine. She helped with homework, taught Skyler to bake cookies, and never once tried to replace their mother. Just added love to our family. Year 4, Eleanor moved in. The transition was seamless because the kids genuinely adored her. They started calling her Bonus Mom, their own idea. She attended every school event, packed their lunches with little encouraging notes and tucked them in at night. Year 5 was magical. Eleanor and I got married in our backyard. Skyler and Walter insisted on walking her down the aisle together. In their speeches, they thanked her for making dad smile again and being the mom who stayed. There wasn't a dry eye in the house. By Year 6, our life had completely transformed. We bought a bigger house with a proper yard. The kids were thriving. Skyler made honour roll. Walter was team captain. Eleanor had legally adopted them after my ex's parental rights were terminated for abandonment. We were a real family. The legal process had been surprisingly straightforward after three years of zero Contact. The court classified it as voluntary abandonment. Eleanor's adoption paperwork went through without a hitch. The kids were ecstatic to officially change their last names to match ours. Last Tuesday, everything changed again. I was making coffee when I heard Eleanor gasp from the living room. Through the window, we watched my ex climbing out of a U Haul truck, pulling suitcases toward our front door. She still had our old house key. She walked straight into our kitchen like she owned the place.

Mercedes was doing 115 miles per hour when it flew past my hidden patrol car on the highway. Not just speeding, weaving through traffic like a video game, forcing a minivan with a baby on board sticker to swerve onto the shoulder. This wasn't reckless driving anymore. This was attempted murder on wheels. When I finally got him stopped after a three mile pursuit, the driver was already on his phone. Dad, I need you to handle something now. How? He looked at me through designer sunglasses with pure disgust. You have no idea who you just pulled over. Rookie, 23 years old, reeking of alcohol at two PM on a Tuesday. When I asked for his license, he laughed. Call Chief Morrison. Tell him you pulled over his son. This conversation will be over in 30 seconds and you'll be directing traffic at elementary schools for the rest of your career. Chief Morrison, my boss's boss's boss. The man who controlled every promotion, every assignment, every career in our department. His son Tyler Morrison was legendary among cops, untouchable. D U. I s disappeared. Assault charges vanished. Even that hit and run last year somehow became a misunderstanding. Sir, I need you to step out for a field sobriety test. Are you seriously this stupid? He held up his phone showing me his father's contact. One call. One call. Your badge goes in the trash tomorrow. I've gotten 12 cops fired or transferred, 12. Their families couldn't pay their Mortgages because they thought they were heroes. My body cam was recording everything. But body cam footage had mysteriously disappeared before when Tyler was involved. I thought about my daughter's college fund, my wife's medical bills, my mortgage. Then I smelled it. Marijuana smoke, but something else. Chemical, burnt plastic. I looked in the back seat and my blood froze. Clear plastic bags with blue crystals. Not just possession amounts, distribution weight, federal prison weight. That's not mine, he said. Instantly, his arrogance finally cracking. Someone planted that. You planted that. This is a setup. I called for backup, typically requesting internal affairs and state police, not local backup. Tyler went pale. Wait, wait, wait. We can work this out. My dad has connections you could make detective tomorrow, lieutenant, by 30. Just let me make one call. While searching the vehicle, I found something that made my hands shake. Department issued radio, an actual police badge, not fake, but reported stolen eight months ago. And worst of all, a Manila envelope with photos of three female officers, soccer photos taken at their homes through windows. Officer Patricia Chen was one of them. She filed multiple harassment complaints against an unknown stalker after refusing Tyler's advances at a department Christmas party. She requested transfers three times, been denied three times. State police arrived first. As they cuffed Tyler, he screamed at me. You're done. My father owns the city. Your kids will grow up without a father because you'll never Work again. One hour later, Chief Morrison himself showed up, face purple with rage. He pulled me aside, body cam still rolling.

Happened when someone refused to take your life saving advice? I told a teenage girl she was gonna get assaulted working the night shift at a truck stop and she kicked me out for harassment. I've been driving trucks for 12 years now and I've seen people, men especially, at their darkest, late at night on the road. I started driving trucks after my daughter was born because it paid better than warehouse work. My route takes me from Dallas up through Arkansas and into Tennessee. There's this one gas station that I try to avoid like the plague. It's one of those places where the parking lot lights are half broken and there's always sketchy stuff going down. Some nightmare on Elm Street shite. Last time I was there, some tweaker tried to sell me a chainsaw at three in the morning. But sometimes you need gas and it's the only stop for 40 miles. This happened about six months ago. I pulled in around 11 at night and noticed something was different right away. The old guy who usually work nights wasn't behind the counter. Instead, there was this young girl who couldn't have been older than 19. She had bright purple hair and enough piercings to make her head explode in an MRI. Full sleeve tattoos on both arms, too. She was reading a textbook when I walked in, so I figured she was a student. I grabbed an energy drink and some beef jerky and went Up to pay? You new here? I asked while she rang me up. Yeah, started last week, she said without looking up from scanning. They had a help wanted sign in the hours work with my class schedule. My stomach dropped a little. This girl had no idea what she'd signed up for, so I told her very respectfully, listen, I don't mean to pry, but you might want to find somewhere else to work. This place gets rough, especially at night. She finally looked up at me and her face went hard. I can take care of myself, thanks. That annoyed me a little, but I needed her to understand. I'm sure you can, but the drivers that come through here aren't your average Cust. Some of these guys have been on the road for days straight. They get weird ideas in their heads, especially when they see a young woman working alone. Is that supposed to be a threat? Her voice got sharp. No, I'm trying to warn you. I've been stopping here for years, and I've seen some bad stuff go down. You need to at least keep some heat under the counter for Protection. Get out. She pointed at the door. I don't need some random trucker man explaining danger to me that I can handle myself. I don't even know what mansplaining is. I said, look, I have a daughter about your age, and I'd want someone to tell her before I could even say Anything else? She screamed out. Before I call the cops and report you for harassment. I held up my hands and backed away. Fine. I tried. Some people just won't listen when you're trying to help them. I paid for my stuff and left without another word. Back in my truck, I popped open the energy drink and did my usual safety check. Tires looked good, load was secure. I was just about to pull out when I remembered I promised my wife I'd grab diapers on the way home. My wife just had another baby girl. She goes through them like crazy and we were almost out. I sat there for a minute debating whether to go back in. The girl clearly didn't want me there, but I really needed those diapers. I waited about five minutes to let things cool down, then headed back inside. The store was empty. That purple haired girl behind the counter. I hoped for the best and told myself maybe she was in the bathroom or on break. Then I heard.

Our wedding anniversary dinner. My wife said, I'm not your property. I'm opening our marriage. She kissed my best friend and left with him. I looked around the table at my shocked family, then calmly stood up and said, actually, I have an announcement, too. I pulled out my phone and showed everyone the pregnancy test photo I'd taken that morning. Brandon's wife, Rachel, is eight weeks pregnant. Congratulations. You're going to be a stepdad. The color drained from Brandon's face. My wife's triumphant smirk vanished instantly. See, Rachel had called me crying at 6:00am. She'd found Brandon's burner phone with months of messages to my wife. Hotel bookings, love letters, the whole affair laid out in black and white. Rachel wasn't just devastated, she was furious. And pregnant. And a divorce attorney. Rachel's already filed the papers. I continued, watching Brandon panic. She's going for everything. The house, the business, full custody. She documented everything. Must. My wife tried to grab Brandon's arm, but he was already backing away. This isn't what we planned, she whispered. Oh, and honey, I said, pulling out another document, remember that promotion you've been working toward? Your boss got a very interesting email this morning about company policy violations. She stared at me in horror. You didn't. I didn't have to. Rachel's very thorough when she's angry. Brandon was already at the door, phone pressed to his ear, probably calling Rachel. My wife looked around the silent room, finally realizing she'd lost everything. For a man who just abandoned her. But I wasn't done. There's more. I said, enjoying the terror in her eyes. Rachel found out about the joint credit card you opened. The one with 30,000 dollars and charges for your romantic getaways. Guess who's responsible for that debt now that Brandon's assets are frozen? My mother in law spoke up. What are you talking about? Oh, Teresa, you might wanna call your advisor. Your daughter used you as co signer on that apartment lease downtown. The one for her business meetings. Rachel's law firm is very interested in that fraudulent application. My wife went white. You can't prove any of this. I don't need to. I smiled. Rachel has the bank records, hotel surveillance footage and testimony from the private investigator. You were too careless to

When did the I crave attention kid go too far? This kid Alonzo, in my sophomore year, was the ultimate drama queen. He'd faint during blood drives, claim he was lactose intolerant every time we had pizza parties, and somehow always had a medical emergency during tests he didn't study for. The teachers all knew his act, but they had to take it seriously just in case. Alonzo fed off any reaction he could get. If you called him out, he'd play victim and say you were bullying someone with real medical conditions. He had this whole sob story about anxiety and panic disorders that his mom apparently backed up with doctor's notes. But we all knew it was garbage. Only had episodes when it was convenient. His biggest performance happened during our school's lockdown drill in March. We were in third period history when the announcement came over the intercom. Teachers and students, please begin lockdown procedures immediately. Mrs. Stevens quickly locked the classroom door and herded all 28 of us into the supply closet at the back of the room. It was cramped and dark, but we've done this drill dozens of times before. Everyone knew the routine. Stay quiet, stay hidden, wait for the all clear. Most of us were just annoyed we were missing class time. That's when Alonzo started his performance. At first, it was just heavy breathing and fidgeting. I can't do this, he whispered to nobody in particular. I'm claustrophobic. I can't be In here? Esme, who sat next to him in chemistry, rolled her eyes. Alonzo, just shut up. It's only for, like, 10 minutes. But Alonzo ramped it up. He started hyperventilating, making these exaggerated gasping sounds like he couldn't get enough air. I'm serious, he wheedled. I can't breathe in small spaces. This is triggering my panic disorder. Missus Stevens tried calming him down with quiet words, but Alonzo was building to his crescendo. He started clawing at the closet door, pulling on the handle like a trapped animal. Let me out! He whispered frantically. I can't stay in here! I'm having a panic attack! Then he started crying. Loud, dramatic sobs that echoed in the tiny space. Twenty seven other students were shooting him death glares, making cutting motions across their throats. Anything to get him to shut up. That's when we heard Mrs. Stevens's phone buzz with a text message. Her face went completely white as she read it. This is not a drill, she whispered to us. School is an actual lockdown. The room went dead silent. Everyone's annoyed expressions turned to genuine fear. This wasn't practice anymore. There was a real threat somewhere in our school. But Alonzo, he completely lost it. He started full on screaming, banging on the closet door with both fists. Let me out! I can't breathe! Somebody help me! His voice was echoing through the hallways, potentially giving away our exact location to whoever had triggered the lockdown. Mrs. Stevens lunged Forward and
